[h1] Far Cry 5: A Scenic Yet Flawed Expedition [/h1]

[h2] Review Date: [/h2]
January 18, 2024

[h2] Reviewer Name: [/h2]
Schqrk Reviews

[h2] Overall Rating: [/h2]
6/10 ⭐

[hr][/hr]

[h2] Introduction [/h2]

Embarking on a journey through the sprawling landscapes of Hope County, Far Cry 5 attempts to weave a tale of resistance against a charismatic yet sinister cult. However, as the dust settles on this expedition, the experience falls short of the series' high standards, resulting in a game that is visually striking but marred by various shortcomings.

[h2] Graphics and Visuals [/h2]

[✔️] 🎮 Scenic Beauty: The visual presentation of Far Cry 5 is undoubtedly a strong suit. The landscapes of Hope County, from lush forests to serene lakes, are visually stunning. The game's attention to detail in capturing the Montana setting is commendable.

[✔️] 🖼️ Artistic Direction: The artistic direction complements the game's tone, enhancing the overall atmosphere. The cult-dominated landscapes, eerily beautiful in their own way, contribute to the sense of unease that permeates the narrative.

[❌] 💔 Technical Inconsistencies: While the scenery is picturesque, technical inconsistencies such as occasional texture pop-ins and minor graphical glitches detract from the immersive experience.

[h2] Gameplay [/h2]

[✔️] 🎮 Open-World Exploration: Far Cry 5 introduces an expansive open world, encouraging exploration. The diverse environments provide a sense of freedom, and the variety of vehicles adds to the open-world experience.

[✔️] ⚙️ Familiar Mechanics: The gameplay mechanics, while familiar to series veterans, offer a mix of stealth, gunplay, and vehicular combat. The seamless transition between activities keeps the experience engaging.

[❌] 💔 Repetitive Mission Structure: The main storyline and side missions often follow a repetitive structure, leading to a sense of monotony in gameplay. The formulaic approach to objectives limits the variety in mission design.

[h2] Story and Narrative [/h2]

[✔️] 📜 Cultic Intrigue: The premise of battling a religious cult led by Joseph Seed sets an intriguing stage. The charismatic yet malevolent nature of the Seed family adds depth to the narrative.

[❌] 💭 Lack of Impactful Choices: While the narrative offers moments of tension and drama, the choices presented to players don't always feel impactful. The sense of agency in shaping the story is somewhat limited.

[h2] Audio and Sound [/h2]

[✔️] 🎵 Atmospheric Soundtrack: The game's soundtrack effectively enhances the atmosphere, capturing the tension and intensity of Hope County's struggles.

[✔️] 🔊 Voice Acting: Strong voice acting performances contribute to the portrayal of the Seed family, instilling a sense of dread and conviction in their characters.

[h2] Settings and Customization [/h2]

[✔️] ⚙️ Decent Settings: Far Cry 5 provides an array of settings for players to customize their experience, from graphics options to controls.

[h2] Content and Replayability [/h2]

[✔️] 🔄 Abundance of Content: The game offers a substantial amount of content, including side activities and challenges. However, the repetitive nature of missions may affect long-term replayability.

[h2] Pros and Goodness [/h2]

[✔️] 🌟 Visual Beauty: The scenic beauty of Hope County, coupled with strong artistic direction, creates a visually appealing environment.

[✔️] 👥 Cultic Intrigue: The Seed family's presence adds an element of intrigue to the narrative, creating memorable moments.

[h2] Cons and Drawbacks [/h2]

[❌] 💔 Technical Inconsistencies: Occasional texture pop-ins and graphical glitches disrupt the immersive experience.

[❌] 💭 Repetitive Mission Structure: The repetitive nature of missions can lead to a sense of monotony.

[❌] 💭 Lack of Impactful Choices: The narrative choices don't always feel impactful, limiting player agency.

[h2] Overall Summary [/h2]

Far Cry 5's journey through Hope County offers glimpses of visual brilliance and moments of cultic intrigue. However, technical inconsistencies, repetitive mission structures, and a lack of impactful narrative choices prevent it from reaching the heights of its predecessors. The game, while enjoyable in parts, struggles to maintain the high standards set by the Far Cry series.

[h2] Why Not 10/10? [/h2]

Far Cry 5 falls short of perfection due to technical inconsistencies impacting immersion, a repetitive mission structure leading to monotony, and a narrative that doesn't fully deliver on the potential of impactful choices. While it has its moments, these drawbacks prevent it from attaining a higher score.

[h2] Completion: [/h2]
100%

I played this game (released 6 years ago) for around 5 hours so far. I remembered the time I spent on Far Cry 2. I loved it and bought this game for 13€ on sale (including all DLC's). 9€ for the base game. Forget the DLC's. All of them are garbage. 
The game looks nice, even if you need to set everything on normal because your hardware can't deal with this 6 years old game. (Ryzen 7 3700X, RTX 2070, 32 GB memory & Windows 11). To be fair, my hardware is around 6 years old. :)
It kinda find to explore the nice looking world and send some bad NPC's to hell.
What came to my attention, during my ~5 hours gameplay are some bugs:
- I felt through the ground, because I tried to use the parachute
- I need to reload a checkpoint, even I solved the mission but one of the NPC ran from the compound and left the mission area and I was not allowed to leave the mission area 
Not that much, but can't remember a game that annoyed that much in this short time. Really stupid bugs that are not fixed, even if the game is 6 years old.

The type of game you play when you just want a dumb open-world FPS and to simply wander around shooting people while doing mindless tasks that barely require any attention. If you can ignore all the USA cringe and get past the antidrug subtext, it might be a fun experience.

The gunplay is fun as hell, and blowing up shit is just absolutely satisfying. Don't expect anything else: a good story? Nah. Good characters? Meh. Just pure gameplay, son. No mental effort. Just pew pew pew. All you need is half a braincell and a pair of hands to play this game, my friend (although I'm pretty sure someone might've finished it with their feet at this point...).

So why is this a negative review? Well, to put it simple: this game aged like milk, in every aspect of it.

After the first few (fun) hours, you'll start seeing a pattern - and every encounter in the game will follow it. Sidequests are bland and useless, just like the exploration, which isn't rewarding at all. Exploring feels like a complete waste of time, and capturing outposts is just... meaningless. Characters are completely forgettable (even the boss ones), history is predictable and full of clichés, locations are uninteresting, and the list of downsides goes on... It's a game where appearances matter more than anything, and the magic goes away pretty quick. It has no substance, no charisma. It's like eating McDonalds except with no taste.

With so many excellent first person shooters out there, I would never recommend wasting your time in a mid tier Ubisoft FPS. That would be insane. Life is too short for mediocrity. Peace out.

My first thought going from Far Cry 4 to Far Cry 5 was a disappointed "oh".

What a downgrade Far Cry 5 is! I mean the music is stellar, especially the cult music, I liked the villain and his lieutenants, but somehow it just didn't come together. Pros:
 - The most beautiful environment I've played in so far
 - The sounds of the environment were just as amazing to hear as they were to see
 - Plenty to discover and do, but not too much
 - The weapons are very satisfying to use
 - More vehicles, and you can more easily call in a car or chopper when needed (instead of hunting for one)
 - The boss battles are the most creative in the Far Cry series that I know of (I haven't played FC6 yet)
 - The DLC is very fun so far, maybe a little more fun that the main game...

Cons:
 - The base missions feel very generic and don't really challenge you as you progress.
 - Although there are more vehicles, they seem to handle worse in this game than in previous ones
 - The story is kinda "meh". Some things didn't really connect with me until the end.
 - Parts of the story and general dialogue can be a little too disturbing 
 - Many of the side missions are just boring (go here, shoot this, come back, do it again)

Far Cry 5's picture of Montana was beautiful and made me want to run around in it instead of drive or fly. It's a good thing too, because the vehicles in this one just don't handle as well as in previous games IMO. The story is OK.

In conclusion DON'T BUY THE GAME EVEN ON SALE! it isn't even worth the price tag of free.

Eagle, Guns, and Cults – Oh My!

Y'all, Far Cry 5's about as redneck as a lifted truck in a Walmart parking lot. It’s like they took every backwoods stereotype, threw in a case of beer, and called it a game.

Montana’s the stage, and it's like a country song come to life - more guns than teeth, and more freedom than a bald eagle at a monster truck rally. You’ll feel like the king of the trailer park, I tell ya.

The Seed family? Hot dang, they're nuttier than a porta-potty at a chili cook-off. Joseph Seed’s preachin’ like a televangelist caught in a bear trap - all fire, brimstone, and a side of crazy.

Gameplay’s like a redneck’s dream date - huntin', fishin', and blowin’ stuff up like it's the last call at the fireworks stand. And Cheeseburger the bear? That’s America, baby - fat, sassy, and ready to bite.

Graphics are prettier than a new set of mud tires on your cousin's truck. Roamin' Montana’s like being in a beer commercial - if the beer commercial had a high body count.

The story’s twistier than a pig's tail. It's like a conspiracy theory had a baby with a moonshine recipe - strong, confusing, and packs a punch.

Multiplayer's like a family reunion, but with more explosives and less awkward questions about when you’re gonna settle down and find a nice girl.

Sure, the game’s buggier than a swamp in July, and the ending'll split opinions like a debate over Ford vs. Chevy.

To sum it up, Far Cry 5’s like a deep-fried Twinkie - not for everyone, but damn if it ain’t a wild ride. Perfect for anyone who loves freedom, firepower, and a healthy dose of insanity.

Rating: 5/5 Stars – ‘Merica, Heck Yeah Edition

Far Cry 5 is an open-world first-person shooter with a slightly tweaked Ubisoft formula. For me, it’s a decent game, but nothing special in the end. This time, Ubisoft brought the setting to the United States, specifically Montana. And it is beautiful in any of the 3 main regions. This time, we’re fighting against a religious cult that took hold of the region as their own state.
The story is alright. This time, you play as a customizable, silent protagonist. In good Far Cry tradition, it has memorable villains, especially the leader of the cult. Too bad he doesn’t appear enough. Each of the 3 regions is controlled by a sibling of the leader, and they’re all twisted in their own way.
Speaking of which, the game gives you the freedom to play the story in whatever order you want. After an introduction, you have the freedom to play through the 3 regions however you want, since their stories are self-contained. The game suggests starting with a specific region, but you can leave that one for last, or even cycle through them and play them at the same time.
One thing that I didn’t like is the story progression system. The way it works is that you need to complete activities, like missions, to fill up a progress bar. Once you reach a certain point, the next mission involving the leader sibling is unlocked. So far, so good. However, once you reach that point, you are forced into the mission. I understand that it may make the game feel more organic, but I like to explore at my own pace and didn’t enjoy being forced into the missions.
The map is big, but not too big. The size feels appropriate, although it’s mostly mountains and forest with a few locations spread out. However, even in remote areas, things are always happening, like cultists taking prisoners or dealing with the wildlife. Unless you liberated a region, since most cultists disappear after that.
There’s no mini-map; instead, you have a compass similar to the newer Assassin’s Creed titles. Another way to make the game and exploration more organic. You can still access the map at any time, but it starts with fog and there’s no easy way to reveal locations. You’ll need to explore, rescue prisoners, find maps in outposts and other locations, or look for road signs. That I enjoyed; it felt like Ubisoft took some risks, instead of revealing everything by climbing towers and buying maps, littering the map with icons.
Gameplay is also alright. It does what an FPS should do but doesn’t innovate that formula. You shoot cultists and wildlife with weapons. Weapon variety is lacking, and while you can customize them, it’s limited to changing the skin, adding a scope, a suppressor, and a larger magazine. Some weapons also support different firing modes and ammunition, but that’s it.
Being an FPS, it’s much better to play on a keyboard and mouse, but I found that activities like driving and fishing feel better on a controller. If you have both, I suggest switching up. It’s awkward, but I preferred playing this way.
There’s also a standard progression with skill points to unlock perks, and a basic crafting system. My favorite element is the addition of party members. You can recruit allies to help you in combat, and they’re actually useful. Especially the 9 unique NPCs you need to unlock; they offer a solid selection of skills. There’s a perk that allows you to have 2 of them at once, and in a way, that can break the game with the right people in the right circumstances. They can even revive you.
While I played the entire game solo, there’s also a co-op mode and multiplayer with Far Cry Arcade, including a map editor. From what I saw, there’re still some people playing this mode.
The season pass also gives you access to 3 main DLCs. Hours of Darkness is a mini-campaign set in Vietnam, and in a way is an homage to the second Rambo movie. It’s a way to experience the main game mechanics in a smaller package. Lost On Mars has a similar structure, but taking place on Mars has futuristic weapons, more jumping verticality, and the enemies are alien arachnids. They are annoying and make combat much harder. It’s also longer than the first DLC. Dead Living Zombies is a set of 7 short levels where you’re fighting zombies, mostly at close range. It also has a score attack mode with some unlocks to the main game. Getting the best scores is hard, though.
Overall, I think the DLCs are a mixed bag, but if you enjoyed the main game, I think you’ll enjoy them for the most part. Time to talk about the Ubisoft shenanigans. Obviously, you’ll need to use Ubisoft Connect, which at this time has problems like not being able to see your stats and achievements in-game. Especially the achievements; they unlock correctly, and you can see them in the desktop app, but there’s no notification when you unlock one.
And of course, there’re microtransactions, although this time they aren’t too bad for a simple reason. Everything you can buy with premium currency you can also buy with regular in-game money. Of course, this means you have to grind that money in-game, but nothing is exclusively behind a paywall.
To conclude, Far Cry 5 is another Ubisoft open-world title, with only a few significant changes. It’s a good game, but not great. But it’s usually cheap when on sale, and I can recommend it at that price.

Far Cry 5 delivers an astonishing gaming experience, though in the context of its illustrious series, it may not stand out as spectacular. What sets it apart are the diverse vibes emanating from each boss encounter, transforming your gameplay and immersing you in an ever-changing world.

The main narrative is a captivating journey filled with intrigue, unexpected plot twists, adrenaline-pumping moments, and pure, unadulterated fun. It's a rollercoaster of emotions that keeps you hooked from start to finish. Additionally, the side stories contribute their own layer of enjoyment, offering a mix of entertainment and moments that require a bit more patience but are equally rewarding.

In my assessment, Far Cry 5 deserves a stellar 9/10 rating. For those seeking an escapade where you can momentarily switch off your brain and revel in immersive gameplay, this title is undoubtedly a must-have. Dive into the captivating world of Far Cry 5 and let the adventure unfold.

Far Cry 5 delivers an unforgettable gaming experience that combines breathtaking visuals, intense action, and a gripping narrative. Set in the fictional Hope County, Montana, the game immerses players in a world on the brink of chaos, with a charismatic cult leader, Joseph Seed, at its center.

One of the standout features of Far Cry 5 is the vast and open-world environment. From lush forests to serene lakes, every detail is meticulously crafted, creating a stunning backdrop for the chaos that unfolds. The game's dynamic weather system further enhances the immersion, providing a realistic and ever-changing landscape.

The storyline is both compelling and thought-provoking, tackling themes of fanaticism and the consequences of blind faith. Joseph Seed's charismatic yet menacing presence adds a layer of complexity to the narrative, keeping players on the edge of their seats. The game's characters are well-developed, each with their own unique personalities and stories that contribute to the overall depth of the plot.

Gameplay is where Far Cry 5 truly shines. The freedom to approach missions in various ways, coupled with a vast array of weapons and vehicles, ensures that no two playthroughs are the same. The introduction of new companions adds an extra layer of strategy, allowing for diverse tactics in the fight against the cult.

The multiplayer aspect of Far Cry 5 is equally impressive. Co-op mode lets players team up with friends for chaotic and entertaining missions, while the competitive multiplayer offers intense matches that keep the adrenaline pumping.

In conclusion, Far Cry 5 is a masterpiece that successfully combines stunning visuals, a captivating storyline, and engaging gameplay. Bought this game back in 2020 and just managed to get around to it in 2023. Beat it today.

I rate this game a solid 8/10. It's strongest points are the soundtrack, core game play, side content, and some  interesting characters and possibly the best setting in the Far Cry series. 

However, the story and some questionable game play choices are ultimately what hold this game back from greatness. 

The perks and upgrading system is pretty good. Good variety of guns to customise and upgrade. Buying and selling system is really good and the fishing and hunting is fun enough and will be the main source of your income. The map is littered with a healthy variety of activities to partake in. In summary, most of the traditional Far Cry elements are here for you to play around with.

This game will keep you busy. I took my time and beat the campaign along with some side content in about 28 hours. I have probably another 10-15 hours worth of side content to complete which I may or may not do. The multiplayer is basically dead but there is a solo arcade option which can give you almost endless challenge. 

Overall, great game, but not without its flaws. Story could have been better. It's probably worth the price tag of $39.99 at this point in 2024. Been about 6 years since this game came out.
The co-op in this game was a huge upgrade. A lot of quality changes and feels like a breeze of fresh air in the series. I highly recommend playing this game.

I've been playing video games since 1991 and Ubistupid was at one time a name a person could trust ... I've long since sighed every time I see a game I'm interested in is published them.

The Sneed family apocalypse cult vs Waco County police department

What is essentially Farcry 3 with some minor improvements and flair here and there; in other words this is Farcry 3.5. Mechanically and gameplay wise it does feel like the most well designed of the Farcry games, but there aren't any surprises here. You'll roam about the countryside, doing side quests and liberating outposts; hunting for money to buy guns etc, etc.

The setting and the characters are the most interesting parts of the game by far. Though the game's statements are somewhat (understandably) superficial, there are things that it's trying to say. Joseph and the cult try over and over to forcefully convert the player in the same way they've been indoctrinated. And they'll go to extreme lengths to justify themselves and keep their moral superiority, all the while purging the countryside in rural America. It's a bit spicy of a premise, but in practice, the game waters it down quite a bit. The most cogent theme of the game I could muster is man's ever-burning desire for simple solutions to complicated problems. Joseph builds the rock of his cult on giving people simple solutions and a reason to lash out against the world.

It's a fun time. There are always going to be spots that could use more polish in an open world game like this. I was starting to get a bit tired of the game around the 20 hour mark. Though the gun roster isn't expansive it's fine enough. Mostly by the end my pattern recognising brain was ailing. These cultist types love their big coats, beards, scraggly white sweaters, and stealing every possible kind of vehicle in the county. You also get captured 20 to 30 times during the game. All of this with a factory model silent protagonist.

Overall, it does what it does pretty well, ending notwithstanding. It certainly is one of the games of all time.

Far Cry 5 is considered by many to be the last good Far Cry game. I agree. Overall I think this is a worthy entry in the FC series and worth a purchase (especially on sale which it seems to be often). However, in many ways I don't think it lives up to FC3 and FC4. Like all FC games it has its' issues.

Where FC5 succeeds:
This is the first FC game that felt "next-gen". It's a significant graphic and performance upgrade vs FC3 and FC4. It played well on my PC minus a few non-game breaking bugs. Hope County looks really good.

The music is great. Has some of the best music in the franchise if not the best.

The sandbox part of this game is much more expansive and open compared to previous entries. Tons of weapons, vehicles, and allies you can use. However, this leads into the bad parts of this game.

Where FC5 fails:
FC5 has an open mission structure. This means you can approach one of three main regions in any order to progress the story. From a sandbox perspective this might be good, but it breaks the game up and really hurts the story.

Speaking of story, it's...ok. The story itself is interesting especially if you dig deeper into it. However, it really fails in its presentation. All three regions basically capture you (several times each) to get to the next major plot point. The Deputy must be the luckiest person alive, the player, not so much. It makes the villains seem incompetent.

What is truly incompetent is the enemy AI. They aren't the worse in the franchise but they aren't improved from older titles. The difficulty in this game is odd. If you play on the hardest difficulty available at the start, the enemies hit really hard. This makes the few scripted sequences frustrating since you don't have control. However, due to how open the game is it doesn't matter how hard the enemies hit. With certain companions and weapons you basically play on easy mode.

The vehicles controls on m&k are pretty bad, especially the planes. This isn't unique to FC5 but it has to be mentioned.

A quick note on the DLC:
I really disliked the Mars DLC. It was a slog to get through. However, if you beat it before starting the main game, you'll get some Mars weapons right off the bat which makes you basically unstoppable.

The zombie DLC was also pretty bad. Just completely forgettable. I actually forgot this game had it until I looked it up.

The Vietnam War DLC is the best of the bunch, but not by much. It's very linear but at least it has some replay value. The issue with this DLC is you can just run straight to the end and beat it. I beat it in around half an hour on the hardest difficulty.
Decent far cry. Certainly better than 6.

Before I say anything about the game I just wanna make it clear that this is basically the exact same game we've been getting since FC3 but that is not my main problem with it. I still love this open world Ubisoft style of game, and even with Assassin's Creed (and Immortals to an extent) pivoting to the same style I am still not sick of it yet.

Another important note is that this is a Ubisoft game so expect overpriced and mediocre DLCs at best and terrible forced integration with their launcher to use their DRM.

With all that said, this is a fun game to me as a fan of other games in this style but with one major caveat that absolutely guts the pace of gameplay. Every time I get immersed in to the games open world and start enjoying exploring and messing around with the sandbox elements they send a "capture party" and make you watch ~30 minutes of cutscenes. Interesting concept, but poorly executed. I think it would be much more enjoyable if the capture party was a group of challenging enemies that you can actually fight off but NO. Instead the first time they hit you with a bullet the screen gets all fuzzy and your character blacks out. Even this system could be fine if there was a way to escape capture but even flying to the highest possible point (the capture parties never use helis or planes) you will eventually just be forced to black out. This is insanely annoying, don't see how this made it to release. At the very least New Dawn and 6 get this right. There are other ways to tell this otherwise alright story in a way that doesn't rip you away from the actual great part, the gameplay, for an extended period of time if you don't want to be.

[h1]Intro[/h1]
Many people regard Far Cry 5 as a bad game. I think for new and casual players, it is alright: there is value in the exciting gunplay and beautiful scenery even though rapid despawning and frequent pop-ins can be annoying. But if you are critical about games, it is an mediocre game that you should steer away.

[h1]Stale Gameplay[/h1]
Since Far Cry 3, the series has become a sandbox experience, where the game provides tools and means and challenges, and lets players approach objectives however they want. A good example is outpost taking, my favorite part of the series, where the players can take on it in many ways, such as direct combat (with various weapons), stealth, sniping, etc.

With the success of the predecessors, Far Cry 5 follows the same sandbox design and mechanics, but adds a few things: companions that aid you with various skills, a bigger and easier-to-access category of vehicles offering new tactics like bombing; and more side quests and activities such as auto-generated events, fishing and arcade (warp to other maps to complete objectives), though at the cost of being overwhelming at the start.

(Control of aircraft and wingsuit is secretly terrible, except you mitigate by enabling aircraft mouse control, but you can't with wingsuit.)

In the sense of being a sandbox like the predecessors, it is a step in the right direction as it adds more means, tools and challenges. But after Far Cry 3, 4 and Blood Dragon playing exactly the same, these surface-level changes are not enough since returned players can quickly realize they have already done the same thing three times. I guess if you’ve never played any Far Cry game, it is alright. Yet the series was in need of revamping its gameplay to prevent things from getting stale, but Ubisoft failed to deliver.

(Far Cry Primal is a bit different in gameplay for it largely focuses on repetitive material gathering and doesn’t have diverse gunplay as you only have three weapons.)

[h1]Fragmented Experience[/h1]
The biggest change to the game is the mission structure, and it is not good - players must finish open-world content to accumulate main quest progression. Technically, there is a mission category called main quest, but most of them are just open-world content rebranded, and only a few are real scripted levels, like destroying the statue or escaping the bunker.

Far Cry series used to have these long, well-crafted and enjoyable scripted levels for main quest sequences, which are essential to the storytelling, character development and playing experience. With this change, they are gone in favor of players doing more open-world stuff, which are short, tasteless and hastily put together. Even for the few remaining scripted levels, they are short and you probably finish them right when you start to enjoy yourself.

I don’t think it is because they ran out of development time, but an ongoing trend for Ubisoft to replace handcrafted scripted level with generic open-world content, seeing other Ubisoft titles have the same change in design. It seems Ubisoft has become lazy and stopped caring about their games.

What’s worse, it is not just the scripted levels, but a large portion of missions in Far Cry 5 are short, even outpost taking somehow is briefer than Far Cry 4. I don’t know if many people notice, that many missions take just a bit longer, or even shorter than the time to travel there to finish. Essentially, players spend lots of time traversing whereas they should’ve spent more time in action, and this unreasonable time distribution makes the experience feel fragmented and dissatisfying. It is probably why a few players I talked to state the game feels weird yet can’t pinpoint why.

(Took me 32 hours to finish everything except collectibles and arcade in the base game, much shorter than 45 hours of Far Cry 4; there are lots of collectibles in Far Cry 5 to extend its playtime.)

[h1]Empty Story[/h1]
I see the above two aspects as flaws, but the story is the severe blow: it is lazy and sloppy, and the first time I feel the scriptwriters were incompetent while being self-absorbed in writing the story.

An evident example is that, as the progression bar is full, players will be automatically teleported to the main quest, no matter where they are or what they are doing. It is so hasty and hilarious seeing players get kidnapped/OD’d/hypnotized alone in a car, in a chopper, during swimming, or flying a wingsuit, but that isn’t the worst part yet.

Far Cry 3 and 4 are great in storytelling. Take 4 as an example, there are complexities in villains and heroes to convey a story about there is no definitive black and white, whereas Far Cry 5 only has a blank story with unrelatable characters. With story time has already been cut short because of the change in mission structure, that precious time was dedicated to four villains talking some mumbo jumbos that make no sense. I don't know what those monologues are for, because they neither develop the characters nor convey any constructive message, and they aren't even relatable or intimidating to audiences. It seems to me they are just there to dial the edginess of villains to eleven, to cover the fact that there is no substance in character and story.

Heroes only exist to give missions. So, despite a much larger cast of characters than any predecessor, all of them combined have no more personality than a piece of wood, making the story impossible to empathize with. Yet somehow, scriptwriters were fixated on making a surprise at the end - they wrote a deus ex machina ending(s) which may be offensive to some people, to impress no one but themselves, because the story is so empty that no one cares.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
As a Far Cry fan, it is sad and disappointing to see a great series end up like this. It is probably a good example of why Ubisoft is getting less and less relevant in recent years: always picks the tried-and-tested safe route and lacks love, care and creativity.

For recommendations, Far Cry 3 and 4 are the best if you are interested in the series, or Blood Dragon for something shorter. I heard even the latest Far Cry 6 is much better than 5, though I have yet to play.

Characters: 
In the heart of Montana, you’ll encounter Joseph Seed, a charismatic yet enigmatic cult leader. While he lacks the iconic flair of Vaas or Pagan Min from previous Far Cry games, his presence sets the stage for an unforgettable journey. His motivations may be murky, but the story weaves unexpected twists, making it worth seeing through to completion. And for the first time in the series, you can choose between a male or female protagonist, adding a touch of personalization. Alas, your character remains mute, referred to simply as “The Deputy.”

Story: 
Far Cry 5 thrusts you into the heart of a religious cult that has taken over a sizable chunk of Montana. Joseph Seed’s Eden’s Gate cult has amassed weapons, influence, and resources, rendering it an impenetrable militia. As a sheriff’s deputy, your mission is clear: dismantle this dangerous organization. The narrative unfolds against the backdrop of Hope County, where every corner holds surprises. From public executions to hidden secrets, the story keeps you engaged.

Graphics: 
The meticulously constructed world of Far Cry 5 mirrors the beauty of Big Sky Country—rolling plains, dense forests, winding rivers, and majestic mountains. However, it’s not on the same visual level as titles like Horizon: Zero Dawn or Assassin’s Creed Origins. The landscape density occasionally causes distracting pop-in, and load times can test your patience. But fear not; the overall presentation is solid, even if it doesn’t reach the pinnacle of graphical excellence.

Content: 
Hope County is a gigantic open world where things are constantly blowing up, wild animals are pouncing, and a never-ending supply of cultists lines up for target practice. Whether you’re sneaking through outposts, engaging in intense firefights, or encountering glitchy moments, the gameplay keeps you on your toes. The variety of missions, from serious to downright hilarious, ensures there’s never a dull moment. Just watch out for those magically appearing trees!

Overall Recommendation: 
Far Cry 5 delivers the most fully realized, player-driven entry in the series. It’s an awesome open-world action game that invites you to explore, strategize, and create chaos. So grab your weapons, rally some allies, and dive into this wild adventure. Montana isn’t just serene landscapes; it’s also home to some seriously dangerous folks. Highly recommended for thrill-seekers and open-world enthusiasts!

Best far cry game in the series. Far cry 3 is just right behind it.

I think Far Cry 5 got a lot of unfair flack from the community. Being this far into a series, the gameplay isn't going to be anything groundbreaking. What it is, though, is polished and fun.

However, I still have some issues with it. The AI is very strange, and sometimes you'll be minding your business when a technical shows up and mows you down in 3 hits. The gameplay itself is pretty nice to play, and very easy to control, I just think the health and AI aren't keeping pace.

The boss fights are actually quite good. My favorite has to be the dogfight with John Seed. Jacob's fight is a sniper hill, easily completed with 2 RPG shots, while Faith's fight was the most technical of the 3; kinda feeling like I was playing Destiny or Borderlands for a little bit.

The story is miles ahead of the previous entries. Joseph Seed is an absolute menace, and his siblings are just as frightening story-wise. You begin the game as a Deputy of the Hope County Sheriff's Department, executing an arrest warrant for Joseph Seed, leader of the Eden's Gate cult that has taken over large areas of the county. Shit promptly goes sideways and you're separated from your teammates, left to fend for yourself in hostile territory; the typical Far Cry experience. What's different is that the world is divided up into 3 parts, and you can tackle them in any order you desire. Once you're done, you take on Joseph and the ending begins. I have to admit, despite knowing about the next game in the series, I was still sitting there jaw agape as the credits began to roll and "We'll Meet Again" began to play.

Speaking of the credits, the music selection is actually very good. There are a total of 2 Creedence Clearwater Revival songs, and neither of them are "Fortunate Son"; a remarkable achievement in my honest opinion. "Only You" is setup well in the story, and by the end you'll be joining the many other gamers who are now traumatized by that song.

The side missions, on the other hand, fell flat for me. One too many forced stealth missions rescuing hostages than I would like. As I said earlier, the AI is strange, and Far Cry AI has never been amazing in the first place. This turns those hostage rescues into a slog of resets until the AI cooperates. Just not a fun time. The Gun For Hire missions were on the opposite end of the spectrum, each and every one was enjoyable in their own right.

Overall, despite having it shelved for many years, I actually quite enjoyed what Hope County had to offer, and I kind of want to play Far Cry New Dawn just to find out what happens next.

Far Cry 5 is a game of highs and lows. It has an incredibly memorable campaign and characters, but is also so frustrating, rigid, and nihilistic that I honestly cannot say if it is good or not. 
The core gameplay is peak Far Cry where all of the innovations from the previous titles work together to make combat fun and engaging. Stealth and going Rambo are both viable options to take down most levels and outposts with plenty of equipment and skills to help you play how you want. This also leads to one of the games greatest flaws in that unlike 3, 4 and Primal where there was an XP system, in 5 you have to do actions to unlock skill points. This involves playing certain ways that might not align with your style in order to get ahead such as getting X amount of flame thrower skills even though you want to stealth, hunt X amount of specific animals, take x amount of drugs, etc. They probably implemented this to try and get the player to try out all the different weapons and activities but instead it just hampers the fun if you like to play a very specific way since you get penalized for it. 

Montana is a cool if nonsensical setting for Far Cry, taking place in a rural American county under siege by an apocalyptic Christian cult that has cut off all access to the outside world. Apparently if you listen to the radio and read some notes it explains that the US and the world at large is in the middle of huge political upheaval and that is why no one outside comes to help but it is still a pretty dumb excuse that you have to actually hunt for and destroys the suspension of disbelief. 

Far Cry 5 takes the popular story dynamics of 3 and 4 and ups them to 11 but in my opinion fumbled it badly. 3 and 4 were known for their strong antagonists with extremely memorable dialogue. Vaas and Pagan Min were equal parts charismatic, humorous, and intimidating. However you only meet Vaas a few times in person in the game and Pagan Min is only really communicated with on a walkie talkie the entire game. To try and one up this in 5 they introduce 4 antagonists being the Seed family with the leader Joseph and his siblings. To circumvent the lack of face to face interaction the players had in previous title, the Seed family will abduct you at certain times in the game so they can have a scene with the player. It is incredibly poorly done being that you can be in the middle of a mission and suddenly you black out so that one of the Seeds can just insult and torture you for a few minutes to show off how evil they are. Unlike previous titles, the player character does not have a name and does not talk. This makes the scenes even worse as the "Rookie" goes through worse scenarios than even Jason Brody and Ajay but cannot say a single thing when the Seeds go on their annoying diatribes about the apocalypse, sin, natural selection, etc. The game basically makes the Seed family these omnipotent demonic entities that can kidnap you at any time just to let you go and insult you until next time. On top of that the game ends on such a terrible nihilistic note that it makes you wonder why you even bothered to play the game to begin with. New Dawn, the sequel to 5 makes it a little easier to stomach but barely and it still by far the worse story for a Far Cry game in my opinion. 

TLDR: 5 is a game with clashing gameplay mechanics and a story that can be annoying and hard to sit through. The core mechanics however, are better than they have ever been and the game can be extremely fun if not a little easy when played coop. Just be aware that if you do play coop, none of the coop partners progress carries over to their solo game.

 One more game from the Far Cry franchise. This time with massive anti-Christian and female supremacy propaganda. The gameplay is probably the best of all the Far Cry games that I’ve played, but the uplay launcher and political messaging ultimately ruin the game.

 As in other Far Cry games, the story is tipically short, unnecessarily brutal and nihilistic, with lots of lazy writing. This time the evil doers are a fantasy cult based on the Catholic church. Both possible endings are terrible and fit in with the poor overall story line.
 As with other Far Cry games, the open world is fun to explore and Far Cry 5 offers even more fun, with stunt challenges, treasure hunts, fishing and hunting challenges. Fishing is fun and easy, but not very profitable. Hunting is very easy, but is on the other hand very profitable if you hunt high value animals. Apart from cars we can use boats, aircraft and helicopters. I found them fun to drive and fly around, except for the aircraft, which has weird controls and a flight model that is worse than some 30 years old DOS games that I've played. The overall gameplay is arcade, as usual. There are only a few weapons but most have upgrades like silencers, different optics, increased magazine sizes, and color scheme options to choose from, which can be fun. The sights are a bit of a downer, as at night they glow too much. Gunplay is slightly better than in Far Cry 3.

 The game was enteratining, but after discovering most of the map (99.9%), finishing all of the challenges (fishing, stunt etc.) I feel there is very little more for me to do. It took me about 40 hours to do literally everything, except maybe going for some achievements hunting. There is Game+ mode which carries over perks, so this might be an incentive to replay and try for a different ending. Despite all, I find Far Cry 5 the best of the series that I've played so far (2, 3, 5 + New Dawn).

 I don't recommend this game because of the program needed to play, called uplay. Apart from it being a terrible program, on my second playthrough on highest difficulty (game+, 50+% completed) uplay got updated and deleted all of my saves and settings. I've now uninstalled this game and will never again buy anything from ubisoft. Thank you ubisoft, for wasting my time. Ironically enough my completed game for New Dawn save remains…

Hopefully last update: After nine months and no solution from support (and my ticket being closed because I was told to wait while they investigate, this was almost half a year ago) I seemed to have found solution myself. For some reason the default MTU of 1500 is too high for Ubisoft Connect to function properly on my PC, lowering it to 1452 somehow fixed it.

----------------

Update: It's now been over two months, and the support still hasn't managed to solve my problem with Ubisoft Connect. The responses in my ticket have been going back and forth between same troubleshoot steps, sfc and beyond. It was escalated for a little while, and then returned back to normal support for some reason. Will update again if anything changes.


--------------------------

Update: Apparently Redhorn error has been resolved, but unfortunately I am still unable to co-op due to Ubisoft Connect not connecting to the servers without using VPN. I have been in talks with Ubisoft support, but there hasn't been solution to the problem during the three weeks my ticket has been open, instead I have been asked to go through the same troubleshoot steps I said I have already done. 

I will change by review if/when the issue is fixed.

------------------------

Bought the game over a week ago to play Co-op with my husband, but I have been unable to access the game without the use of a VPN, and even then I am met with Redhorn error when attempting to connect to the game servers.

I never reviewed a game, but I have to open an exception for this one. Everything is fine, until the ending, that is really simplistic and invalidates all the hours spent in this game. If I could I would pay the game's price again to removed it from my library and my mind.
nice game

***Pros***

Hunting
Fishing
Gun Play
Combat
Perk System
World
Co-operative campaign* (see Cons)

***Cons***

Cruelty to animals
Inconsistent writing
Obnoxious dialogue at times
Boomer won't get in vehicles
Players cannot join an existing session
*Co-operative campaign (No Shared Progression)
There is no controllable flashlight (the game turns one on for you when certain conditions are met)
Lack of any night vision equipment
Nighttime is far too long
Far too easy to accidentally switch your weapon with what is on the ground when just attempting to loot a corpse
No way to access certain weapons without visiting a Shop
No Steam Achievements
Denuvo Anti-Tamper DRM

***Final Thoughts***

I don't feel that hunting and fishing are cruelty to animals. However, some of the missions in this game are cruelty to animals and really serve no purpose other than for shock value and thus devalue the overall product.

The gun play is tight and the combat is satisfying. There are varying levels of intensity, with the Cult Outposts Liberation missions being the most robust to engage with.

The main story is fairly well-written however, the manner in which some dialogue is delivered is verbose and can be obnoxious at times.

Some of the side missions are poorly written or just stupid (not the ones that are obviously self-deprecating).

The lack of a controllable flashlight or some form of night vision capability is mind-boggling.

4 out of 5

Игра уныла.

*Сеттинг - для ярых фанатов культуры реднеков.
*Графика - вроде бы неплохо все, но свет отвратителен, в частности реализация засветов - какой-то HDR на стероидах. Если использовать HDR-режим то становится все только хуже.
*Баги - игре уже куча лет и она так и осталась полна багов, тысячи их. И животные внутри камней, и умирать вы будете без причины, и невидимые стены, и проваливаться сквозь землю - список огромен. 
*ИИ - туп до безобразия, к середине игры уже начинает выбешивать. Отдельных какашек в панамку разрабам за то, что NPC, с которыми ведешь диалог, могут сагриться на врага в километре от них и прекратить диалог пока этот враг не будет уничтожен.
*Персонажи - не интересные. Возможно потому, что из игры в игру убисофтом идет копипаста персонажей.
*Геймплей. Тут есть пара хороших моментов: убрали проклятые вышки, сделали гринд-задания не обязательными. Весьма разнообразны задания поиска сокровищ. Ну и на этом все.
*Сценарий. Идея хорошая, реализация посредственная. С каждым "боссом" все по одинаковой рутине - они "воруют" вас несколько раз, каждый раз сопровождая долгими беседами и каким-то магическим образом вы каждый раз от них убегаете. Отдельное слово про киднеппинг ГГ который тупо реализован через гаснущий экран - убисофт не заморачивались. Впрочем, нельзя не отметить, что один момент приятно удивил в конце разборок с Джейкобом [spoiler] появление Илая в конце было неожиданным. Но и тут фигня - не убить его нельзя, миссия стартует заново[/spoiler] . Ну и концовка вообще ни о чем, опять все происходит магическим образом.

Возможно в это все дело веселее играть компанией, но для соло уныло так, что DLC даже запускать не стал, с меня достаточно.

Rating: ★★★☆☆

Far Cry 5 offers players a mixed bag of experiences, and it's a game that has both its strengths and weaknesses. Let's dive into what worked and what didn't.

The storyline is, to put it mildly, bizarre and may only be fully appreciated by those with a penchant for the surreal or mentally unstable. The narrative seems to take a nosedive into the realm of the absurd, making it hard for more grounded players to truly engage with the plot. The events unfolding in the game feel dumb beyond dumb, lacking the depth and coherence that one might expect from a AAA title.

However, where Far Cry 5 excels is in its visually stunning world. The scenery is nothing short of breathtaking, with meticulously crafted landscapes that truly immerse players in the game's environment. Exploring the vast, open-world setting is a joy, and the attention to detail in the design of the surroundings is commendable.

On the downside, the whole Bliss concept feels forced and falls flat. The attempt to inject a sense of mystery and intrigue through this element ultimately comes across as contrived and unconvincing. It's not the kind of captivating narrative twist that adds depth; instead, it feels more like a desperate attempt to introduce an element of surprise that doesn't quite hit the mark.

Another perplexing aspect is the inability to pick up money directly, being restricted to exchanging it for items. This bug may frustrate players who enjoy the immediacy of collecting currency in other games. It's an odd bug that feels so stupid and limits the player's agency in managing their resources.

Despite its narrative missteps and quirky design choices, Far Cry 5 does have its merits. If you can overlook the oddities and appreciate the game for its visually stunning world, it might be worth a shot, especially considering its affordability. Far Cry 5 is an okay game for those looking for a budget-friendly gaming experience, as long as you can embrace the eccentricities and enjoy the beauty of its virtual landscapes.

2/5 stars from me.
This game isn't bad, but the plot is jarring and lost on me, the map is too big, the grind is real, and there are far, far too many enemies.

The world is so big that you have to fast travel or spend 5 minutes walking through the woods or on the road to a place across the street on the map. Or if you are willing to risk driving, you'll still take forever to get anywhere and only increase your chances of getting attacked since this game goes out of it's way to disincentivise driving. (The roads are actively patrolled where an enemy will pass by at least once a minute, there's active roadblocks preventing progress).

There are so many enemies between locations that I can't avoid any fights when travelling on foot from point a to point b. In five minutes you could face off against 15 enemies, an explosive tanker, a loot truck, a prison escort, and a truck with a machine gun if you travel on the road and encounter just 1 enemy. And that's at 0 Resistance level. At level 1 Resistance, they bring helicopters out to search for you, rocket launchers, water vehicles, and similar out against you. It's brutal and unforgiving, giving no chances to loot or breathe.

And if you take your time, start exploring, go back to areas you previously explored because you unlocked something that will help, or anything of the sort, then you're actively punished by the game with a forced cut scene that will magically teleport you closer to where your main mission is in that area. Needless to say, that's not a good or liked feature in my opinion. Extremely jarring. "You are walking through the apple orchards by yourself, hunting turkeys, deer, and cougars for feathers and pelts to sell, then BAM! Suddenly you're treated as though dead or dying, are dosed with bliss, and getting waterboarded. When the cutscene ends, you're in the middle of a high-stakes action sequences halfway across the map." The fluck?! Not cool!

My experience was completely disjointed, with jarring plot and non-stop action where you can't get a break unless you choose to grind. And even when you're grinding or simply fishing or something, you still can't catch a break because wildlife or enemies will spot and attack you if you stay in one spot for too long. Stealth is a must, and even if you are stealthy and disable all alarms, somehow reinforcements will still arrive.

I give this game 2 of 5 stars.

Far Cry 5 offers an engaging experience in an apocalyptic world controlled by religious fanaticism. 

With breathtaking landscapes and action-packed gameplay, the game captures attention. 

Despite some repetitive missions, the variety of weapons and tactics adds charm to the adventure. 

The plot might not be the deepest, but the engaging soundtrack and overall atmosphere make Far Cry 5 a satisfying experience for fans of open-world shooters.

The Good:
Gameplay is fun, lots of cool mechanics, fun to play either loud or stealth. You get to pet a goddamn grizzly bear.
The Bad:
Some minor UI control glitches. Bad, dumb follower AI (be prepared to wait for them to get in your vehicle).
The Ugly:
The story is great, but the last mission throws away literally everything you work for. There is a sequel: Far Cry New Dawn, that apparently addresses this, but a game should be self-contained and going by that logic, shit's fucked.
The Unforgivable:
Fishing as a major part of the game, because why WOULDN'T you have a badly made, *intentionally* time-consuming mechanic in your game?

Excellent member of this extremely fun series. Great villain(s) and an awesome soundtrack, make this a lot of fun to play. The usual "simulation" mechanics create a lot of interesting, often chaos-filled, scenes. Much more often than not creative ideas one has turn out to work because the whole approach is more simulation-based rather than trigger-event-based. This often leads to very satisfying game play. There is a lot of humour as well, so I can highly recommend this one. Personally, I find it to be more satisfying than Far Cry 4.

For the ending you'll [spoiler]need your big boy pants[/spoiler].

Best Far Cry for me. It stayed fun and engaging throughout the whole game while other FC's like the 3rd and 4th didn't spark the same with me. It's a gorgeous game with an amazing story, but a pretty weak and unsatisfying ending to me.

I wouldn't recommend buying this game for the multiplayer, you have to stay very close to eachother, which is pretty annoying.
Some side quests can be annoying, like having to follow an npc for ages or doing fetch quests, but most of them are really fun and unique.

Overall, a 9/10

Far Cry 5 is a game I was really excited about, I'm a total bitch for religious themes and having a Far Cry game where you fight against a cult of lunatics is definetly my kinda shit. I have to say I enjoyed my time playing the game, but I can't say I love it because of a few reasons which I think are pretty fucking important when it comes to games in general. 

First of all, the game is riddled with technical issues to the point where I think it'd be impossible for me to play this without mods. The game has this stupid bug where everytime it saves, it does a little stutter which lasts for about half a second. The problem is, the game autosaves for [b] literally anything [/b]. Saw a sign showing a new hunting ground for a specific animal? Save. Picked up some money from a table? Save. Picked up A FUCKING ARROW ON THE GROUND? SAVE. It's impossible to play the game for 5 minutes without coming across a stutter because of autosaving and that makes the game unplayable from the get-go. I think it's unacceptable that a game can only be played normally with the use of mods, and it's not just perfomance, a lot of simple features just aren't in the game and it really takes away from the whole experience. Lucky for us, modding the game is easy and helps a lot. If you are even thinking of buying FC5, the Resistance Mod is basically obligatory. Some mods that I recommend are: Autosave Stutter Workaround, which removes the excessive autosaving (you still get the stutters when it saves, tho), FOV unlocker (some interactions like climbing ladders reset your FOV to default while being performed, this fixes that), No Capture Parties to remove this very annoying feature (it spawns a mission instead which you can play anytime you wish) and the RP - Reward System which increases the amount of points you need to finish a region, usually you can finish a region without much effort, this mod increases the needed amount so you play the game more and complete more missions before the final confrontation. Some cosmetic mods are recommended too like Restoring Skinning Animations or Faster Parachute.

However, once you download the correct mods, the game is pretty good. It has a satisfying gunplay, nice first person features (which Far Cry is known for), and the characters are really well done. Joseph and his family are great villains and it feels very nice to fight them, I do think Jacob shines above all of them when it comes to having an impact on the player, but they all serve a great purpose on the story. 
That said, I do think the game is too non-linear for its own good, since anything you do helps to advance the story it never feels like you're part of a big plot, it does feel fun to go through each region getting to know the characters and the villains and the people, but I feel like the plot lacks a little personal connection to the player (the protagonist being mute doesn't help it either). The cutscenes when you get captured feel so out of sync with the rest of the game, like, you get captured, some bad shit happens and 10 minutes later you're back to the open world like nothing happened, basically you don't really feel the impact of things happening around you and that kinda sucks.
It also does lack a little bit on the "Far Cry" side of things, a lot of features that are franchise staple at this point are not here, there are no knife takedowns, you can't craft medkits and you have only one healing animation which is the player wrapping a bandage around their arm. Far Cry is about getting personal with the world and the protagonist, and so far, 5 is the one with the least of that.
But I don't think it's a bad game, fighting the enemy feels great, hunting feels really nice, and you can fish!
There are many weapons you can customize and many different ways to kill Peggies, you also have a shovel as a melee weapon which I gotta admit I used a lot more than I probably should and it was real fucking funny everytime

Overall, it's a pretty good game, even if it has a lot of technical issues I have to say I enjoyed myself, especially at the end while I was going against Jacob I really feel like the game shined and I had a lot of fun. Also the game looks pretty gorgeous but that's no surprise. Also also, the endings are probably the best FC has seen so far and I loved every one of them, super fucking metal, definetly left me speechless for a good 30 minutes

Far Cry 5 is a refreshing take on the series, not in game play standards, but in story. The idea that Ubisoft would tackle a controversial subject such as religion aids to the unique feeling of this game and the world it build. Joseph Seed and his underlings is eerily reminiscent of real world cults, and helps build a gang of followers that could 100% happen in real life. The combat is smooth and satisfying, and the gun sounds and play are fantastic. Furthermore, this game is does not take is self seriously all the time, which helps keep the player engaged in story changes. Being able to maul cultists to death with a hillbilly and a brown bear never gets old. Because this is an older title, I do think that $60 is a bit much of an asking price. When this game goes on sale however, it is worth it.

[b]Far Cry 5 takes you on a thrilling ride through the captivating landscapes of Hope County, delivering an action-packed adventure that feels like a gaming masterpiece. As a tech-savvy gamer, immersing yourself in this game is akin to stepping into an adrenaline-fueled playground of chaos and liberation.

[i]Pros:
Open-World Freedom: The game excels in offering an expansive open world filled with diverse activities and side quests, providing players with the freedom to explore at their pace.
Compelling Storyline: Far Cry 5's storyline, centered around a cult's takeover in rural Montana, provides a gripping narrative that keeps players engaged and invested throughout the game.
Stunning Visuals: The game boasts stunning graphics and attention to detail, rendering the picturesque landscapes of Hope County with breathtaking realism, enhancing the overall immersive experience.
Versatile Gameplay: Players can approach missions and encounters with varied strategies, thanks to the diverse arsenal of weapons and vehicles at their disposal.

Cons:
Repetitive Side Content: Some players might find the side quests and activities to be slightly repetitive, potentially impacting the overall novelty of exploration.
Lackluster AI: At times, the AI behavior of both allies and enemies can feel inconsistent or less challenging, affecting the game's immersion during combat scenarios.[/i]

In summary, Far Cry 5 stands out as a thrilling open-world adventure, offering an engaging storyline, diverse gameplay options, and stunning visuals. While it may have some repetitive elements and AI issues, the game's immersive world and engaging gameplay make it a standout choice for fans of action-adventure games.[/b]

Where are we now? Far Cry 5. What to describe about this game? This one feels much higher in every detail of the open world, and the sheer depth of the gameplay mechanics, compared to the usual Ubisoft games. This feels like it was partly done by Rockstar North at times.

Pros:
1. Brilliant open world. Hope County, Montana is detailed. 
2. So much to do. Prepper stashes, the phone calls, voicemails left behind, all contribute to the brilliance and character of the open world. 
3. Antagonists. All 4 antagonists are well done. Jacob, John, Faith have their own character and, Joseph...Greg Bryk's portrayal of Joseph Seed is very much, in one word, surprisingly good.
4. Lore. The lore in this game is better than any Far Cry game till date, and I mean it.
5. Gameplay. It's smoother, well refined, and most bugs have been squashed out by now. Gunplay is extremely fluid. 
6. Optimisation. I ran it on an i5 650, R7 240, with 8gb RAM and I still get around 25 FPS on low. 
7. GFH. Guns for Hire are a welcome upgrade, thankfully.
8. The soundtrack of this game and thye music chosen is pretty solid on all fronts.
9. Graphics. With the HD texture pack installed, this is really a great looking game. 

Cons:
1. Capture Parties. 'Nuff said.
2. Classic Ubisoft issues. The basic enemies having very similar faces, having 3 recruited companion GFH with same name, and stuff like that.
3. Online matchmaking. On PC, it's terrible. Not sure about Consoles.

Notes:
1. This game is the most fun I ever had in a Far Cry game, or any Ubisoft game for that matter. Shovels? New melee weapons can be used as projectiles? Hell yeah
2. The setting actually worked.
3. The GFH at times has pretty shitty AI.
4. Likeable sound design.The in game radio is INSANE 
5. I kinda actually like the endings. 
6. The story is actually good if you dig up enough evidence and go into ''Conspiracy Theory'' mode. Otherwise the story may feel disjointed.
7. Brilliant level design.
8. Why the fuck is ''Leaving Mission Area'' still a thing Ubi?
9. The amount of story defining choices is limited. 
10. FC Arcade is extremely great, and it's sad that FC6 won't have it.

Is it worth the money? Well, I got it on sale, for 15 USD. Certainly worth it.

[h1] Guns, Religious Cult, Small Towns In The Middle Nowhere And An Arrest Warrant For A Cult Leader What Could Go Wrong? [/h1]

[b] The Positive's [/b]
+ Co-Op Friendly Campaign
+ Interesting Storyline 
+ Lots Of Customizations 

[b] The Negative's [/b]
- Standard Ubisoft Bugs
- Awful Checkpoint System At Times

[b] The Aspect Of The Game [/b]
[i] You play as Rook a new deputy working for a local police department in Hope Montana. You, a sheriff, a few deputies and a U.S. Marshall step into a cult ridden valley to arrest Joseph Seed a notorious cult leader in the region that spouts on about the end of times. [/i]

[b] My Two Cent Review [/b]
[i] Now I have played this game many times in the past but just recently finally finished it with the help of friends. Couldn't bring myself to play the game by myself. The story line of the game is semi decent that tries to make you think if you are the good guy or bad guy in the story but it's obvious when you look around at what the cult has done to the people of Hope County who the real bad guys really are. You play a[spoiler]s the most kidnappable[/spoiler] deputy and go through three different regions of hope county taking down the cult by eliminating each part of the seed family. Each boss battle for the region is unique and fitting for them. Honestly the best part of the game is being able to play it with friends because doing everything by yourself gets boring dull after awhile since a lot of the game is rinse and repeat with each region. Sure they add a new enemy in each region but it doesn't change from what you normally do. The ending was what about what I expected from a doomsday cult and [spoiler]the best ending is really just to walk away at the start of the game and avoid all this from the start.[/spoiler] [/i]

[b] The Value Of The Game [/b]
[i] If you have a friend to play with and like the Far Cry games this isn't a bad one to pick up when it goes on sale.  [/i]

[h1] Final Score 63/100 Ranking D Tier [/h1]

IMHO FarCry 5 is easily close to being the most immersive piece of the FarCry series yet.

The Setting is brilliant and basically describes the regional USA version of an early 2025-style Great Reset with all its nitty/nasty details.
From Bioweapon-infected and completely drugged up, 5G-zapped Zombie-type enemies shedding mRNA all over the place, fairly credible cultists defending their suicide sect to the last breath, Bill Gates/Fauci/WEF-type contaminated Water, Plants and Animals all the way to a broad array of natural wildlife and scenery.
And yes, even a turkey can get angry and won't recognize the open brandishing of an M60 to settle a local dispute.

On the have-side everything from helpless hikers, hostages over to folks who pick up a gun after being freed, drive-by assistance by random 2nd amendment folks reacting to nearby gunfire all the way to ex Soldiers, Specialists and Preppers lending a helpful hand.

Compared to FarCry 4, where - by far - the biggest threat to you were local MiniVan NPC Drivers (anyone remember these? Oh the horror of these days...) or 90% of the local population seemingly perma-spamming for what sounded like a famous local Toothpaste Brand ( "The Golden Path" (tm) )...
FarCry 5 comes around very quickly as potentially(*) >very< immersive.
Bullet drop & TOF (time of flight) give you basic ballistic Gameplay rarely seen in games these days, so landing a long-range sniper shot on a moving target takes a little work.

Adding to that is the eerie Soundscape which I found absolutely awesome.
Nothing beats being a tad low on ammo and scooting around with one or two buddies you recruited through a forest at night and hearing that weirdo cult music from a far distance as you slowly move closer.
Especially on the Sound experience, that's close to a 10 out of 10 in my view (well, hearing).
FarCry5 Audio really shows off when played on good, loud speakers.
Getting bullet/arrow impact audio (emphazised) with natural range delay just adds to the Audio satisfaction.

Even NPCs chatting amongst themselves and your recruited special NPCs specifically reacting to each other individually in their own style takes quite a while before it gets old.

In all of that, humor isn't lost though and there's a serious number of Side-Missions or NPC lines that made me chuckle.
Comments on "don't worry about Tower Climbing", snarky self-reflection on FarCry Blood Dragon or admitting to using every conceivable cliché about Preppers... FarCry 5 has you covered ;)

----------------------------------------

(*) ...but there's the drawbacks on the immersion potential. And sadly, while they're a bit isolated, they are huge when they hit.

- Vehicles are bullet soakers for smaller calibres and yes, that includes windshields of even basic vehicles.., well not too bad and a .50cal or AP Ammo kinda fixes that
- the magic Bliss Bullets aka "Story Bullets" that hit you eventually during Story progression no matter what you do, allowing the bad guys to hijack you despite being surrounded by an army of friendlies smashing the hunting party chasing you
- maybe the worst of them IMHO, that magic Star Trek Teleporter Tech that even allows Story bad guys to warp you out of existence anywhere and anytime, even from a bunker. Just bizarre. If they have 25th century tech, why would any of their cult army or their regional bosses even have to bother to fight anyone?

Now I get that the Storyline Narration was intended to progress - but the way they did it (at least for me) was an absolute immersion-killer. A big shame.
IMHO one of the worst wrongdoings UbiSoft could have possibly done here, which is super unfortunate because it otherwise shines on immersion like few Games I've seen in the last years. The resulting Contrast/Break that creates is just way too big (at least I strongly feel that way).

No Spoilers... but the (most probable/typical) ending strangely follows that new path (Golden Path ??!?) of "inevitable outcomes" first seen to some extent in FarCry 4, which UbiSoft seemingly having dived into for some... psychological conditioning reason or something (?).
This kinda kills the entire Player Agenda thingy... I don't like that. But at least you get to keep going until the very end until you get screwed over one way or another.

-----------------------------------------

To make a long story short, FarCry 5 is a keeper and definitely recommended despite a few distinct shortcomings.
Replay value btw. is a thing here, as there's likely quite a few useful things the average Player only discovers a tad too late in the Game. Difficulty and another Weapon set/progression approach was more than enough for me to make a re-run.

PS.
I can't even explain why...
...but entering a truck, listening to the V8 powering up, hearing Jess hopping onboard, giving the double tap on the car and the simple line "Gun it!"... It just never gets old :)
This is much better than 6. I regret buying 6 because of all the woke nonsense...

Mid Far Cry 3 reskin (at best), buggy as a motel 6 at worst

+ Far Cry Arcade

-  Preexisting glitch that prevents reverse/descend trigger controls on gamepad 
This doesn't completely break the game or prevent story progression by any means; However, it does beg the question how a title could release over half a decade ago and still contain a bug that prevents an action as simple as reverse in a vehicle or descend in a plane/helicopter.. Sloppy work on the devs part. Certainly bogged down flying segments

- Ubisoft Connect game launcher // uplay dog water

- Soap opera narrative. If Far Cry 4s try hard villain, Pagan Min , felt unconvincing.. The father has the symbol of a crown tattooed on his chest, reminiscent of 'king/queen' hoodies- complete w/ grade school desk carvings engraved across the rest of his body. The more you focus on the Fathers shallow tattoos, the less intimidating and more comedic his character/demeanour becomes. Leading to some cringe dialogue sequences
 
Repetitive mechanics & persistent bugs lead to a promising if not derived, frustrating experience. If you've played FC3 and any of the subsequent releases in the franchise, this instalment should feel hauntingly familiar. Far Cry 3 had soul, Far Cry 5 lacks soul & serves 'crown' example as the shell of a former self

I bought the game and originally played it on release on an old Xbox One, and my opinion of the game hasn't changed since then. I still think the game is an incredibly fun, but flawed, experience, with a beautiful world, fun gameplay, and memorable (for the most part) characters. It ain't perfect, but if you've liked Far Cry games before, or open-world games in general, then check this game out. It goes on sale pretty often these days, and it's got co-op, which is nice. Also, the soundtrack is fantastic. Dan Romer was cooking when he wrote it. There's a good reason why just the ambient tracks of this game have millions of views on YouTube.

Probably my favorite of the Far Cry franchise. Great story, expansive world, incredible music, great graphics. My only complaint would probably be how diverse they made rural Montana. A third of the people you run into are black, whereas there are basically zero blacks in rural Montana in reality. It's so bad that it breaks the immersion in the game. Might work for people who don't know much about America, but for anyone who has ever been outside of urban areas, especially to more rural "flyover" areas, you know how ridiculous it is to have that level of diversity. In reality you'd find far more Native Americans, who are barely represented in the game.

That aside, the game was incredible and I highly recommend it.

Finally got around to playing through the main campaign as of December 2023. Probably going to be my only play through, and I'm not even going to bother with the DLC. If you're aren't familiar with the Far Cry series, then summarily it's a choose your own playstyle first person shooter/stealth game. None of the mechanics are very deep, but what's there is fun and great for a mindless gaming session. The theme of FC5 is religious zealots in rural North America.

If you are familiar with the Far Cry series, then it is mostly the same. I noticed less towers to climb to reveal the map and less reliance on hunting animals for skins to improve equipment or skills. 

I give the game an 8 out of 10, and if it is on good sale, then go for it. As for the DLC, none of it seems appealing, so I think I'm ready to move on to another game before I tryout New Dawn and FC6.

it was alright. i enjoyed the setting and the parallels with real american stuff- though i would have appreciated if they dived into that a bit more, though obviously if they get too spicy and realistic you risk offending more people so eh what can you expect from a AAA game. i think the story left a little to be desired, particularly with the ending(s). i dont hate what they were going for, but in my opinion they werent executed the best. 

in general the story felt a little slapped together, with some things never quite adding up. (for example, bliss is ~one~ drug that seemingly effects people completely differently, unrelated ways depending on the plot which comes across as pretty contrived. sometimes its a tranquilizer, sometimes its mind control, sometimes its...telepathic? maybe i missed something but it left me confused.

on the subject of game mechanics its a bit of a mixed bag. to me the guns feel super weak and weightless due to the lack of visual feedback in the shooting animations. i swear the ai has a tendency to shoot you through smoke and trees and things that they shouldnt be able to see you through (because you cant see them). on the other hand the guns are still serviceable and still decently fun to use; unlike the animations the sound design on them feels nice and punchy like it should. takedowns are fun, bow and throwing knives are fun, and the cult music is...actually kinda good and i found myself listening to it way more than the other stations lol.

i like to play games for the story first and gameplay second, ideally both ofc. so for me the story being kinda mid hurts it a lot for me. and for goofing around in an open world sandbox, i will personally lean towards rdr2 or gta v, however there is still a decent bit to do. the gameplay still is decent if not a bit frustratingly-designed at times.
