Far Cry 5 is one of my fave games of all time. While it has its flaws, which I will try list fairly, there are other things in this game that makes it very special. Just to be clear, while I've only got 29 hours playing it on Steam, I've played it through Ubisoft for more than a hundred hours, completed it, completed the DLCs, and have come back again to it multiple times. What I love is:

1. This has got one of the most engrossing casts of characters, bad guys and towns people, you will meet. The pinnacle bad guy, Joseph Seed, is wonderfully fleshed out, and his "kids" have distinct, equally vicious personalities.
2. The ability to partner with named NPCs, some named animals, and occasional random NPCs is also a lot of fun and allows you to add a small amount of tactical play to your various missions and stalking efforts. 
3. Similar to Far Cry 4, you have a nice array of weapons available, mission types, the ability to conquer and bring to your side various outposts and installations.
4. The game allows you to enjoy some stealth play. You can lay down an awful lot of bad guys with bows, thrown knives, and silencers and enjoy a stealth like experience even though it's probably not the most challenging stealth you can game. 
5. The land is absolutely beautiful and has so much going on that you can use this game as a walking, hunting or fishing simulator from time to time. You can go animal hunting with bow or rifle with your trusty dog, or for a real trip, bring your mountain lion or bear. There have been times I've strolled into a camp with someone playing the guitar and a couple dancing, and the location is very chill and has nothing to do with the story. 
6. You can "paper doll" to you heart's content... there are SO many cosmetic options with complete outfits, but also hats, gloves, tops and bottoms... very fun and a lot of them fit well within the story context.
7. The Dan Brown soundtrack is brilliant. Imitating rural commune and religious folk music, the songs line up with the cult context the bad guys have created. The tunes are catchy, the songs and lyrics brilliantly original, and all in all it adds immensely to the immersion. In FC5, the music is not just background, it is part of the world you are adventuring in.
8. The scripted elements are excellently written and eventually become haunting with some brainwashing you can't avoid. Bewitching!
9. I'm not a puzzle guy, but the puzzles in FC5 are doable, intuitive for the most part, and fun... again... for the most part. 
10. You can fly airplanes and helicopters... a great way to see the beauty of the land and move about it quickly.

On the downside, Far Cry 5 has been heavily critiqued so you may have heard some of these already.
1. Perhaps the most significant complaint against the way the story flows it that there are scripted moments where you WILL be captured temporarily as an story element to detail Joseph Seed's boss minions--his "kids". Was always frustrating when I was owning Hope County and was totally armed for bear, but because it was scripted, it just happened. Still, the story elements in each case were very well done. 
2. The game balance gets thrown off by some of the weapons you have free access to. For example, in FC5, you can take a belt loading machine gun, stick a sniper scope on it and a silencer. Yep. You heard it. You may not use a more realistic weapon for the rest of the game. And it WILL throw the balance off... way OP. But then... if you have the space adventure DLC and you add the futuristic weapons to the game, fuggedaboutit! Surprise! Surprise! Earthlings have nothing that can compete with your Star Trek period weaponry.
3. The linear game flow is tight... there may be a couple of different endings, but in general, the game is gonna lead to an ending... but I guess in the Far Cry series, you're used to that by now. :-)
4. I'm not sure this is a downside, but FC5 is not as immense in geography as FC4. Especially if you're in the air, it doesn't take long to traverse Hope County. I find myself wishing it was bigger. Than again, I loved FC4. 

All in all, FC5 is a gorgeous game with a great storyline, and its characters and plot will get to you and stay in your memory for a very long time. It is open world despite the linear nature of the storyline and you can basically take on the game's challenges in any order, although the different regions and sub-boss storylines do vary in difficulty. I did them in suggested order and recommend it... especially for noobies.

No way to skip it and don't care to fight with the poor developers idea of a good time playing a game. Farcry 1~3 was a blast, Primal was a joke that I never bought. [h3]🔥 Far Cry® 5: A Fiery Resistance[/h3]

Far Cry® 5 is an FPS (first person shooter) video game. The game is set in a rural area of Montana called Hope County. The protagonist is a deputy sheriff. The main antagonist is an apocalyptic cult called Eden's Gate, led by a fanatical leader named Joseph Seed. The game's graphics, sounds, music and animations are very high quality and realistic. The story of the game tells the struggle of the deputy sheriff to save the people of Hope County from the cult. The atmosphere of the game draws you in and you join a fiery resistance 😍

## 🌟 Pros of the game

- What I like about the game is that I can go wherever I want on the open world map, use various weapons, vehicles and animals, play alone or in pairs with a friend, do different quests, side quests, activities, fight with the members and leaders of the cult. These features make the game both free and fun. For example, I can find many places, mysteries, easter eggs to explore on the map, change my weapons and vehicles as I wish, befriend or hunt animals, cooperate with a friend by playing co-operatively, progress by completing missions and side quests, and engage in conflicts with the members and leaders of the cult. These choices affect the outcome of the game and offer me different endings. This makes the game more interesting and varied. 😎
- The game also has a lot of secret and extra content. This content enriches the game even more and adds new mechanics, levels, characters, stories. For example, in each chapter, you can find hidden bags, chests, plates and collect them to earn extra money, weapons, equipment, knowledge, find hidden caves, islands, regions and encounter challenging enemies or puzzles, find secret missions and complete them to get new weapons, vehicles, animals, unlock secret achievements and brag about them. I can also access the game's downloadable content, play through different environments and scenarios in the three-part storyline Hours of Darkness, Lost on Mars and Dead Living Zombies, play Far Cry® 3 Classic Edition, and try different maps and modes in Arcade mode. This content adds to the replayability and rewarding nature of the game. 😊

## Cons of the game

- What I don't like about the game is that sometimes it has too many errors, bugs, glitches, sometimes it is too repetitive, sometimes it is too ridiculous. When the game has too many bugs, glitches and glitches, it can be frustrating and annoying. The reason for these problems may be that the game requires too many system requirements or the game is not optimised. To resolve these issues, I can lower the game settings, update the game, verify the game files, or reinstall the game. I can also get help or share my problems on the game's support page or forums. 😢
- The fact that the game is very repetitive may not actually be a disadvantage, because I can get used to it, but sometimes I might want the game to be more varied and surprising. In this case, I can change the game by playing extra content. The fact that the game is very silly can actually be an advantage, because I can find the game funnier and more entertaining. But sometimes, I might want the game to be more logical and realistic. In this case, I can search the internet to better understand the game's story, characters and mechanics, visit the game's wiki page or forums, read interviews or reviews by Ubisoft, the game's creator, and try to find the game's hidden content. 😕

## 🏆 Game Scoring

I will rate the game in five categories: graphics, sound, gameplay, story, and overall. For each category I will choose one of five stars. Here is my rating:

Title: "A Riveting Ride Through Hope County"

Rating: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ (5/5)

Far Cry 5 delivers an unforgettable gaming experience that seamlessly combines intense action, an immersive open world, and a compelling narrative that keeps players on the edge of their seats. From the moment I stepped into the sprawling landscapes of Hope County, I knew I was in for a wild ride.

The game's attention to detail is simply outstanding. The picturesque Montana setting is brought to life with stunning visuals, capturing the essence of the rural wilderness and small-town charm. Whether soaring through the skies in a plane or navigating the dense forests on foot, every inch of Hope County feels meticulously crafted and ripe for exploration.

What truly sets Far Cry 5 apart is its dynamic storytelling. The game introduces a charismatic and enigmatic antagonist, Joseph Seed, whose charismatic presence permeates every corner of the map. The cult he leads adds an eerie layer of tension to the narrative, keeping players guessing and eager to uncover the mysteries of Hope County. The freedom to tackle the game's objectives in any order adds a refreshing element of choice, allowing players to shape their own path through the chaos.

Gameplay is where Far Cry 5 truly shines. The diverse arsenal of weapons, vehicles, and tools provides players with endless options for creative mayhem. The introduction of Guns for Hire adds depth to the gameplay, as each companion brings a unique set of skills and personalities to the table. Whether I was stealthily infiltrating an enemy outpost or engaging in a full-blown firefight, the gameplay remained consistently exhilarating and satisfying.

Multiplayer co-op is seamlessly integrated, allowing friends to join the chaos and tackle missions together. The cooperative experience enhances the game's already impressive replay value, turning every session into a new adventure filled with unpredictable moments and collaborative strategies.

Far Cry 5 isn't just a game; it's an immersive journey that captivates players from start to finish. With its breathtaking visuals, engaging storyline, and dynamic gameplay, it's no wonder that this installment in the Far Cry series has become a timeless classic. Ubisoft has truly hit the mark with Far Cry 5, delivering an experience that will keep players coming back for more. Highly recommended for anyone seeking an action-packed and thoroughly enjoyable gaming experience.

Great game, enormous fun. Is it better than FC4 and FC3? Difficult to say. I played FC3 and FC4 on Playstation and enjoyed both of them immensely. I recently replayed FC3 on PC and am currently FC5 on PC, using a PS5 Controller (I don't have a PS5, it's just my preferred controller).
Strangely, I can run FC5 at much higher settings than FC3, and get much better FPS. Better optimisation I suppose.
If you do want to play with a PS5 controller on the PC, I recommend using DS4Windows, as FC5 does not directly support the PS5 controller. With DS4W you can map the PS5 to a PS4 controller, which is supported by FC5.

Far Cry 5 - A Riveting Adventure in Hope County

Pros:

Engaging Open World: Hope County is a stunning and expansive open-world environment that feels alive with diverse landscapes, wildlife, and dynamic weather, providing a rich backdrop for exploration.

Compelling Storyline: The narrative is gripping, tackling controversial themes with a fresh perspective. The charismatic antagonist, Joseph Seed, adds depth to the plot, making it one of the series' more memorable stories.

Freedom of Approach: Far Cry 5 excels in giving players the freedom to approach objectives in various ways. Whether it's stealth, brute force, or a combination of both, the game accommodates different playstyles.

Companion System: The game introduces a compelling companion system, allowing players to recruit allies with unique skills. This adds an extra layer of strategy to the gameplay, making encounters more dynamic and enjoyable.

Fantastic Soundtrack: The game features a diverse and fitting soundtrack that enhances the atmosphere. The music seamlessly complements the action, intensifying the gaming experience.

Weapon Variety and Customization: A wide array of weapons is at your disposal, and the customization options allow players to fine-tune their arsenal to suit their preferences, providing a satisfying level of personalization.

Cons:

Repetitive Side Missions: While the main storyline is engaging, some of the side missions and activities can feel repetitive after a while. More variety in the optional content could enhance the overall experience.

Unrealistic AI: At times, the enemy AI can behave unrealistically, leading to moments of frustration. Improved enemy intelligence could make encounters more challenging and satisfying.

Minor Technical Glitches: While not game-breaking, there are occasional technical glitches and bugs that can temporarily disrupt immersion. Continued patching and updates could address these issues.

Lack of Meaningful Choices: Despite the game's themes of resistance and rebellion, some players may find the lack of impactful choices in the narrative disappointing. More branching storylines based on player decisions could add depth to the overall experience.

Limited Character Development: While the main villain is intriguing, some of the supporting characters lack the depth and development needed to form strong emotional connections. More fleshed-out character arcs could enhance the overall storytelling.

Conclusion:

Far Cry 5 delivers an exhilarating and visually stunning open-world experience with a captivating storyline and excellent gameplay mechanics. While it may have some minor flaws, the overall package offers an engaging adventure that is sure to satisfy fans of the series and newcomers alike. The combination of a vibrant world, diverse gameplay options, and a compelling narrative makes Far Cry 5 a worthy addition to the franchise.

[list]

[/list]

The Far Cry series is perhaps my favorite series of games to ever come out.

I've played almost all the Far Cry series, but this one is probably the weakest.

Even as a kid I played Far Cry 1 on my old pentium and enjoyed the relaxing game, but where Far Cry has reached today is really amazing how times change in this gaming world :)


❌
For this Far Cry, the developers decided to change the map, shooting, markers, etc. in a slightly drastic way.

The developers probably thought that players would get used to this novelty, but it caused rather negative reactions from people.

In general, until Far Cry 4, everything was fine, we always had great villains, maps, weapons, just a few hours of fun, but after this release of these new Far Cry series, it seems to me that this company is going down the drain. Pretty decent experience if you just want a game for shooting and chaotic combat. Its a basic Ubisoft game that is very similar to previous Far Cry games. The gameplay turns into a series of repetitive chores after reaching the 5-10 hour mark. There are some really good parts (like the phenomenal soundtrack), but overall the experience is mediocre. 
I played this once and do not feel like going back to play it again. 

Positives (+) 
         - Beautiful graphics 
         - Very good soundtrack 
         - Good shooting 

Negatives (-)
         - Ubisoft connect 
         - Not unique compared to predecessors 
         - Stupid AI 
         - Very repetitive gameplay 
         - Story ultimately falls flat

I used to love the Far Cry franchise, but that has now ended. I bought Far Cry 3, 4 and 5 a couple of years ago. I've played them all and really liked them. Then life hit me, kids, work, stuff like that and I didnt play them for around 1.5 years. Then recently I wanted to get into gaming again. But when I wanted to start up Far Cry 5, i didnt work. I corresponded with Ubisoft Support and they told me that they deleted my Ubisoft Account because of inactivity, even tho i had paid games on that account. If i wanted to play, i had to buy the games again. I found out they delete account after 6 months of inactivty.
That is a really crazy, greedy way to treat your customers and loyal fans. So i will no longer support Ubisoft and I've played my last game from them.

I do not recomend supporting the thieving and greedy Ubisoft.


Edit: Lots of people calling me a liar hmm. Why would I lie about this? What would I gain from it? I have no idea why some accounts havent been deleted and why some have. My experience is based on my own account and the correspondance with Ubisoft Support, which id happily show you, if I could upload pics on here. The only purpose of this is to warn others.

And since the games are tied to your ubisoft account, it doesent matter that you buy them on Steam. Mine were bought on Steam.

Heres is a Copy/Paste of one of the Emails I Recevied. Dont mind the different username. Thats what I use on my Ubisoft Account.

I understand that you are having an activation issue with Far Cry 5.

Please feel free to contact us for any questions or concerns that you may have and we will be happy to assist you further.

Have a great day and thank you again for being part of the Ubisoft Community. Take Care!

This game is a masterpiece of 'games that are meant to be played casually'. The typical open-world formula seen in other Ubisoft games actually works in this, meaning that the abundance of side-missions do in fact keep you entertained. Although GTA is in another league, Far Cry 5 still beats GTA in one aspect. After a certain time, GTA open-world starts to feel hollow and bland, THAT isn't the case with Far Cry 5. The characters are likeable, there's a good interaction mechanic with NPCs; it's not perfect or super-realistic but it's fun and that's where the game succeeds. You can also do bunny hop, Villains are awesome, Story can be finished at the first mission itself, Add-On(s) are cool and LASTLY, you can recruit a dog to play alongside you.

[b] tldr: the game is a carefully-crafted love letter to gamers [/b]

If you are looking for realism or a story experience like Far Cry 3, this might not be what you want. But if you want a really fun arcade shooter with satisfying stealth and decent gun play this is definitely a game for you. Really fun to kick back and clear outposts, 8.5 / 10 game.

I think this Far Cry game is a great installment in the series. It is not better than other Far Cry games, but it has a uniqueness that only Far Cry 5 brings. The story is kind of weak and I also feel like the villains just aren't very impressive. 

The gameplay overall is immersive and fun but there's an issue with things despawning from loot to entire convoys of enemies even though you are standing right next to them. It's a minor inconvenience that won't go unnoticed but doesn't affect gameplay too much, other than that it shows how little care Ubi put into the design of the game.

That being said, the music and visuals are simply stunning. That combined with a great map and the game is worth your money. I really like this game and recommend it especially when it's on sale.

I think this review could use an update regarding the money issue. Money becomes a non-issue if you explore the game's content a bit more thoroughly. Many of the weapons have the exact same stats and many of the vehicle types are identical, so it just boils down to what aesthetic you prefer. You can make a lot of money by hunting and fishing; the latter being the more time consuming of the two. When you loot an animal you get bait, which can be used to immediately spawn in the predators which inhabit the your current area.Once you purchase the weapons that suit your play style, the money will begin to accumulate quite substantially.

I have only defeated one area boss and I have more weapons and vehicles than I need, and still have around $30-40,000. That's also without finding all of the hidden bunkers and other game-world items in that area.
I would recommend this for people only wanting to play solo or with one friend, but you can only have 2 people in coop story

This here is a great example as to how awful Ubisoft games are

There is maybe 1-2 hours of actual plot in this game, the remaining 45ish hours of game is spent playing the same mission three times. Each of these missions is split further into 3 parts based on your "resistance" in the region to make the game feel longer. Each of the missions ends in the Same. Exact. Way. and you know the ending of the game once you start your first play through. 

But what about those 150+ missions that you can go on? Every single one of them is a chore. "Go to 'X' and kill 'Y'" or "Go to 'Z' and collect 'W'" sometimes they get really advanced and make you do "Go to 'A' than go to 'B' than go to 'C' follow companion '1' and than kill 'X' and yippie companion '1' will now be available to follow you" and my favorite is the classic warcraft "kill 10 'X' class enemies." 

Well the companions you mentioned earlier they must be cool though right? Every. Single. Character. that is supposed to be a good guy is either a redneck because "hahahahaha rural people with guns that vote republican are stupid hahahahahaha" or a whiny looser with dyed hair because some of the devs probably spent more time on Tumbler instead of coding the game. All these characters got so annoying I clicked the "walk away" ending just so the bad guys would win and all the characters would die. And I couldn't even have this since if you click that ending it just puts you back in the game right before the final mission and you have to go through the actual "Ubisoft approved" ending

Also the game is riddled with game breaking bugs! Wanna just fall through the floor at random strips of road with no warning? You'll love Far Cry 5! Wanna have your companion just walk through a cliff side and get stuck behind the world? You'll love Far Cry 5! The best part about these bugs is that a hard reset wont fix them, checking the integrity of the files wont fix them, and heaven forbid you ask a forum how to fix them. The only solution that I've found is to completely uninstall and reinstall the game, and with my internet that takes an hour to two hours. 

Well are the minigames enjoyable? The fishing game is novel... but loses its luster after a couple hours. Hunting is just another chore while also being the only real way to make in game money other than giving Ubisoft actual cash. The Arcade? you couldn't pay me to play a game in a game.

Graphically the game looks good for the first 3 hours you play it but than all the scenery just blends together. Every interior is the same, and the scenery doesn't change. This combined with the level of detail decisions that the devs made should be a crime against humanity. Everything looks okay from far away... but objects will not spawn if you aren't within 200 meters awayof said object. Also if there are more than 10 moving things on screen everything looks like clay. I kept the game resolution on Ultra High, and other than making my PC beg to be put down, none of these graphical issues went away. The only thing that remains high quality throughout the game is the characters arms but having your arms be super detailed and contrasted to an actual clayscape makes you feel a little sick.

What is the good part of the game? Ubisoft finally figured out how to make a good antagonist. Also the decision to make half the games soundtrack gospel music was a bold choice... but one that works well.

I would never condone anyone getting this game unless it is 75% off like when I got it. Infact I would have stopped playing it after 5 hours and have forgotten about it if I wasn't required to be locked in my room for 3 weeks due to the Coronavirus.

Fun game, i'm nostalgic for far cry 4 so i bought this while it was on sale for 9 dollars. There seems to be scripted events that occur when you gain resistance points that cannot be avoided, this can be annoying depending on what you're doing but otherwise this game is a pretty fun installment in the far cry series. A change they made was the inability to gain bait from every kill, so the infinite kill and sell strategy that worked for getting funds in far cry 4 is gone. Thankfully the vehicles and weapons aren't that expensive so it takes banking resources for roughly 20 minutes to get that item you have your eye on. I'm only in the first area but for the price i bought it for it's a steal. Definitely recommend getting this while you can (autumn sale). The music and setting are fantastic as well, really gives you the impression you're a local fighting say the branch davidians who are taking over the county. I'm honestly not sure if i prefer this over farcry 4 so I think that's a glowing review, since nostalgia makes far cry 4 seem 10/10.

[h1]⛺[u]Graphics:[/u][/h1]
Amazing graphics with beautiful landscapes and artistic cutscenes. Sometimes, it's like watching a movie!
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3014840030

[h1]🎮[u]Gameplay:[/u][/h1]
[b]Overall enjoyable but quickly repetitive.[/b]

The gameplay has some similarities with its predecessors (Outposts, vehicles, combat etc.) but has some major differences :

- [b]Far Cry 5 doesn't hold your hand as much as before[/b]. At first, you will find yourself lost and wondering the map not understanding the objectives and not knowing what to do first. Then, after some time, you will gradually get used to it.

- The combat system is very similar, you can hold up to 3 main weapons, 1 one-handed gun and 1 melee weapon. There's a wide variety of weapons such as revolvers, shotguns, rifles, snipers, explosives, rocket launchers, bow and even an alien weapon. 
[b]Unfortunately, there are no knives as melee weapons meaning no knife takedowns[/b]. Although the takedown mechanics are the same, the gruesome visuals of takedowns are no longer there.

- [b]Something I really hate in this Far Cry game are the "forced missions"[/b]. Meaning that at several points, while playing, exploring, doing a side quest etc. you will be tracked down and forced to do a main mission. Basically, there are 3 regions each having a "boss" and there's a progress bar for each region. The progress bar is divided in three parts and every 33% you are forced to do a main mission. It is extremely difficult to NOT add any progression to the progress bar as everything counts towards its progression. For example killing enemies, freeing hostages, liberating an outpost or doing a side quest. So it is extremely annoying when in a middle of a side quest you reach the 33% and are forced into another mission. The worst is when you reach the 100% and the game forces you to confront the region's boss (only applies to Faith and Jacob Seed). 

- After clearing the first region, I found the game quite repetitive. Strangely enough, I have spent much more time on Far Cry 4 and haven't got that feeling. I'm not sure, but maybe it's not varied enough, the side missions are too similar to one another or something is missing.


[h1]💀[u]Difficulty:[/u][/h1]
I played the game on hard
At first, the game was quite challenging, plus with very few skills and few weapons I died quite frequently. But after grinding skills and also getting used to the game mechanics it was really enjoyable to play on hard.
Note: there aren't any achievements for completing the game on hard or normal


[h1]⌛[u]Game length:[/u][/h1]
[b]~70 hours[/b] without fast travelling and all side quests included


[h1]📖[u]Story:[/u][/h1]
Overall, the story is [b]quite good but I wouldn't call it amazing[/b]. Global plot felt a bit bland, basically the whole plot is about the protagonist who is charged to stop the cult leaders and save their friends
[b]Character development[/b], on the other hand, was [b]very well made[/b] mainly for the antagonists. The antagonists' motives are interesting and original, different from the usual bad guy that wants to be powerful, rich etc. Their personalities and background are very complex and adds very well to their delusion.


[h1]🎬[u]Cinematic/Art:[/u][/h1]
Although it lacks in the plot, [b]Far Cry 5 has amazing cutscenes[/b] with beautiful colors and lighting, nice shots, great acting and a heavy atmosphere.
Unfortunately, the protagonist never speaks.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3023058540

[h1]🎵[u]Music/Sound:[/u][/h1]
[url=https://music.youtube.com/watch?v=4X2Zc9rCTH8]Cull the herd[/url]

The sound effects are well done, especially environmental sounds where you can hear the birds chirping, water flowing etc. Exploring with the nice sound effects makes it even more enjoyable.


[h1]💸[u]Price:[/u][/h1]
Although the game has 30+ hours of content, it's mostly copy-paste and I wouldn't pay full price for it. 
I'd recommend to [b]wait for sale[/b].


[h1]🚀[u]Requirements:[/u][/h1]
Surprisingly, I could run it smoothly on [b]high on an old GTX 1050 at an average of 40fps[/b].


[h1]🐞[u]Bugs:[/u][/h1]
Nothing game breaking.


[h1]📝[u]Final:[/u][/h1]
Overall, a good, entertaining and enjoyable game but it wasn't extremely impressive.


[h1]💯[u]Final Score:[/u][/h1]
7/10

[h1]Far Cry 5 Review By Me:[/h1]

[u][b]English:[/b][/u]

Far Cry 5 is another installment in the popular first-person shooter game series that transports players to the perilous lands of Montana in the United States. Released in 2018, the game garnered significant attention due to its controversial storyline and open-world setting. Here's my review of Far Cry 5:

[b]Graphics:[/b]

Far Cry 5 astounds with its graphics and the meticulous detailing of Montana's open world. The landscapes are stunning, showcasing a variety of terrains, from mountain ranges to rural areas and lakes. They feature realistic textures, lighting effects, and a dynamic day and night cycle. Characters and creatures have also been carefully designed, adding realism to the game world.

[b]Gameplay:[/b]

The game offers dynamic and exhilarating gameplay, typical of the Far Cry series. Players step into the shoes of a character known as the "Deputy Sheriff," who aims to topple a religious cult called the "Project at Eden's Gate," led by the charismatic Joseph Seed. In the game, you can make use of various weapons, vehicles, and gadgets to defeat your enemies. The combat system is smooth and satisfying, and the cooperative mode allows for shared gameplay with friends.

[b]Story:[/b]

Far Cry 5 stands out from previous entries in the series due to its controversial narrative. The game confronts players with the theme of religious fanaticism and mass manipulation. While some may consider this a bold approach, others may feel uneasy about the subject matter. However, it's worth noting that the story is intriguing and full of plot twists.

[b]Open World:[/b]

Montana is an enormous, open world that you can explore at your own pace. It's teeming with interesting side quests, challenges, and mysteries to uncover. The abundance of available vehicles and weapons makes traversing Montana consistently exciting.

[b]Music and Sound:[/b]

Far Cry 5 features an outstanding soundtrack that perfectly complements the game's atmosphere. Ambient music, natural sounds, and character dialogues contribute to immersing players in the game world.

[b]Summary:[/b]

Far Cry 5 is another successful entry in the series, offering excellent gameplay, beautiful graphics, and an intriguing storyline. However, due to its controversial theme of religion and fanaticism, it may not appeal to everyone. For those who appreciate dynamic gameplay and open worlds, Far Cry 5 will undoubtedly provide many hours of enjoyment.

[u][b]Polski:[/b][/u]

Far Cry 5 to kolejna odsłona popularnej serii gier first-person shooter, która przenosi nas w niebezpieczne tereny Montany w Stanach Zjednoczonych. Gra, wydana w 2018 roku, zyskała dużą uwagę ze względu na swoją kontrowersyjną fabułę i otwarty świat. Oto moja recenzja gry Far Cry 5:

[b]Grafika:[/b]

Far Cry 5 zachwyca grafiką i detalami otwartego świata Montany. Pejzaże są piękne, z różnorodnością terenów, od górskich pasm po wiejskie okolice i jeziora. Charakteryzują się one realistycznymi teksturami, efektami świetlnymi i dynamicznym cyklem dnia i nocy. Postacie i stwory również zostały starannie zaprojektowane, co dodaje realizmu świata gry.

[b]Rozgrywka:[/b]

Gra oferuje dynamiczną i emocjonującą rozgrywkę, typową dla serii Far Cry. Gracz wciela się w postać zwaną "Zastępcą Szeryfa," który próbuje obalić kult religijny o nazwie "Zbawiciele Edena," dowodzony przez charyzmatycznego Josepha Seed'a. W grze możemy korzystać z różnorodnych broni, pojazdów i gadżetów, aby pokonać wrogów. System walki jest płynny i satysfakcjonujący, a tryb kooperacji pozwala na wspólną rozgrywkę z przyjaciółmi.

[b]Fabuła:[/b]

Far Cry 5 wyróżnia się od poprzednich części serii ze względu na kontrowersyjną fabułę. Gra konfrontuje graczy z tematem fanatyzmu religijnego i manipulacji masami. Choć niektórzy mogą uważać to za odważne podejście, inni mogą czuć się nieswojo wobec tego tematu. Warto jednak zauważyć, że fabuła jest intrygująca i pełna zwrotów akcji.

[b]Otwarty świat:[/b]

Montana jest ogromnym, otwartym światem, który można eksplorować według własnego uznania. Pełen jest interesujących zadań pobocznych, wyzwań i tajemnic do odkrycia. Wielość dostępnych pojazdów i broni sprawia, że podróżowanie po Montanie jest zawsze ekscytujące.

[b]Muzyka i dźwięk:[/b]

Far Cry 5 oferuje znakomitą ścieżkę dźwiękową, która doskonale pasuje do atmosfery gry. Ambientalna muzyka, dźwięki przyrody i dialogi postaci przyczyniają się do immersji gracza w świat gry.

[b]Podsumowanie:[/b]

Far Cry 5 to kolejna udana odsłona serii, która oferuje znakomitą rozgrywkę, piękną grafikę i intrygującą fabułę. Jednakże, ze względu na kontrowersyjny temat religii i fanatyzmu, nie każdemu może przypaść do gustu. Dla tych, którzy cenią dynamiczną rozgrywkę i otwarte światy, Far Cry 5 z pewnością dostarczy wiele godzin zabawy.

Updated Review:

Given this game's penchant for wasting your time and forcing things on you that you don't want, I decided I would look up the endings to see if the game would waste ALL of my time, and yep, turns out all of the endings suck. The only good ending is the one where you don't handcuff the cult leader Joseph in the beginning, meaning the best ending is the one where you don't even play. 

You know what Ubisoft? I AGREE. Don't play this game. Far Cry 3, 4, Primal, or any of the Assassin's Creed games are vastly superior to this disaster.

My final review is even more negative than when I left it. Oh and uh, the person who designed the "Patriot Acts" mission can shove sand into their eyeballs and glue them shut.

Original review below:


Oh, were you playing the game? Sorry, you've been kidnapped for 5th time in an unskippable event that pulls you out of what you were doing and forces you to do something else.

What's that, you're having problems "tailing a helicopter"? Why that's a perfectly reasonable mission when you're on foot and the only vehicle you have access to is on a steep winding mountain making it impossible to follow. You didn't know you needed the wingsuit? Well at least you only have one single save and cannot reload and earlier save and get it.

Every single time you start enjoying this game, Ubisoft makes sure you loathe it. Every time you start to actually get immersed into the game world, they rip you out of it and force you to do something else, always something you don't want to do. The save system is beyond garbage, there's only one save slot, and reloading a checkpoint saves all of the progress you don't want it to (that's why people reload saves, smoothbrains, why do you do this in every game?).

I'm going to keep playing and so my review might change, I hope it does, but so far after 18 hours it's very difficult to recommend a game that is great one moment and completely terrible and frustrating the next. This is a relatively shallow experience under a top notch facade, with loads of atrocious design decisions but some good emergent gameplay.

Pros:
-Great, immersive world
-Great gunplay
-Nice immersive sim elements
-Lots of vehicles 
-A few terrific weapons
-Companions are good if a wee bit shallow
-Difficulty is well-balanced...when the mission design isn't horrible

~Mids:
-Some missions are fine
-AI is inoffensive

Cons:
-You WILL contend with the Ubisoft launcher, which initially prevented me from even playing
-Truly terrible save system
-Stuff is constantly thrown in your face every 100 feet never giving you time to just breathe
-A few really awful and incredibly poorly designed missions
-You are CONSTANTLY pulled out of this "open world" game, forcing you into doing something entirely different with no way of stopping these events or having any control over them
-Technical issues getting game to read my GPU, a common problem

I'm so tired of these issues plaguing so many Ubisoft games. Year after year players make it very clear they hate these very intentional decisions that Ubisoft makes games after game, yet they double down on them and pretend like they aren't issues. They are. They're major issues. They ruin what would have been great games and undermine the incredible work of these development teams. And everyone should be clear that these teams are not really to blame, it's the company itself. It's upper management, it's executives, some things are middle management, but mostly this is a very top down problem. 

I'm just over it. I'll re-review when I complete the game.

Great game with awesome DLCs.

Both shooting and stealth feels good. Main antagonist is well developed. Enjoyable experience from start to finish, nice story and beautiful open world that's great to be in (other than all the baddies around).

I can't believe I am saying this but this is one of the best ubisoft game to be launched in recent times where all their games have gone down the drain.

This game is easily 9/10 for me and 100% recommended. 
Buy it on sale since it is 5 years old now.

I went with Far Cry 5 Gold Edition which includes -> Base Game + 3 DLC expansions + a copy of Far Cry 3.

Let's start the review now ----------------------------------------------------

[PROS]

The initial atmosphere and beginning of this game lays excellent ground work for story to develop. I can't stress enough on the fact that this game got me hooked right from the moment it started. 

This is very important since this motivates me to see what else the game has to offer and how the story is gonna develop.

The characters of this game are filled with emotion and strong personalities. The cultist madness of antagonist and his minions is through the chart. They are trying to tell you a story where the end justifies their sickening means. From there you are brought in the world of classic far cry experience. 

The game mechanics have always been the strong suit of Far Cry with one of the most authentic driving experience in entire industry. There are added companions who serve certain roles according to your command which compels us to smartly execute the mission.

Stealth, outsmarting AI, cordinating with companions turns Far Cry gameplay into something more intuitive and interesting. This mechanic begs you to try the smart and stealth way instead of guns-blazing.

Story, characters, mechanics are top-notch but what's more ?

"CO-OP GAMEPLAY" - I completed the whole campaign with my friend where I can't express enough how much fun we had. There's so much happening in the game when you and your homie start doing brainless stuff xD. I laughed hysterically for half the campaign doing crazy stuff and this experience was more than enough to call it a day even if sometimes we didn't feel like doing missions.

[CONS]

The only bad thing I would say about the game is and which is very critical to know before buying - The story only progresses for the person who is Host of the co-op party. Meaning the friend who joins has to complete all those missions back in his own world or you have to play campaign twice to help each other complete the game. My friend was generous enough to play 70% campaign on my world and 30% on his own world but we still had our fun.

There are still a few bugs here and there like you can get stuck inside a destroyed car or you can get stuck behind the wall where you basically can't interact with normal world. Considering game is 5 years old, it should be more polished by now.

Let's talk about DLCs now --------------------------------------------------------------

{DEAD LIVING ZOMBIES} -> This is basically DOOM but you can invite your friends in co-op for added fun. Gameplay is pretty monotonous across closed levels which give stagnant experience after a couple of levels.

[LOST ON MARS] -> This is like ALIEN ISOLATION where your end goal is to escape a space ship stuck on mars. Dark and poorly lit rooms for added horro with no other creature in sight where we solve door puzzles to progress ahead. Little boring but unique experience.

{HOURS OF DARKNESS} -> This is where a US army trooper has to reach evacuation point by going through deep jungles of Veitnam. You have to fight through their troops to reach evacuation spot. This is the only expansion with truly open-world map where you can do similar stuff like base game to ease out your journey or speedrun through forest while fighting enemies to reach your helicopter.

These DLCs expansion are good content especially when all of them have co-op enabled to carry the same outside campaign.

Fully Recommended

I have always liked the Far Cry franchise, although I never played Far Cry 1-2. I loved playing Far Cry 3 due to its graphics, sounds, guns, and story. When I first played Far Cry 5, I hated it because of the difficulty I felt while playing, with the level upgrades and not enough supplies. Later, I found out that I was the one at fault for not knowing about its mechanics. The gameplay is really good, just like I remember from Far Cry 3. THIS GAME HAS THE BEST GUN SOUNDS I'VE EVER HEARD IN A GAME! It literally feels like I'm in the game when I hear the sounds. When someone shoots past you, and you're playing on full volume wearing headphones, it literally feels like someone took a shot at you. The graphics are really good, and the game is well-optimized. I had no problem playing on ultra settings at 4K. The story is about Project at Eden's Gate, which is a cult, including an armed terrorist paramilitary group led by Joseph Seed and his siblings. Our goal is to kill every cultist, take over their lands, and free the place. I had real fun playing this game because of the driving, and you could fly planes and helicopters in this game, which is really fun. That's about it; I don't really have much else to say. I would give this game a rating of 7/10. -CroxeSinned

Far Cry 5 : An Immersive Adventure in the Heartland

Graphics: ★★★★☆
Far Cry 5 showcases stunning visuals and realistic environments that truly bring the Montana wilderness to life. From the lush forests to the snowy mountains, the game's graphics provide a highly detailed and visually captivating experience.

Gameplay: ★★★★☆
The gameplay of Far Cry 5 offers a seamless and immersive open-world experience. With a plethora of engaging missions and side activities, players are provided with countless opportunities to explore the vast map and interact with a diverse range of characters. The inclusion of various vehicles adds an extra dimension to gameplay, allowing for fast-paced action and thrilling chases.

Story: ★★★★☆
The narrative of Far Cry 5 is intriguing, delving into the conflicts and struggles of a remote Montana county under the oppressive rule of a religious cult called Eden's Gate. The characters are well-developed and offer emotionally-charged encounters throughout the game. While the story occasionally suffers from pacing issues, the unpredictable twists and turns keep players engaged till the very end.

Sound: ★★★★★
The sound design of Far Cry 5 is exceptional, immersing players in the game's world. The ambient sounds of nature, gunfights, and explosions are incredibly realistic, while the voice acting is top-notch, bringing life to the diverse cast of characters. The game's soundtrack perfectly complements the atmosphere, enhancing both the tension-filled moments and the peaceful tranquility of exploration.

Multiplayer: ★★★☆☆
Far Cry 5 features a cooperative multiplayer mode, allowing players to team up with friends to tackle missions and explore the vast open world together. While the multiplayer adds an extra layer of fun and excitement, it is not as polished as the single-player experience. Connection issues and occasional glitches can hinder the enjoyment of the cooperative gameplay.

Replay Value: ★★★★☆
With a vast map to explore, countless side activities to complete, and multiple endings, Far Cry 5 offers significant replay value. The game encourages players to experiment with different playstyles, weapons, and approaches, ensuring that each playthrough feels fresh and unique.

Overall: ★★★★☆
Far Cry 5 delivers an immersive and captivating experience set in a beautiful yet dangerous open world. The game excels in its graphics, gameplay mechanics, and sound design. While the cooperative multiplayer could use some improvements, the game's strong storyline and replay value make it a must-play for fans of open-world adventures and first-person shooters.

I bought the Gold Edition for $13. At that price, this is a good buy. The issue is that at anything higher, especially normal price, I simply cannot recommend. Even at $13, there was a lot of other games I could have played that would have been much more entertaining. 

Pros: 
Good Soundtrack 
Solid Premise 
Cool map 
2 play co-op

Cons: 
Very Repetitive. All three of the heralds basically just need you to destroy a certain amount of crap belonging to the cult, and then boom, the game is basically over. There are not very many actually unique missions, and the number of missions involving getting a truck of some kind back from a cult outpost, killing everyone at said outpost, and then driving the truck back is in the tens. 

Graphics are decent, but not what I would expect from a game of this budget and acclaim 

Story Lacks real meaning, and I could not get connected 

Characters are pretty copy and paste, and are very forgettable. 

Guns are unbalanced. Some guns are great, but some weapons will never be used because they are simply worse. 

NPCs are extremely stupid, and can be killed en masse with anything with a range longer than 10 meters. They will not seek cover, fire back with any accuracy, or anything of that sort. 

All of the boss battles and the final battles are extremely easy. Even with the game on normal, it is actually difficult to lose, and my teammate and I never lost a boss battle. 

Multiplayer exists, but is flawed. The secondary player never can actually unlock any new guns or perks, and so cannot really progress. The secondary player is also excluded from any and all game choices entirely, and is merely a spectator at times during the game. The secondary player cannot start missions and gets killed if he is more than a few dozen meters from the host. The secondary player's items can also be brought in from other worlds, making the game easier to cheese than it already is. 




All in all, an attempt was made, but the game falls flat due to it's repetitive nature and many problems it must work out.

Far Cry 5 takes the franchise to new heights with its captivating narrative, stunning open-world design, and an arsenal of chaotic possibilities. As a veteran player of the series, I can confidently say that this installment doesn't disappoint.

The game's setting in the fictional Hope County, Montana, is both beautiful and haunting. The open world is vast and diverse, encouraging exploration and discovery. The attention to detail is commendable, from the dense forests to the serene lakes, making every corner of the map a visual treat.

What truly sets Far Cry 5 apart is its compelling story. The charismatic and sinister cult leader, Joseph Seed, adds a layer of depth to the narrative rarely seen in open-world shooters. The tension builds steadily as you work to liberate the county from Seed's control, and the unpredictable twists keep you on the edge of your seat.

The game's characters are well-crafted, each with their own unique personalities and stories that add to the overall richness of the experience. The addition of Guns for Hire brings a tactical element to gameplay, allowing for diverse strategies in taking down cult outposts.

Gameplay is where Far Cry 5 truly shines. The freedom to approach objectives in any way you see fit is exhilarating. Whether you prefer stealth, long-range sniping, or going in guns blazing, the game accommodates your playstyle. The vast array of weapons and vehicles further enhances the sandbox experience, making every encounter feel dynamic and unpredictable.

Visually, Far Cry 5 is a masterpiece. The attention to detail in the environment, character models, and lighting effects is outstanding. The game's soundtrack complements the action seamlessly, enhancing the overall immersion.

While some may argue that the ending is divisive, I appreciate the bold choice to leave a lasting impact on players. It's a testament to the developers' commitment to delivering a memorable experience.

In conclusion, Far Cry 5 is a wild ride from start to finish. Its engaging story, dynamic gameplay, and stunning visuals make it a standout title in the series. Whether you're a longtime fan or a newcomer, this game is a must-play for anyone seeking an open-world adventure filled with action, suspense, and a touch of insanity.

The start is very good, when you get introduced to the villain, but then it gets boring. 
I like the fact that you now have a teammate of some sort to help you. The game has new stuff to offer when it comes to the customization of the guns and the fighting is better, but it stops there.
The main villain is not memorable, because you meet him in the beginning, but then don't see him until the very end almost. It is the same concept of destroying rode blockades, radio towers and bases, but the map is now split in three parts. You walk around destroying those to get the fast travel and mini map, but the story is to kill the boss in each separated area on the map, and then you have to start all over for the next boss. There isn't really any rewards for doing stuff in one part, because you have to start all over for the next part of the map. 
Fighting the main villain is not that big of a part to the game, so he almost just feels like any other of the bosses you have killed the rest of the game.

Deleting the contents of my last review to type something more original:

Friendly bots are entirely useless. Hostile bots are only difficult because the devs didn't make them genuinely fun to fight, they just spammed so so so many of them. The overall movement in the game clunky and buggy. Planes have horrible controls. Helicopters are a joke. Hit boxes are random at distance. Bullets appear to drop, but don't actually fall as they travel. Environmental clipping is random. Sticking a gun through a solid wall will allow bullets to pass through and hit an enemy, but sheet metal roofing is bullet proof. Destructive environments EXPLODE. Quest-essential bots getting stuck on terrain and environment stuff. Side-quest related bots will despawn the second they go out of render distance, and bots will similarly spawn from thin air. Straight up, this game plays like a re-skinned/textured arcade shooter from decades back. It'd be acceptable if it was a 20 year old game,..but it's not....

Don't pay full price for something so half-assed.

It feels likes like Three mini Far-Cry 3 games in one game on a single open world map with one last big boss fight (When you exclude or generalise each of the protagonist's story or purpose. First play-through was obviously for story, the second time is for the Infamous achievement.

It's a fun shooter with allot of activities. It takes about less than 20 hours just for the main story if done with barely no difficulty. There are Three DLC contents separate from the main story except for the included items that can be brought to the main story. 
     - Hours of Darkness DLC has it's own map with an additional two game-modes after first completion of the DLC.
     - Lost On Mars DLC is just a single game mode and set on the Planet Mars. This DLC can be done with all of its achievements in less than 6-8 hours possibly even less with Co-op.
     - Dead Living Zombies DLC feels like a Left 4 Dead game at times because of how iconic it is (Not exactly the same but feels that way).  Dead Living Zombies will have you trying to stop the zombie apocalypse while Left 4 Dead is about surviving the zombie apocalypse.

Far Cry 5 delivered an adrenaline-fueled thrill ride set in the heart of rural Montana that left me breathless. The game's open-world setting was a visual marvel, with picturesque landscapes and a captivating atmosphere that immersed me in its beauty and chaos. Exploring Hope County felt alive and dynamic, with surprises around every corner. The gripping storyline, centered around a cult's reign of terror, kept me engaged and invested in the journey. The freedom to tackle missions and challenges in any order I chose was liberating, offering a true sense of exploration. The diverse range of weapons and vehicles added to the excitement, making every encounter a unique and intense experience. Far Cry 5's seamless blend of action, exploration, and a gripping narrative made it an exhilarating and unforgettable gaming adventure.

Ubisoft really sold it out with this game. The lack of atmosphere and certain touches to the game, which made Far Cry as to what it once was, really drags more of the negatives than positives. It feels empty and dull. It is not about the story, mostly. Maybe something could've been done better, but when it comes to the story anyone could say it is the "regular old Far Cry". The game, even though stunning, feels forced and blank with all the unavoidable encouters and pushes to play the story missions, rather than experience the world and play how you like. On top of that, your character is mute and there are no organic transitions from cutscenes to gameplay which ruins the immersion. The lack of animations such as ones for looting and skinning also ruin the atmosphere and life, Far Cry was renowned for. Some of the side characters feel robotic and the AI is, simply put, stupid. It feels like there was not that much care, nor thought put into this game after all. I could also add the fact that it is "ruined" by the presence of microtransactions, in terms of in-game currency of "silver bars", in the single-player! All in all, the game just does not feel right. I would not recommend this game to anyone, especially for its full price! If you can, replay older Far Cry games such as Far Cry 4,3 and/or 2.

I hate cutscenes that trigger at random, unavoidable times, knock you out (cliche), wake you up in a totally different place on the map (cliche), knock you out again (cliche), in fact I'm juts plain sick of all the fade in, fade out stuff because Ubi doesn't know how to write a good game.  And the fact that I didn't want to be in this stupid cutscene anyway means I skip them and do not watch them.

Way to go, Ubisoft.  You put a ton of effort into producing cutscenes that aren't even watched on the initial playthrough because the player resents you smashing them over the head with them without asking.  If I had a dollar for every time I was trying to casually go from point A to point B on the map only to get forcibly hijacked way over to point Z by a cutscene that I just want to skip on the first playthrough because spite, I could afford to buy the game again.

Also, there is no depth to the game.  Every single mission in the whole game is EXACTLY the same: 1. Go to some point on the map. 2. Kill all the baddies there.  That's it.  That is a full and honest description of every single mission in the entire game.  Every.  Single. One.  They are all exactly the same.  Missions at the end of the game are exactly like missions at the beginning of the game.  The format doesn't change.

Don't bother with this game.  Get something from Rockstar or CD Project Red instead.

One of the laziest AAA games I think I've played yet. Obviously, the Far Cry formula isn't very creative to begin with but this feels incredibly phoned in even for Ubisoft. Every system in the game, from the gunplay to driving feels incredibly mediocre. Possibly the worst part though is the story which kept me completely unengaged. Nobody involved in the making of this game made a sincere effort, there was no artistry put into it, so why should you spend your time on it? Yes I finished it but I was watching TV on my other monitor the entire time, and I would recommend you find a better game to spend your time on.

[h1] A FC5 review [/h1]
[hr] [/hr]

[h2] Advisory [/h2]
Being a longstanding player, having played through FC3, FC4 and a little of FC Primal and Blood Dragon I feel I have come to enjoy and hate this series over the years. I won't go into how Ubi-Shit make awful cash grab games, because. That would take away from this review and in all honesty this game isn't a Ubi-Cash grab it's a game with so much love, detail and attention to every aspect of it that I cannot not make a review of it. So, I will. Without a further a do let's go into it.

[h2] Graphics and Optimisation [/h2]

For [b] 2018 [/b] theses graphics aren't impressive, they're damn fucking amazing. The game is well optimised, having watched Benchmarkers on YouTube I can see without a doubt this can run on all kinds of hardware. Ranging from low end, to RTX 3090s everyone will see an equally amazing experience, this can also apparently run on the Valve Steam Deck, performance looks good and I've heard good feedback from people on the Console. I personally ran this on a Gaming Laptop with a GTX 1660 TI, which is by all means not low end. However Performance [b] never [/b] dropped at all. The game has out dated textures and some aspects of the visuals don't look amazing, models look last generation. However, the game more then makes up for it with its incredible lighting, the only downside is the SSR which do not look good by any means. However, given the games age this is of course excusable.

[h2] Gameplay [/h2]

The gameplay [i] can [/i] can get boring, it is the same loop. Liberate an outpost, do a mission/side mission, liberate some hostages, deal with a supply truck and blow up a gas truck. It's practically just a run and gun, type of experience with nothing really else to add. But, this a norm with FC. However, it does have VIP enemies and so on. The game, has an amazing open world. Allowing you to go almost everywhere with zero restrictions. It does try and guide you, however it won't force you to play how the game is intended. And you're completely free to take on the campaign however you like.

[h2] Campaign and Story [/h2] 

[b] This will be spoiler free [/b] the campaign has 3 separate difficulties: Easy, Normal and Hard.

The gameplay won't change regardless of mode you pick, I played on Normal and personally found it difficult to complete the game. However, I more then likely have a [b] skill issue [/b] and should cope. The game has issues with pacing, the story is interesting to say the least. Without getting to spoiler-some it's practically WACO siege if it was on crack Cocaine. I don't want to give any details, there is character development. As the game progresses you do feel attached to the people involved, and naturally you want to help them. I won't delve to much further into this, I don't want to give out any spoliers. The Story is incredibly interesting however, and had me hooked from the beginning.

[h3] TLDR [/h3]

Buy it, it's a great game. With lot's of fun, to be had. Everything about it screams value for money [b] (DO NOT BUY IT AT 60 BUCKS THO [/b]

At the ripe price of 8 pounds, it is truly an absolute fucking bargain. I give it 9/10

[h2] The Good[/h2]
[list]
    [*]Great gunplay and bullet impact on enemies
    [*]Soundtrack and audio design is exemplerary
    [*]Does well most of the things that previous FC games did, like the obvious outpost freeing. It improved some things like collectables having fun side stories around them, and not being as annoying to get. 
    [*]Apart from the crappy ending I got, the story's pretty good. Especially side missions and side characters are a lot more fleshed out than in previous games
    [*] The gun 4 hire / companions you unlock throughout the game are really cool. The have context-aware dialogue, talk to other NPCs in the game world and even each other, and *when it works* have dialogue that reflects your game progress. Apart from that they actually have some combat ability
    [*] They did a pretty good job at selling the US Montana environment
[/list]

[h2] The Meh[/h2]
[list]
    [*] The Living World events are not as annoying as previous games, especially FC4 and FC:Primal (thank god). It could however still be toned down a little
    [*]  I encountered some smaller bugs like falling through the map if you open your parachute too late. Or NPCs constantly stopping talking mid-dialogue, because they saw some enemy 10 km away. 
   [*]  DLC weapons are instantly unlocked and actually ruin the game. They are stupidly OP. I don't recommend using them
[/list]

[h2] The Bad[/h2]
[list]
    [*] Just as in previous Far Cry games the economy is terribly designed. In previous installments, you get way too much money way too quickly, and unlock everything long before the game is over. In this game, you get way too little money, and will never unlock everything unless you plan to grind "fishing" and skinning animals for days. The missions give practically no reward
    [*]  This is a big one. NPCs keep spoiling the story! Ubisoft for some reason couldn't get quest facts to work correctly in this game. They have tons of  progression-based dialogue like "great job killing villain A", and "I'm so glad you took out villain B", or "aaawh it's really unfortunate you ended up killing "friendly character" - BEFORE you did it! Both random NPCs in the overworld and even your own gun for hire squad mates do this. It's incredibly frustrating
    [*]  The constant "getting kidnapped" mechanic is horrendous. It takes away all control of the player, places you in dumb unrealistic situations, and does so without giving you a choice or chance to fight back
    [*]  Weird microtransactions. There was no need for that
    [*]  Talking to NPCs itself is frustrating, instead of being able to repress the "talk" button to hear more dialogue lines, you need to move out of sight a bit, then back to the NPC, then press talk again. As I'm someone who wants to hear all the dialogue, this was an extremely frequent frustration
  [*]  The ending I got was really disappointing. Not because it was a bad ending, but because it was terribly unrealistic and just like the kidnapping, took away all control of doing what I wanted to do for no reason at all
    [/list]

Overall 7.5/10

Great game, enormous fun.  Is it better than FC4 and FC3?  Difficult to say.  I played FC3 and FC4 on Playstation and enjoyed both of them immensely.  I recently replayed FC3 on PC and am currently FC5 on PC, using a PS5 Controller (I don't have a PS5, it's just my preferred controller). 
Strangely, I can run FC5 at much higher settings than FC3, and get much better FPS. Better optimisation I suppose.
If you do want to play with a PS5 controller on the PC, I recommend using DS4Windows, as FC5 does not directly support the PS5 controller.  With DS4W you can map the PS5 to a PS4 controller, which is supported by FC5.

Memorable, beautiful, and nostalgic. This is the best looking and set far cry game. The best part about this game is definitely the music and setting. You have some of the best music in all of gaming in this game that fit in the atmosphere really smoothly. The setting is perfection, it has so much forest and natural beauty but also a good mix of American hill billy feeling towns. You could travel around this map for ages and not get bored since its so astonishing and there are so many Easter eggs to find. It also has a top 2 far cry villain, Joseph Seed. This villain is truly complex and has so much depth layered around his character which makes him really interesting and captivating, you're always wanting to learn more about the character. But this game also has many flaws, first being the main character has no character which wipes away a lot of the potential from this game because how can you root for a main character who has no ideologies or morals. Secondly the story is extremely repetitive and predictable. Its just kill one boss after another. For these reasons this game is a 7/10, its got the same basic formula but it does it really well and its catchy but overall nothing too special. 10/10 atmosphere and music though.

Far Cry 5 is an amazing first-person shooter that transports you to the gorgeous and lively Hope County, Montana, where you face a thrilling challenge from a powerful cult. You play as a deputy sheriff who joins forces with the local resistance to liberate the region from the charismatic leader, Joseph Seed, and his family of zealots. The game offers a huge open world that is full of possibilities, secrets, and surprises. You can explore the stunning landscapes, hunt wildlife, fish, fly planes, drive vehicles, and use a variety of weapons and gadgets to take down your foes. You can also customize your character, recruit allies, and even tame animals to assist you in your missions.

The game features a dynamic story that adapts to your actions and choices. You can tackle the main campaign in any order you want, or ignore it altogether and just have fun in the sandbox. The game also supports co-op and online multiplayer modes, where you can team up with friends or strangers to complete challenges, create maps, or just cause chaos. The game has a lot of humor and personality, but it also tackles some serious themes and delivers some emotional moments. The game has a great soundtrack that matches the mood and setting of the game, and the voice acting and motion capture are superb.

Far Cry 5 is a polished game, though. It has some minor technical issues, such as long loading times, pop-in, glitches, and crashes, but they are not frequent or game-breaking. It also has some gameplay issues, such as repetitive missions, annoying enemies, and lack of stealth options, but they are not significant or frustrating. The game can also be too easy or too hard, depending on your difficulty setting and playstyle, but you can always adjust them to suit your preference. The game’s story is also bold, as some people may find it provocative, unrealistic, or unsatisfying. The game’s ending, in particular, is daring and may leave you feeling shocked or intrigued.

Overall, Far Cry 5 is a fun and exciting game that offers a lot of content and variety. It is a game that lets you play the way you want, and rewards you for exploring and experimenting. It is a game that has a lot of charm and character, but also a lot of violence and madness. It is a game that will keep you entertained for hours, but also make you think and feel. It is a game that is worth playing, if you are a fan of the Far Cry series or the genre in general.

[b]Advisory: My "Play Time" is inflated by 20 or more hours because Steam counts Ubiconnect being open as play time[/b]

[h1]TL;DR:[/h1]

Buy it on sale, waste some time, if you get bored (and you will) you probably won't miss anything by putting it on the shelf.

[h1]The Writeup[/h1]

The whole game is ridiculously on-rails, to the extent that it's essentially a rails shooter with lots of space and stuff to do between the rides. You don't have any agency in how the "plot" advances, and the game essentially deus-ex-machina-s you into whatever situation is necessary to deliver the story before you are regurgitated back into the world so that you can flail about before getting browbeat again.

The plot is an excuse to build the game and is completely linear with no nuance. A fifth grader could deliver something less insipid. [spoiler]There's a vaguely post-contemporary quasi-Christian religious movement (Eden's Gate/EG) that owns an alarming (and convenient to the plot) amount of cold war defense infrastructure in some fictitious part of Montana. The members of EG believe that society will collapse and that they have been chosen to rebuild, and have been terrorizing their neighbors in preparation. This terrorizing has attracted the attention of The Government™, who send a poorly prepared an out-matched team to collect their leader. Things being as they are, the leader is not very interested in taking a vacation, and things go south. You, the protagonist, are - as these things tend to go - the only remotely competent member of this team, and[/spoiler] you must dispense with the three lieutenants, John, Jacob, and Faith before you can have a calm, reasonable discussion with the leader, Joseph. Each of the three are one-dimensional stereotypes: John is a smooth talking lawyer and high-class-bumpkin, Jacob is a PTSD case and army-surplus-enjoyer, Faith is a Manson girl. In the process of taking out the trash, you will - as one expects - liquidate an unending army of the same six or so bandits, all of whom are broadly incompetent yet capable of operating attack aircraft. Between avoiding and/or killing bandits, you advance the story by interacting with offensive and paper thin stereotypes (we're talking [i]Postal[/i] levels of character stereotyping), many of whom can only be transplants from other parts of the states, and by being "kidnapped," which consists of being forced to play through repetitive and bland linear story segments that you will come to hate.

The characters and setting in this game live in this weird uncanny valley - it's as if aliens were asked to create a simulation of rural North America by watching Right-Wing Infotainment and reading satire. There's also this insidious stench of centrist all-holds-barred sociopolitical commentary throughout the whole thing.

[h1]The Shit List[/h1]

[olist]
[*] The game purports to allow for "non-confrontational" (not "stealth," that's a little too specific) gameplay, and offers silencers, throwing knives, and takedown mechanics; however, it does not complement these features with other considerations such as allowing for multiple approaches to scripted missions (they are [i]designed[/i] to escalate to [i]very[/i] hot confrontations), sane NPC patrol behavior and placement, not having an air patrol alarm an entire encampment of bandits for unclear reasons even when you are undetected by the plane and bandits, and other such things.
[*] There's too much lens flare. Lens flare is not realistic, unless you see the world through a camera. For the record, lens flare is caused by internal reflections within an optical system, and should be accompanied by glare and reduced contrast. 
[*] Apparently one can just go to Wal-Mart and purchase a fighter plane with support for aerial bombs. Who knew?
[*] Ally NPCs are a liability in many cases. Don't travel with them, only call them when needed.
[*] Driving fast enough along a long stretch of road demonstrates how hard the game tries to create the appearance of a dynamic world, but it falls short as it quickly becomes apparent that the thing you just drove past will not persist once it drops out of range: for example, I can speed past a sizable conflict with multiple vehicles, and if I come back thirty seconds later there will be nothing there. It's a little silly.
[*] "Functional requirement" crafting system - I can make proximity mines, but I can't remove accessories from a weapon on the go.
[*] "Homeopathics" are a mechanic, and I don't think the writers did any research into what that term means, or the pseudoscience behind how they are supposed to work. They are totally irrelevant, save for one story mission.
[*] Bliss is pretty much "universal plot solvent." It is all drugs at once. It's a sedative, it's a stimulant, it's a hallucinogen, it's an entactogen. It exists to plaster over plot holes.
[*] If you are going to pick a plant to make "Bliss" from, Jimsonweed is probably not it. You probably want some kind of Acacia - those can be very spicy and exciting, and produce compounds that are actually useful building blocks.
[*] There's all sorts of stupid speculation, tantrum throwing, and flame wars about the ending in the community tab. In my opinion it borders somewhere between a cop-out and dark humor/irony. You can throw another layer on that cake by simply asking "yeah, that was bad, but is Eden's Gate's vision of the future a humane one?"
[/olist]

The graphics, vehicles, and physics are cool.  A lot of the NPC dialogue is humorous in a good way.  The Montana country side is beautiful to quest in and the cult story concept is intriguing.

However, the open world they tried to create is a double-edged sword.  Maybe it was too open.  It felt like the game had no direction and you were doing the same, seemingly endless quests over and over again.  

Combat didn't seem realistic at all - too arcade like.  When you got shot with a bullet, the only thing that happened is your health meter went down a bit.  It seemed like getting shot wasn't a big deal and had no consequences.

Oh yeah, then there's the install that includes "Ubisoft Connect" where you have to create an account and sign in.  Ubisoft Connect is of those Steam wannabes that could never gain traction yet ended up selling on Steam anyway.

The verdict?  Buy if it's on sale to mess around and give it a try.  It's definitely not worth the outrageous price of $60 - $70.  I personally got bored of it quite quickly.

The game is 'enjoyable' and I highly recommend you to try it yourself. 

For me, however, the story of this game is quite simple and DULL. In this game, your main goal is to free the territories while also eliminating the cult leaders, Joseph Seed and his brothers. For those who enjoy following a game's plot, you've undoubtedly discovered that this game has the foolish notion of making a story and repeating the same phrase till the finish. 

To clarify, the game consists only of freeing territories, being abducted by adversaries, killing them to escape, liberating regions again, and being kidnapped again until you reach the conclusion. This repetition is UNAVOIDABLE. It automatically happens to you, regardless of what you're doing. You may be fishing and still get abducted, or you could be going about looking for a good spot to grab a screenshot and still be taken. It is very annoying. 

However, the concept of a quest relationship appeals to me. In comparison to other open world games, the primary mission and side quests are usually unrelated. Almost every side mission you do has an impact on the boss's reaction and leads to the main plot.

I believe you should give this game a go. It's not really good, but it's still entertaining.

Far Cry 5 is a mixed bag, offering some great moments but also falling short in several areas. On the positive side, there's a ton of content with loads of side quests and opportunities for explosive mayhem. The game's humor shines through in quirky missions like Testie Festie, and it boasts an interesting cast of characters. Clutch Nixon events are a blast, and the opening sequence is one of the series' best. The villains are memorable, and the inclusion of companions with unique perks adds depth to your journey, especially with loyal Boomer by your side.

However, Far Cry 5 has its downsides. I personally didn't like how the game integrated your inventory capacity with the games perk system, and the game's weapons feel rather average. Basic NPCs lack diversity, and repetitive voice lines become noticeable. The game often plays like your typical shooter, and the removal of radio towers might disappoint some fans. Additionally, the rush to gain reputation points can detract from the enjoyment of the story missions, and the ending makes you feel like everything you've done was for nothing. Thankfully, there's a mod to address the pacing issue https://www.nexusmods.com/farcry5/mods/23. While Far Cry 5 has its quirks, it still manages to offer a satisfying dose of open-world chaos.

Having played Far Cry 3 and 4 in the past, I was disappointed by this game. It feels far too formulaic without enough character when compared to those two.
This might suit some players, who just play these games for the gameplay. But I found the story to be lacking compared to its two predecessors. The character you play as is a blank slate. There are very few cutscenes for the NPCs, making your mission interactions with them seem very stale and robotic. There are some recurring characters from previous games, in which they often had story-important missions and side quests. In this game, however, only their voice actors are present, but there is no motion capture cutscenes or interactions with them, making your time spent with them as forgettable as the majority of the optional side quests of this game.

I think this game would suit many people who just want solid FPS gameplay. For those looking for more depth in other departments (Story, character progression), be aware of the differences between this game and the previous main two in the series. With your expectations changed, you might not be disappointed, and can enjoy this game for what it is.

"Farcry 5" is a first-person shooter video game that was released in 2018. It's set in the fictional Hope County, Montana, and revolves around a doomsday cult that has taken control of the area. Here's a brief review:

Pros:
1. Open World: The game offers a vast open world with diverse landscapes, activities, and wildlife, providing a sense of freedom and exploration.

2. Story: The game's storyline is engaging and explores the theme of religious extremism, adding depth to the typical shooter narrative.

3. Graphics: "Farcry 5" features stunning visuals with detailed environments and realistic character models.

4. Gameplay: The game's combat mechanics are solid, offering a variety of weapons, vehicles, and skills to tackle the challenges in different ways.

Cons:
1. AI: The enemy AI can sometimes be predictable and not as challenging as one would hope for in a shooter game.

2. Repetition: Some players may find certain missions or activities repetitive over time.

3. Story Pacing: The pacing of the main story can be uneven, with occasional interruptions by side activities.

Overall, "Farcry 5" offers an enjoyable open-world experience with a compelling narrative, but it does have some shortcomings in terms of AI and mission variety. If you enjoy open-world shooters and are interested in the game's setting, it's worth giving it a try.
