Spoiler Disclaimer. 

I have played Far Cry 1, 2, 3, Primal, 4, 5, and New Dawn. As a FPS, I really have enjoyed them. I have liked the change in scenery from one to the next. Really feels like the developers found a niche, and stuck with it hard. Keep beating that dead horse til it stops spitting out money. Well, now it stops for me. I will not be playing Far Cry 6, and I shouldn't have bothered with New Dawn. 

Have you ever had a coworker, fellow student, friend or whoever, who you can tell is not very intelligent, but they occasionally grace you with what they believe is a nugget of wisdom? This individual, assistant-manager-type, will tell you something they seem to think is very enlightened and mindful, and all you can think while they're talking is: "Yeah, I came to that conclusion on my own, with no help, at the ripe old age of 9. Why are you just now realizing this at 42?" They like to tell you all about their rules for life, work ethic, or how they make decisions, and everything they say is either a really bad idea, or it is so basic, no one should ever have to have it explained to them, because its just something everyone figures out from living the bare-minimum of life outside your parents' basement. And you're living a better quality life at 20-some-odd than they are at 40-some-odd, so why would you listen to what they have to say? 

A large group of this kind of person is who wrote the stories for these games. 

Look... These are First Person Shooter games, taking place in interesting locations that have few, if any consequences for your incredibly violent actions, and include a scenario and hate-able villains that spurs on your incredibly violent actions. We take these actions in video games because we're not going to in real life. So we don't need these games to punish us for these actions, because we're not doing anything to real people, we're just killing 1s and 0s. I don't need to have some (very specific characteristics that probably violate Rules and Guidelines) pacifists judging me and punishing me for playing the game the way it was designed, and trying to convince me that I'm the "real villain" for trying to stop a cult of murderers, torturers, rapists, kidnappers, Geneva-Convention-breakers, thieves, liars, corpse-mutilators: all under the guise of being political and religious zealots. 

I've enjoyed hunting animals for their skins and using them to upgrade my gear (removed in Far Cry 5 for some dumb reason). I've enjoyed trying, and retrying, and retrying to take and retake outposts in all these games: the layouts have almost always been well thought-out and executed. I've enjoyed that you don't necessarily have to go everywhere on the map and finish every little thing, but I always do. I like that in Far Cry 5, Dutch tells you he's not going to ask you to go climb radio towers all over the county, because the developers had an uncharacteristic moment of consciousness. I have enjoyed the gear layouts, and especially in Far Cry 5, the choices of weapons and customization. 

What I don't like: 
They try to make you feel bad for, sympathize with, or straight up join the villain in most/all of these games. 
They try to make you feel bad for killing scum-of-the-Earth type individuals. 
There is ALWAYS a drug element. Primal, you're drinking bloody nasty stuff from a skull. 4, you're getting stabbed against your will by some druggies. 5, you're getting too affected by Bliss. I remember it being a part of 3 as well, but don't remember what it was. 
They ALWAYS railroad you into stuff that most likely wouldn't have happened, considering your character. You can go the WHOLE GAME without needing help, just destroying everything in your path with ease, but the moment the developers need the villain to be able to deliver a monologue, suddenly someone can just punch you in the face and knock you out, open a music box and make you pass out (automatically brainwashed after hearing the song for the first time, ever... yeah that makes sense), or someone just pops up in front of you and blows Bliss in your face, or you survive a vehicle crash with Joseph Seed and he's the only one who doesn't get injured or knocked unconscious. Really, truly lazy writing, and terrible execution. 

And the BIG ONE! What is up with these endings??? 
Far Cry 3's endings were disappointing, but I felt like one was bad and the other was okay. 
Far Cry 4, I have read about an ending that I think I wouldn't mind, but I haven't gotten it yet. But the main two options are AWFUL. 
Far Cry 5 has no good ending. 
Let Joseph go at the beginning? Why would I do that? 
Nuclear war, and 16 years in a bunker alone with Joseph? Miss me with that. 
Let Joseph go at the end and ambiguously fade to red? After all he's done now, of course I'm not going to do that. 
I get that they intended to make him a suuuuuper-lame part of Far Cry: New Dawn, so you couldn't just straight-up brain-pan the guy, but had that been an option, I wouldn't have even been mad about the nuclear war. The way the game ends, I saw the nuke go off, and was genuinely emotionally affected by that turn of events. Then drove for our lives, trying to save Whitehorse and myself, actually worried about the prospect of us dying. Then got to Dutch's bunker, and Joseph killed Whitehorse and Dutch and imprisoned me in the bunker with him, giving off some seriously rape-y vibes, and that ruined everything for me. That ending gave me this very unsatisfied feeling of "What...? Did they actually just do that? Is that really the end of the game?" 
Would have even been better if you, Whitehorse and Dutch ended up in the bunker and Joseph escaped with his life. Then you come back in New Dawn, reprising your roll as Rook, and decide then whether or not to finish Joseph. Has enough time gone by for you to forgive him? Or does your righteous anger still burn hot enough to convince you to kill the hermit? 

Man... This series. Great gameplay, great sandboxing, great weapon choices (excluding the sawblade gun... come on guys), great vehicles, great mechanics, great collection-completion. 
Piss-poor writing. 
Piss-poor railroading. 
Piss-poor guilt-tripping (attempts). 

These games could have been utterly flawless, if they had just forced all the bleeding-heart-writers' content to be filtered through people who actually like FPS games. If they had sat down with disgruntled veterans and current or ex LEOs, they could have fixed everything that was wrong with these games, and made so much more money than they did. It is such a Far Crying shame.

[h1]Far Cry 5 : An Immersive Adventure in the Heartland[/h1]

[b]Graphics: ★★★★☆[/b]
Far Cry 5 showcases stunning visuals and realistic environments that truly bring the Montana wilderness to life. From the lush forests to the snowy mountains, the game's graphics provide a highly detailed and visually captivating experience.

[b]Gameplay: ★★★★☆[/b]
The gameplay of Far Cry 5 offers a seamless and immersive open-world experience. With a plethora of engaging missions and side activities, players are provided with countless opportunities to explore the vast map and interact with a diverse range of characters. The inclusion of various vehicles adds an extra dimension to gameplay, allowing for fast-paced action and thrilling chases.

[b]Story: ★★★★☆[/b]
The narrative of Far Cry 5 is intriguing, delving into the conflicts and struggles of a remote Montana county under the oppressive rule of a religious cult called Eden's Gate. The characters are well-developed and offer emotionally-charged encounters throughout the game. While the story occasionally suffers from pacing issues, the unpredictable twists and turns keep players engaged till the very end.

[b]Sound: ★★★★★[/b]
The sound design of Far Cry 5 is exceptional, immersing players in the game's world. The ambient sounds of nature, gunfights, and explosions are incredibly realistic, while the voice acting is top-notch, bringing life to the diverse cast of characters. The game's soundtrack perfectly complements the atmosphere, enhancing both the tension-filled moments and the peaceful tranquility of exploration.

[b]Multiplayer: ★★★☆☆[/b]
Far Cry 5 features a cooperative multiplayer mode, allowing players to team up with friends to tackle missions and explore the vast open world together. While the multiplayer adds an extra layer of fun and excitement, it is not as polished as the single-player experience. Connection issues and occasional glitches can hinder the enjoyment of the cooperative gameplay.

[b]Replay Value: ★★★★☆[/b]
With a vast map to explore, countless side activities to complete, and multiple endings, Far Cry 5 offers significant replay value. The game encourages players to experiment with different playstyles, weapons, and approaches, ensuring that each playthrough feels fresh and unique.

[b]Overall: ★★★★☆[/b]
Far Cry 5 delivers an immersive and captivating experience set in a beautiful yet dangerous open world. The game excels in its graphics, gameplay mechanics, and sound design. While the cooperative multiplayer could use some improvements, the game's strong storyline and replay value make it a must-play for fans of open-world adventures and first-person shooters.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I come from north-western Montana myself. When I heard this game first came out. I was all for it and so far playing it since it came out. It has not disappointed. From the DLC, I know some Viet Nam vets whom are very close friends of mine. To the wild life, to the cultist's, to the fire arms. Everything is spot on, and I wholeheartedly endorse this game for anyone who would like a taste of my home state.

Far Cry 5 is the most soulless game I have ever played. The 3rd installment seemed to actually have some effort put into the narrative, characters, unique game mechanics (for the time), and use of sudden well-acted cut scenes to disrupt the gameplay loop. This game, the 5th, attempts to recreate some of those special moments from previous titles, but it completely falls flat with the boring narrative and lifeless environments. Racist and religious rural America might seem exotic to people who don't live here, but the game provides no interesting commentary about the current state of affairs. Even if you got this game for free, it is not worth your time. Just replay the 3rd if you're desperately seeking the Far Cry experience. Or watch American History X to get your fix of white supremacist assholes getting a comeuppance. 2/10

[h1] The Good [/h1]
• [u]Open-World Diversity[/u]: Far Cry 5 boasts a vast and diverse open-world environment, offering players a rich playground for exploration with a variety of landscapes, terrains, and dynamic weather.

• [u]Compelling Storytelling[/u]: The game features a captivating narrative with memorable characters, creating an immersive experience as players navigate the intense and unpredictable events unfolding in the fictional Hope County.

• [u]Engaging Gunplay[/u]: Far Cry 5 excels in delivering satisfying and dynamic gunplay, with a wide array of weapons and customizable loadouts that cater to different playstyles, ensuring combat remains consistently engaging.

• [u]Companion System[/u]: The addition of a companion system enhances the gameplay, allowing players to recruit and strategically deploy companions with unique skills, adding depth and tactical options to encounters.

• [u]Stunning Visuals[/u]: The game's graphics and visual design contribute to an aesthetically pleasing experience, capturing the beauty of the open world and enhancing the overall immersion.

• [u]Freedom of Approach[/u]: Far Cry 5 encourages player agency by providing multiple approaches to missions and challenges, allowing for a sense of freedom in decision-making and strategy.

[hr][/hr]

[h1] The Bad [/h1]
• [u]Repetitive Side Activities[/u]: Some players may find the side activities and missions to be somewhat repetitive, as certain objectives and scenarios may feel similar after extended play.

• [u]Limited Enemy Variation[/u]: The variety of enemy types and archetypes may be somewhat limited, potentially leading to encounters that feel less diverse over time.

• [u]Abrupt Ending[/u]: The game's ending has been criticized for its abruptness and lack of a more conclusive resolution, leaving some players wanting more closure to the narrative.

[hr][/hr]

[h1] The Ugly [/h1]
• [u]AI Inconsistencies[/u]: The artificial intelligence (AI) of both enemies and allies can exhibit inconsistencies, with occasional instances of erratic behavior that may break immersion or disrupt the flow of gameplay.

• [u]Microtransaction Integration[/u]: Far Cry 5 includes microtransactions for cosmetic items and boosts, which can be perceived as an unwelcome addition, potentially impacting the balance of progression and rewards.

• [u]Limited Innovation[/u]: While maintaining the core Far Cry formula, some players may feel that Far Cry 5 lacks significant innovation compared to its predecessors, resulting in an experience that may feel familiar to series veterans.

[hr][/hr]
[h1]Overall Score: [/h1]
[h3] 6.7/10 [/h3]

"Amazing Grace" is a Christian hymn published in 1779 with words written in 1772 by English Anglican clergyman and poet John Newton (1725–1807). It is an immensely popular hymn, particularly in the United States, where it is used for both religious and secular purposes.

Newton wrote the words from personal experience; he grew up without any particular religious conviction, but his life's path was formed by a variety of twists and coincidences that were often put into motion by others' reactions to what they took as his recalcitrant insubordination. He was pressed into service with the Royal Navy, and after leaving the service, he became involved in the Atlantic slave trade. In 1748, a violent storm battered his vessel off the coast of County Donegal, Ireland, so severely that he called out to God for mercy. While this moment marked his spiritual conversion, he continued slave trading until 1754 or 1755, when he ended his seafaring altogether. Newton began studying Christian theology and later became an abolitionist.

Ordained in the Church of England in 1764, Newton became the curate of Olney, Buckinghamshire, where he began to write hymns with poet William Cowper. "Amazing Grace" was written to illustrate a sermon on New Year's Day of 1773. It is unknown if there was any music accompanying the verses; it may have been chanted by the congregation. It debuted in print in 1779 in Newton's and Cowper's Olney Hymns, but settled into relative obscurity in England. In the United States, "Amazing Grace" became a popular song used by Baptist and Methodist preachers as part of their evangelizing, especially in the American South, during the Second Great Awakening of the early 19th century. It has been associated with more than 20 melodies. In 1835, American composer William Walker set it to the tune known as "New Britain" in a shape note format; this is the version most frequently sung today.

With the message that forgiveness and redemption are possible regardless of sins committed and that the soul can be delivered from despair through the mercy of God, "Amazing Grace" is one of the most recognisable songs in the English-speaking world. American historian Gilbert Chase writes that it is "without a doubt the most famous of all the folk hymns"[1] and Jonathan Aitken, a Newton biographer, estimates that the song is performed about 10 million times annually.[2]

It has had particular influence in folk music, and has become an emblematic black spiritual. Its universal message has been a significant factor in its crossover into secular music. "Amazing Grace" became newly popular during the 1960s revival of American folk music, and it has been recorded thousands of times during and since the 20th century.

Once again with the repetitive hallucination-dream-sequence-battle-in-a-tunnel, the Far Cry franchise  earns a big fat "uh-uh" from me. You're punished for succeeding in story missions by being forced into the same fight over and over, a timed grind through a surreal burning building. This time-waster tactic disrupts the flow of the game--much like the irritating Shanath arena mess in FC4 (though it does allow for you to make a sandwich--or do your taxes--while voice actors taking cues from Christian Bale's Batman talk raspy nonsense and kill the momentum of a gorgeous open-world FPS--no offense to the voice actors, they all do a great job). Then there's the Faith dreams, where you're forced to walk slo-mo through foggy flowery landscapes, I guess it's supposed to feel like you're playing the game, but you might as well be watching one long cut scene followed by a cookie-cutter boss fight in a small area with limited health and ammo.  Maybe I misunderstand the ultimate goal of open-world games, but it is the freedom I find fun, not being forced to run-and-gun through narrow maze-like hallways or dodge around in a misty clearing in the creepy-crawly woods, racing against the clock in a tedious scripted nightmare.

Don't expect an excellent game, but it's a very good one, with particularly good music and sound effects. The atmospheres of the different regions are well realised. The gameplay in terms of weapons, driving and general movement is enjoyable. The main characters are fun and engaging! The main quests are fun and the secondary objectives are really original and funny.

Some negative points:
-Sometimes there are very chaotic scenes where several events are taking place at the same time. 
-There are occasional disjointed scenes where enemies and allies meet without any interaction (prisoners on the side of the road, etc.).
-The distance between enemy and allied camps is sometimes so close that it's hard to understand why they don't attack each other. 

I can't recommend the game highly enough - it's a great way to let off steam in a very well realised environment!

This may just be the greatest game ever created. From the scenery to the music, everything is perfect. It tackles this little area in my head that wants exactly what this game has to offer. Something about the American tradition mixed with a realistic setting and scenario makes this game amazing. If I had to put a scenario in your head that captures the feeling this game gives me it would be this:
Imagine you are sitting in a lawn chair in your Montana countryside house right in the opening of your garage door. The garage lights are on and you are looking out into the surrounding forest but you cannot see anything but black due to the light pollution coming from the garage. Surrounding your house is the sounds of crickets chirping and frogs croaking. Your 50's style neon sign for "Bush Light" hanging in your garage window reflects a blue hue onto the ground. With your gun in one hand and Bapple in your other, you walk out away from the garage. Looking up into the night sky you see the beautiful stars of the Milky Way. You walk further away and now that the light pollution from the garage is not affecting you, you look around your house. Farm fields and trees are all lit up by the moonlight. It reminds you of a simpler time when you were younger. When life wasn't so complicated and the only worry in life was what you were going to spend your weekend doing. 
This feeling I get when playing this game is why I return to it so often. With my time on PC combined with my time on PlayStation, I have easily 1000 hours in this game. Every time I play through the game I 100% it and make sure to play it in a different style and/or order every time. The best thing about this game is that I don't even need to listen to music. Most of the time paying a game I have spotify in the background or at least turn the music off. But not with this.
If you read all of that thank you and I hope that you appreciate this game the same way I have. If you have not played it, this is your sign to buy the game and at least give it a chance. It is truly a great game.

Recommended if you like Far Cry games, but even then just barely. If there was a "so-so" recommendation then I would choose that.

I actually like the standard Far Cry gameplay loop but this was the worst Far Cry that I have played (between 3, Primal, and 4. 4 is still my favorite). Driving controls are pretty bad, most of the boss fights are lame (a problem with most Far Cry games unfortunately), and all of the several endings are dumb (with the "best" ending being dumbest of all). 

Hunting also seems to be more de-emphasized from previous games. You no longer need to hunt and skin animals to upgrade your gear (that is all done with perks now). You certainly can hunt, but if you don't need cash then there isn't much of a point. There is also no longer a skinning animation, you just "loot" the animal and you instantly get its skin. This might be a minor nit-pick to some, but it bothered me. 

They removed the towers that you have to activate across the map from previous games. I'm admittedly a minority in this, but I like doing the towers. 

Before I played this game I read that the story beats rely on you being knocked out and kidnapped repeatedly. I thought "What, does this happen three or four times? That's not too terrible. You get knocked out in 3 a lot, too". But no, it happens ALL THE TIME. You are constantly being knocked out and kidnapped so that the story can keep chugging along. You can't really believe how often this happens unless you play the game yourself. It's almost unbelievable and some of the laziest writing I have seen in a game.

Things I do like: The NPC companion system is super fun, and I found uses for almost all of the companions. Just sitting back and ordering your team to take a base while you direct them to targets is some of the funnest things in the game (and it counts as an undetected win as long as you yourself aren't seen). And, even though driving isn't very satisfying, I do like flying around in the planes. Strafing and bombing targets is very satisfying. 

So, if you like Far Cry games then I do recommend you give this a try (maybe wait until it's on sale). Unless you want to do every task in the game it's not extremely long (it's tied with Primal for being my fastest Far Cry completion at just over 20 hours. Far Cry 3 was the fastest at around 12 hours and 4 took me over 40).

The Far Cry series has problems. The amount of death you cause, the pseudo imperialist overtones and rampant stereotyping, the repetitive mechanics, the 'map full of icons' to-do list and how it exemplifies the worst proclivities of sandbox games.

Moving to Montana has shifted some of this stuff into other realms that are designed to make people different people uncomfortable, and it toys with psychological concepts with far more depth than the previous games.

It has it's own problems, though. My biggest frustration was twofold: constant enemy encounters while transiting to objectives (literally every 10-15 seconds a truckload of armed cultists would roll up), and forced boss checkpoint missions that would drag you off your current goals at preset progress points. I did install a mod that allowed you to depopulate the map, which helped A LOT with the constant interruptions.

In other words, FC5's biggest issues lie in when the game interrupts the free-flow sandbox play. Which is excellent.

I bought this game at a discount because I wanted a new experience with video games. They have been feeling pretty repetitive and It's been hard to play for good lengths at a time due to this. Far Cry changed all of this.

First of all, I will start off with the environment created by the world of Far Cry 5, it makes you feel truly alone, and powerless as you go up against these cult leaders. Not only that but the visuals and the way that the terrain is built make it fun to walk or run places, and not just fast travel, because along the way you can find animals to kill and sell for money, but you can also find plenty of side quests to keep you engaged within the game.

Secondly, the combat offers a totally fun and puzzling experience, as someone who enjoys going in guns blazing and is the opposite of sneaking around, some situations force you to be quiet for a larger reward, and it is fun because there is always an opportunity to just start shooting like crazy. It is a fun and non-repetitive combat system that I think was synthesized well.

Lastly, the psychological aspect of the story line is beautiful. Without spoiling lots. I want to hate these people, and some of them, I did, some of them I celebrated the downfalls of. But at certain times I would be reluctant to feel too good about the game, because it left me questioning things, asking myself what the whole side of said characters' story was, and how they got there. Not going to spoil any more than that because it is something that I think you all should go find out for yourselves.

Stay safe...

I've always seen far cry as a series ,not about protagonists or world setting ,but about antagonists.In today's age people tend to appreciate more the bad guys than good ones ,because they present more human and understanding motives than heroes ,which are more Gary/Mary Sue like...

In that perspective ,I say that Far Cry 5 ,has the best villan in the series ,not because of his definition of insanity or his overgrown ego ,but because of his "vision" of a prophecy ,of a world that could be clean only through sacrifice ,a thought that a psychopath may have ,but unlike a psychopath ,this man not only does he have lots of charisma to make a loyal army that would put some national armies to shame ,but he also has the power to influence people against him to do his biting.

He is crazy ,because of loss (I don't wanna spoil why ,you'll have to find out) and because of a false signal and a false way of viewing things ,which is a big problem even in our real world,Joseph is not that different from Extreme Christian /Muslim groups that come with good intentions ,but in time dig into sadistic and inhuman practices...So that's why I say he's good because he ,unlike other ones,may sound like a possibility /threat that may exist in our world ,"the individual is supposed to be weak ,but far from powerless a single person has the potential to ruin the world" .

I recommend this game for everyone who wants to see this side of villany and to have fun ,because outside of the occasional glitches ,this game has content to keep you entertained ,from the sandbox open-world to the limitless maps form far cry arcade and co-op you will not get bored.

Far Cry 5 is a true masterpiece in the world of open-world gaming, seamlessly blending breathtaking landscapes, gripping storytelling, and adrenaline-pumping action into a gaming experience that leaves a lasting impression. Developed by Ubisoft, this installment in the series takes players on a wild journey to the heart of Montana, and it's nothing short of amazing.

From the very moment you step into Hope County, Montana, you're greeted with a visually stunning open world. Lush forests, snow-capped mountains, and vast lakes are brought to life with incredible attention to detail. The dynamic weather system and day-night cycle add an extra layer of immersion, making you feel like you're truly a part of this picturesque yet perilous slice of America.

The characters in Far Cry 5 are not only well-crafted but also memorable. The cult leader, Joseph Seed, is a chilling antagonist who'll send shivers down your spine. The local resistance fighters, each with their unique personalities, bring depth to the narrative. And Boomer, the loyal dog companion, quickly becomes a fan favorite for his unwavering loyalty.

The narrative is a rollercoaster ride of chaos and freedom. The game's plot explores themes of religious fanaticism and the consequences of unchecked power, making it a thought-provoking experience. Player choices and freedom of approach are at the core of Far Cry 5, allowing you to tackle missions and objectives in your unique style. The game gives you the liberty to play your way, and the consequences of your actions ripple throughout the open world.

Far Cry 5's gameplay is a thrilling fusion of explosive action, tactical combat, and vehicular mayhem. The vast arsenal of weapons and tools lets you customize your approach, whether you prefer stealth takedowns, all-out assaults, or creative explosions. Vehicles like planes, helicopters, and muscle cars are at your disposal, adding a sense of freedom and excitement to the open world.

The game's co-op mode is a standout feature, allowing you to team up with a friend and experience the chaos of Hope County together. The sense of camaraderie and shared adventures make it an unforgettable cooperative experience.

Ubisoft's commitment to post-launch support further enhances the Far Cry 5 experience. Regular updates, additional content, and an engaging map editor ensure that players have endless opportunities to explore and create within the game.

In conclusion, Far Cry 5 is a remarkable addition to the franchise, setting a new standard for open-world gaming. Its stunning visuals, captivating characters, gripping narrative, and diverse gameplay make it an unforgettable adventure. Whether you're a long-time fan of the series or a newcomer, this game is a must-play. Far Cry 5 is an incredible journey through the heart of chaos and freedom that will keep you enthralled from start to finish.

Anyone who still thinks FC3 is the best in the franchise but hasn't played this, really should give it a try. It makes 3 look like the dinosaur that it is, in every way. First of all, you actually get the wingsuit fairly early. Not 3/4 thru the story. The gunplay is very good, and the driving is also competent. Flying at first takes a bit of getting used to, but then again that may have just been me. I've played thru this at least 5 times, and even after all that I've had as much fun as I did the very first time. To me, that's the benchmark of a truly great game; and anymore it happens so rarely that I take note with each occurrence.

Now, it is an Ubisoft money-grab title, so wait for a sale (still $60 after five and a half years? Really?). The story, and even the map (while smaller) blow the doors off FC6. Grab this and re-live all that fun you remember you had when you played FC3 over a decade ago, but with better everything.

I liked Far Cry 1, but I loved Far Cry 2, 3, & 4.
This one struck the perfect balance between acknowledging what made the fans love the game from the previous installments while adding new features and mechanics without straying too far from the formula.

The Campaign is dark & intriguing, the characters are varied and interesting, and the co-op gameplay is excellent.

If you liked Far Cry 3 or 4, you'll like this one.
If you like story-rich games, you'll like this one.
If you like Open-World RPG-Lite games, you'll like this one.
If you like shooters with cars and planes, you'll like this one.

In short, you should take some time to play this great game!

Just when you start to have fun the game will constantly wrestle you into unskippable, unpausable, looooong cutscenes. The game is completely riddled with this poor design choice. It is so self-indulgent in telling its mediocre story and it gets in the way of enjoying the game from start to finish throughout the entire experience. Totally ruined it for me.

Also, the spawn rate of random enemies appearing and attacking you is way, wayyyy too high. The game offers an open world map with objectives to clear but you can't catch your breath for random groups of grunts constantly zeroing in on you and engaging with you. It's incredibly annoying.

It's a shame because there is a great game to be made here if they just stopped forcing you into unavoidable story events and calmed down with the enemy spawns. Those two things however are so oppressive that you cannot enjoy the game.

TL;DR, the game is good, but it exists in a world in which Far Cry 3 and 4 existed first, and Blood Dragon and Primal surpassed their origins.  Plot's janky, side quests range from meh to pretty good, guns are alright, driving's fun, but it's shackled to Ubisoft's insistence on using an inferior secondary community application.

SPOILERS BELOW:

This game really, REALLY wants you to care about its plot.  Like, the game insists that whatever gameplay thing you have chosen to do is no longer important once they feel like it's time to do plot.  A plot, mind you, that's deeply inaccurate in its intended message.  The whole point is supposed to be that "sometimes it's better to let go and walk away," knowing full well that not only is your character (as a police officer) OBLIGATED to interfere in service to the innocent citizens of Montana, but both you and the character are actively motivated by every facet of gameplay and plot to dive in headfirst and save lives.  This "message" is delivered by a man who: openly admits to killing his infant daughter in his arms; regularly commands the kidnapping, brainwashing, torture, and execution of innocent civilians; is implied to have forced himself upon one of his "apostles" and force-fed her powerful hallucinogens until she was addicted at the tender age of seventeen; doesn't know how to wear a shirt; and willfully wears a man-bun.  The line "not every problem can be solved by a bullet" leaves the mouth of a problem that can be solved with a bullet, and all you are allowed to do is suffer through myriad cutscenes that never would have happened because a sane man would have shot this guy by now.  Even during the end of the game, as you careen through burning forest, you can't turn around and Marvin this man as you SHOULD -- you willingly brought him along with you, for no reason?

The siblings are individually kind of cool, though.

END SPOILERS

The gunplay is Far Cry 3's gunplay, nothing crazy there -- though the shovel launcher is fun.  Movement, vehicular or manual, feels solid.  Game looks good, sounds good, and any time you're not interacting with its horrible Ubisoft-based multiplayer UI or its painfully counterintuitive and ham-fisted "plot," the game is fine.  Problem is, 3 and 4, as well as Blood Dragon and Primal, are RIGHT THERE.  If you're gonna get this one, get it on sale; otherwise, stick with the better games.

Game has beautiful Graphics, fun gun play, story is kinda meh, and the cut scenes / dialogue drag out too much. But the main drawback of this game is that it doesnt have TRUE multiplayer. Meaning that if you try to play with a friend, whoever isnt hosting will not get story progression, and will not get upgrade progression. 

Also it kinda drives the idea of being a looter game but has many instances where it prohibits you from looting. You are limited to how many of an item you can hold, but the game wont tell you what that limit is, or which items have hit that limit, further more, when you clear out a base, all of the bodies you killed disappear, so you cant loot them. 

Can be infuriating for those wanting the joy of loot, and the sheer amount of cut scenes does make me come and go from this game. The gun play is where this game shines, some of the best ive seen.

The Game of the Year (GOTY) and standard version are for the most part the exact same. GOTY has a couple more mission included as downloadable context (DLCs). If you want a solid experience of Far Cry 5, this would be the best version for you. Wait for it to go on sale as a deep discount, buy, download, install and enjoy the game.

NOTE FOR THOSE THAT HAVE UBISOFT CRASHING ISSUES: I've spent countless hours figuring out why my computer crashes with Ubisoft games including other FC games and AC series. I thought it was overheating, an under powered system, bad PSU, and so on. You may see Kernal-Power event 41 show up in Event Viewer after a crash. What I've found is that Adobe update, Dropbox Update, Razer Update, etc etc were the culprits. Any time a program updater would automatically launch, search for an update, or begin an update I would crash. Now. before every game I go to task manager and close all allowable updater programs (just the update background process). This has solved 99% of the problem with an occasional program triggering an update and crash. More often than not when you power back on and check task manager you'll see which updater restarted. Anyways, to the review.

I'd wholeheartedly recommend Far Cry 5 to anyone who likes beautiful, open-world games where you shoot stuff and blow things up.

Set in the absolutely gorgeous state of Montana, this game has some amazing scenery and some breathtaking graphics. The gunplay is improved from the previous installments. I appreciate the realistic touch of being able to switch from fully-automatic to semi-automatic for some of my guns.. Far Cry 5 also has an excellent gun variety, and an equally excellent attachment selection. Like the previous games, it has great sound design, as well as a good soundtrack full of 80s dad rock and gospel music to really immerse you into that rural Montana setting.

One of my favorite features of the game is the arcade. If you wanna take a break from the campaign for a bit, you can find an arcade cabinet or a poster, and play some custom maps made by developers and other players. You can play Bladerunner maps, fight in Egyptian pyraminds, hold out against zombies, or scale giant office towers. It adds a lot of uniqueness to the game, and makes it that much more engaging and worthwhile.

Like features that have been added, though, some have been removed. You still have the wingsuit and grappling hook, but takedowns are all different. There are no longer any manual healing animations, either, but they instead give you a slowly but fully-regenerating health bar, although you can expedite its process by using first aid kits. You also have more melee weapons, as opposed to a single blade, but they all function the same, though. It's just visual differences. You can also throw your melee weapons a short distance that instant-kills any human target it touches, which can make for some amusing kills. I'm sure a lot of people coming from 3 and 4 will greatly appreciate that there are no radio towers to scale in this game. Unfortunately, all guns still aren't unlocked at the beginning of the game. There are now no longer any hunting requirements to get bigger ammo pouches. You get bigger pouches through perks, and you gain those through completing challenges, rather than leveling up, compared to the previous games. Prices are also a pretty big difference in this game, too. Guns are more expensive, attachments are relatively realistically-priced, and you can buy vehicles and clothing as well. Cash isn't as easy to find in loot as in some of the other games, so they decided to make hunting the big money-earner this time around.

You can also go fishing.

And no sharks this time, so you don't have to have a mini heart attack every time you go swimming.

The story is good enough, but it is where most of the complaints about this game come from. It has multiple antagonists, but they aren't nearly as fun or as charismatic as Vaas or Pagan. They're all a little bland, really. Barely mildly interesting, and all of your special events involving them are only a little fun.

Is this game worth the full price? Maybe. I've found I got my money's worth, but I feel that this game has so much replayability, and so many features in it that contributes to its longevity that whether you pay twelve dollars, thirty dollars, or sixty, I think you'd have a good time regardless.

I'm in a toss up between recommending it, and not recommending it... But ultimately, it's the latter. The concept is fantastic, but the execution is horrible. The guns feel awful, their stats and performance make no sense (like shooting a deer in the head with a .45-70, and then it just takes off into the sunset at mach 2), the vehicles are atrociously bad - especially the helicopters and planes that max out at about 55mph, not to mention their horrendous handling and physics, the enemies are all cookie cutter copy/paste scenarios, once one enemy sees you they all know where you are and will shoot you through a forest while sprinting with laser precision... 

The game has a wide variety of side missions, most of which exist only to frustrate you, and don't really offer anything. Any time there was a mission where you had to "hunt" something, I didn't even bother after the first couple. Spoiler, the best hunting weapon in the game is an M60 because you have to shoot predator animals a ridiculous amount of times to kill them. I'm the kind of person who usually finishes EVERY side quest before finishing a main story line, but in this case, I found myself rushing through the main story just to get the game over with as quickly as possible.

Not to mention, it gets REALLY annoying having to go back to base to get a new helicopter every 3 minutes because some random civilian stole yours after you saved them - AGAIN.

The game is worth it, if it's on sale for about $5-10. Otherwise, save your money.

FIRST AN IMPORTANT FOREWORD:

This is a thumbs up for the game, yes, but there's is  a _glaring_ thumbs down area of the game and it's choice to deliver a story. And that is especially apparent in the Faith region. Taking control off the hands of the player, when you are trying for an immersive experience, is a very shitty way of doing things. And it happens.... A LOT... A HELLUVA LOT. After region(s) are liberated from the horrendous writing, things pick up for the better.

Short review:
It's a fun game, the mechanics are nice and it very well might be my favorite Far Cry gameplay, visuals and worldbuilding wise. I think "cult infested rural America" is a bold and fun idea after "exotic" locations and is very welcome. Give it a go, it's often nowadayhs on the cheap, including the DLC's (which I have not tested though). Get over the awful storytelling (please note, not awful story as such, just the way it's often told) and you are in for a solid treat.

Again. Not having control over your character while he is drugged, yeaah, I get how they are justifying it but boy is it arrogant, sloppy writing and a horrible character (when talking about faith). So speedrun the horrible character and story bit and then enjoy the game.

The world design is great with lots to do. Graphically it still looks awesome. The countryside is beautiful. The villains were great as is expected of a Far Cry game. Gameplay-wise it is quite different from Far Cry 4, There are less collectables which is great for completionists. The respawn & fast travel systems are further upgraded. There's lots of guns to suit the way you want to play.The greatest thing about the game though, is undoubtedly, the soundtrack. Dan Romer and the choir knocked it out of the park. I think it's one of the best soundtracks in the last 10 years.

While the villains are great, the protagonist is bland af. I didn't like the way they told the story and the ending is satisfying. I also didn't love the kidnapping mechanic in the 3 regions as I felt it affected the pacing of the story and reduced player freedom. 

The Arcade mode is bugged af and I get a lot of bookworm errors. An Ubi support is as helpful as you would expect. They didn't even reply to my support ticket and it's been two months.

It would be a 9/10 if the kidnapping mechanic was not present as It causes you to miss some main missions if you do too many side quests. Due to the 2 above issues, I removed 2 points from my rating.

7/10

Best one in the series, right next to FC3, but noticeably technically upgraded.
Realistic. Interesting dialogues and characters. Great addition with the roster of allies that can accompany the player.
Engine is bomb. Enemies' kills are visualised the best in the series (e.g. how they react to getting hit,  the blood spatter, ragdoll mechanics, realism of all that - not super realistic unfortunately - like with RDR2 or TLOU2 let's say - but it will certainly happily do) And enemies are not damage sponges even on hardest difficulty which is a plus (FC6 I'm looking at you). 
By default I turn off 'taggin' (seeing enemies through walls, cause that's just a ridiculous proposition) but apart from that great default settings.
Shame it was later followed by a new approach to the same subject with New Dawn where everything is sugar-coloured, octan-spray-paint candy sweet bulls***. And they seem to have changed engine or some solutions, in FC6 + it's not not the same thing, with crocodile allies, over the top acting with poor-writing dialogues, etc. 
FC5 has the most robust and beautiful engine in the series.
Great bow & slingshot mechanic and representation of the hits on enemies.

There is some glitch showing up when you play PS4 controller on steam (whereas some functions of cars and planes do not have a button assigned to them) but you just have to turn off steam input, restart the game, and it plays fine.

Overall though, would love if the series continued in this tone - more serious, realistic (some solutions are a bit OTT, but it's just on the line without crossing it overall), ...normal-colours-coloured... and with an option to play a bit more creatively.

The difficulty level even on the highest level is a bit easy at times. But if the Ubi solution for that would be bullet-sponge enemies then by all means, don't do it, just leave it as it is.

In the beginning God created the heaven and the earth.2 And the earth was without form, and void; and darkness was upon the face of the deep. And the Spirit of God moved upon the face of the waters.

3 And God said, Let there be light: and there was light.4 And God saw the light, that it was good: and God divided the light from the darkness.5 And God called the light Day, and the darkness he called Night. And the evening and the morning were the first day.

6 And God said, Let there be a firmament in the midst of the waters, and let it divide the waters from the waters.7 And God made the firmament, and divided the waters which were under the firmament from the waters which were above the firmament: and it was so.8 And God called the firmament Heaven. And the evening and the morning were the second day.

9 And God said, Let the waters under the heaven be gathered together unto one place, and let the dry land appear: and it was so.10 And God called the dry land Earth; and the gathering together of the waters called he Seas: and God saw that it was good.11 And God said, Let the earth bring forth grass, the herb yielding seed, and the fruit tree yielding fruit after his kind, whose seed is in itself, upon the earth: and it was so.12 And the earth brought forth grass, and herb yielding seed after his kind, and the tree yielding fruit, whose seed was in itself, after his kind: and God saw that it was good.13 And the evening and the morning were the third day.

14 And God said, Let there be lights in the firmament of the heaven to divide the day from the night; and let them be for signs, and for seasons, and for days, and years:15 And let them be for lights in the firmament of the heaven to give light upon the earth: and it was so.16 And God made two great lights; the greater light to rule the day, and the lesser light to rule the night: he made the stars also.17 And God set them in the firmament of the heaven to give light upon the earth,18 And to rule over the day and over the night, and to divide the light from the darkness: and God saw that it was good.19 And the evening and the morning were the fourth day.

20 And God said, Let the waters bring forth abundantly the moving creature that hath life, and fowl that may fly above the earth in the open firmament of heaven.21 And God created great whales, and every living creature that moveth, which the waters brought forth abundantly, after their kind, and every winged fowl after his kind: and God saw that it was good.22 And God blessed them, saying, Be fruitful, and multiply, and fill the waters in the seas, and let fowl multiply in the earth.23 And the evening and the morning were the fifth day.

24 And God said, Let the earth bring forth the living creature after his kind, cattle, and creeping thing, and beast of the earth after his kind: and it was so.25 And God made the beast of the earth after his kind, and cattle after their kind, and every thing that creepeth upon the earth after his kind: and God saw that it was good.

26 And God said, Let us make man in our image, after our likeness: and let them have dominion over the fish of the sea, and over the fowl of the air, and over the cattle, and over all the earth, and over every creeping thing that creepeth upon the earth.27 So God created man in his own image, in the image of God created he him; male and female created he them.28 And God blessed them, and God said unto them, Be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth, and subdue it: and have dominion over the fish of the sea, and over the fowl of the air, and over every living thing that moveth upon the earth.

29 And God said, Behold, I have given you every herb bearing seed, which is upon the face of all the earth, and every tree, in the which is the fruit of a tree yielding seed; to you it shall be for meat.30 And to every beast of the earth, and to every fowl of the air, and to every thing that creepeth upon the earth, wherein there is life, I have given every green herb for meat: and it was so.31 And God saw every thing that he had made, and, behold, it was very good. And the evening and the morning were the sixth day.21 Thus the heavens and the earth were finished, and all the host of them.2 And on the seventh day God ended his work which he had made; and he rested on the seventh day from all his work which he had made.3 And God blessed the seventh day, and sanctified it: because that in it he had rested from all his work which God created and made.

4 These are the generations of the heavens and of the earth when they were created, in the day that the Lord God made the earth and the heavens,5 And every plant of the field before it was in the earth, and every herb of the field before it grew: for the Lord God had not caused it to rain upon the earth, and there was not a man to till the ground.6 But there went up a mist from the earth, and watered the whole face of the ground.7 And the Lord God formed man of the dust of the ground, and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life; and man became a living soul.

8 And the Lord God planted a garden eastward in Eden; and there he put the man whom he had formed.9 And out of the ground made the Lord God to grow every tree that is pleasant to the sight, and good for food; the tree of life also in the midst of the garden, and the tree of knowledge of good and evil.10 And a river went out of Eden to water the garden; and from thence it was parted, and became into four heads.11 The name of the first is Pison: that is it which compasseth the whole land of Havilah, where there is gold;12 And the gold of that land is good: there is bdellium and the onyx stone.13 And the name of the second river is Gihon: the same is it that compasseth the whole land of Ethiopia.14 And the name of the third river is Hiddekel: that is it which goeth toward the east of Assyria. And the fourth river is Euphrates.15 And the Lord God took the man, and put him into the garden of Eden to dress it and to keep it.

16 And the Lord God commanded the man, saying, Of every tree of the garden thou mayest freely eat:17 But of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, thou shalt not eat of it: for in the day that thou eatest thereof thou shalt surely die.

18 And the Lord God said, It is not good that the man should be alone; I will make him an help meet for him.19 And out of the ground the Lord God formed every beast of the field, and every fowl of the air; and brought them unto Adam to see what he would call them: and whatsoever Adam called every living creature, that was the name thereof.20 And Adam gave names to all cattle, and to the fowl of the air, and to every beast of the field; but for Adam there was not found an help meet for him.

21 And the Lord God caused a deep sleep to fall upon Adam, and he slept: and he took one of his ribs, and closed up the flesh instead thereof;22 And the rib, which the Lord God had taken from man, made he a woman, and brought her unto the man.23 And Adam said, This is now bone of my bones, and flesh of my flesh: she shall be called Woman, because she was taken out of Man.24 Therefore shall a man leave his father and his mother, and shall cleave unto his wife: and they shall be one flesh.25 And they were both naked, the man and his wife, and were not ashamed.31 Now the serpent was more subtil than any beast of the field which the Lord God had made. And he said unto the woman, Yea, hath God said, Ye shall not eat of every tree of the garden?2 And the woman said unto the serpent, We may eat of the fruit of the trees of the garden:3 But of the fruit of the tree which is in the midst of the garden, God hath said, Ye shall not eat of it, neither shall ye touch it, lest ye die.4 And the serpent said unto the woman, Ye shall not surely die:5 For God doth know that in the day ye eat thereof, then your eyes shall be opened, and ye shall be as gods, knowing good and evil.

Personally, I love this game. I played over 300 hours on Xbox, and I got it again on sale for Steam. The aesthetics, shooting/fighting, driving, flying, and open world aspect is way more fun than it has any right to be, as well as the arcade that lets you build your own levels. I even found the DLC to be a lot of fun, as well. The ONLY real complaint I have is the abduction mechanic. Without spoiling anything, you get abducted by your enemies (a lot), and there is absolutely nothing you can do to stop it. Yes, it progresses the story, but it's still supremely annoying. You can be flying in a plane a mile off the ground with no enemies anywhere close to you, and you'll still somehow get taken. I'd love it if you could somehow avoid it, but it's only a minor inconvenience in an otherwise awesome game. Highly recommended. The Ubisoft Connect menu is annoying as well, but it's also a minor inconvenience.

Far Cry 5 - це захоплююча гра в жанрі відкритого світу, яка приносить свіжість інновацій до вже відомої серії Far Cry. З першого погляду гра вражає своєю деталізацією відкритого світу, відмінною графікою і фантастичними пейзажами штату Монтана, США.

Однією з ключових особливостей Far Cry 5 є свобода дій для гравця. Ви можете досліджувати великий відкритий світ, виконувати різні завдання і вибирати свій власний спосіб вирішення проблем. Неважливо, чи виберете ви великі стрімкі бої, розглядаєте таємниці гри в справжньому детективному стилі, чи ж берете на себе роль владика зла, ви завжди будете відчувати себе вільним.

Гра також славиться своєю багатошаровістю та глибиною персонажів. У вас буде можливість спілкуватися з різними персонажами, вивчати їхні історії та долі, і це додасть велику глибину іммерсії до гри.

Боротьба з культом "Врятувати Надію" - це захоплююча пригода, яка спрямована на вивчення тем сучасного суспільства, релігійних вірувань і влади. Сюжет гри завжди тримає вас в напруженні, а вибори, які ви робите, впливають на подальший хід подій.

Технічно гра також вражає: графіка на високому рівні, реалістична фізика і динамічна система погоди створюють неймовірно живий світ.

Загалом, Far Cry 5 - це гра, яка точно варта уваги. Вона поєднує захоплюючий сюжет, неймовірно відкритий світ, багато різноманітних можливостей для гравця та глибокий сюжет. Ця гра точно заслуговує на місце в вашій колекції, якщо ви шануєте ігри в жанрі відкритого світу і шутери від першої особи.

Purchased it on sale for $8. Bought a copy for my son as well. Seamless CO-OP Story mode gameplay. Butter smooth graphics on an LG OLED @4k+HDR with all settings on Ultra, average of 180+fps on a 5090 rtx (not a typo) +13900k (of course) but my son plays on a 3060ti rtx +9900k and gets 90fps average @ 1440p everything on ultra. 

Entire game probably has around 40-60 hours of gameplay if you are aiming for 100% completion. You can easily beat it in 20-30 hours if you only pursue the main story quests. 

We set the game difficulty to "hard", as it is the highest difficulty setting, but hard is not difficult if you're decent at FPS games. 

There are no Steam achievements for this game. That is either a big plus or a big minus for some people. There are Steam trading cards though, so you will still get Steam XP for completing the game. 

On sale for less than $10, this game is solid purchase.

This game is on a technical level a decent open world shooter hodgepodge with stuff that works for me and stuff that's definitely superfluous (A relaxing fishing trip during an all out civil war where civilians get slaughtered left an right? Sure!). What's atrocious about it is the extremely badly written story. The plotting is so forced and ridiculous, it is basically "Shoehorning: The Game". You know those cheesy old action tv series where the heroes get kidnapped by the baddies every time and always manage to escape after listening to the bad guy explaining his plans? This is basically the main story gimmick in this game, and it happens A LOT. Like, a dozen times or more. Endlessly rambling monologues by the evil dudes about their clichéd worldview that really make you appreciate the skip button after a while. Which is a shame because I think the voice actors are doing a very good job with the abysmal material they are given, but it's just so pointless and uninteresting, and nothing has any consequence. Then there is the fact that you have basically no agency whatsoever. I don't understand why they made this an open world title since you are so heavily railroaded and often deprived of choice, I seriously think this story would work much better as a linear shooter (apart from the out-of-nowhere ending that is just ridiculously stupid und illogical). It really feels as if it was a linear concept before being retooled into a Far Cry title. The plotting and gameplay mechanics get more and more annoying and ridiculous during the progression of the main story, at the end I just felt insulted on an intellectual level. Some missions and activities are over-the-top GTA-like fun, others are so serious and pretentious, it gives you extreme mood whipIash. If you want to make a silly shooter, go wild and crazy, but don't pretend that you are telling some kind of oscar-worthy story with real emotional stakes by wasting the time and talent of good actors. There are also some really disturbing undertones in the storytelling where I'm not really sure if the developers see the murderous cultist leaders as the evil guys or as admirable antiheroes?! The civilian NPCs get slaughtered and their corpses are defiled left and right, but every single one of the main bad guys gets their dying monologue that is set up like an honorable warriors death. It's so heavyhanded and questionable. 
In conclusion: It is a somewhat fun sandbox shooter that you can enjoy if you have nothing better to play, but if you are looking for decent storytelling or coherent worldbuilding, don't bother. I'm really glad that I didn't pay full price for this.

EDIT:  5 years later and I am still pissed at this game every time I see it come up on sale.  I have plated all of the Far Cry games and this one is by far the only one I actually hate and wish I never wasted money one.

No chatboxes for multiplayer?  Uh, why?  I'm seeing more games doing this, while making microphone communication the only in-game communication method.  Why?  There's nothing edgy or forward-thinking about doing away with something that should have a permanent place in anything multiplayer -- save for very unique circumstances.  No, using the Steam or Ubisoft overlay chat isn't good enough, and is frankly a hassle compared to being able to chat in-game.  

I did quite enjoyed playing this game with my brother on the co-op campaign, despite so-so writing and unlikeable characters (except for the main villain with the glasses, he was cool), but we're both in a state of disbelief that players with various reasons for wanting good, old-fashioned text chatting -- ie deaf people, or people who need to communicate quietly, or even just people who don't feel like talking on the mic -- are being given the middle finger.  Techland and a couple others do this as well, and I won't buy anymore of their multiplayer games, nor will I buy anymore multiplayer games from Ubisoft if they keep basically telling LOTS of us who pay good money for their games to go fuck themselves.  

One might say or think that mic-only communication is the future of gaming, but that's a VERY difficult concept to understand when players should be given a choice.  And yes, it needs to be in-game.  No overlays or third party programs.  Just simply chat box communication.   

Now, let's see some fake dev from Ubisoft respond generically in a tone that basically tells me to go read their Q&A or troubleshooting section -- which is basically their way of telling yet another paid customer to take my thoughts and shove them where the sun don't shine.  Companies that shit on customers long enough eventually get what's coming to them.

[b]7.5/10[/b]

Compared to previous Far Cry games, the story falls short of expectations, with a disappointing ending (Jacob had the best story, and I wish he was the main antagonist of the game).

The crafting system is weak and mainly focused on throwables, the once-rewarding hunting for crafting improvements isn't worth it anymore, and the perk system lacks rewards found in earlier games of the series (you only need the grapple hook, parachute, and the wingsuit). 

I recommend playing Far Cry 5, but I can't justify giving it a positive review as it fails to capture the full Far Cry experience.

This game saved my life.

I am 33.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.
After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Title: A Thrilling, Unpredictable Masterpiece - My Review of "Far Cry 5"

In the realm of open-world gaming, Ubisoft has continually pushed boundaries and crafted unforgettable experiences. "Far Cry 5", released in 2018, stands as a testament to their commitment to delivering immersive, sandbox adventures that leave players breathless. This review delves into the dark and twisted world of Hope County, Montana, where cultists, chaos, and carnage reign supreme.

"Far Cry 5's" setting is nothing short of spectacular. Hope County, a rural Montana landscape, is both beautifully picturesque and eerily unsettling. The serene wilderness juxtaposed with a cult's iron grip creates an atmosphere that's brimming with tension. Ubisoft has succeeded in crafting a believable and captivating open-world playground.

The narrative, revolving around the extremist religious cult known as the "Project at Eden's Gate," is both timely and disturbing. "Far Cry 5" pulls no punches in exploring themes of fanaticism, indoctrination, and the corruption of power. Players find themselves in the shoes of a silent protagonist, Deputy Sheriff Rook, sent to arrest the cult's leader, Joseph Seed. From there, the story spirals into a chaotic odyssey of resistance, making players question their own moral compass in the process.

"Far Cry 5" boasts a diverse cast of characters, each with their own motivations, quirks, and flaws. The "Guns for Hire" system lets you recruit unique allies, adding an extra layer of strategy to game-play. Whether it's the charismatic preacher Jerome, the explosives expert Nick Rye, or the enigmatic "Hurk," each companion brings a fresh dynamic to combat and story progression.

But it's the villains who steal the show. Joseph Seed, along with his heralds, are some of the most memorable antagonists in gaming history. Their fanatical devotion and unnerving charm leave a lasting impression, making every encounter with them a tense and unforgettable experience.

"Far Cry 5's" game-play is where it truly shines. The open-world sandbox is your canvas for chaos, and the freedom it offers is staggering. Want to liberate an outpost with stealthy precision? Go for it. Prefer to ride in guns blazing with a bear by your side? The choice is yours. The game's dynamic AI and responsive gun-play create countless opportunities for emergent game-play moments.

The arsenal of weapons and vehicles is diverse, catering to different play-styles. The progression system, tied to challenges and exploration, encourages you to experiment and adapt to various situations. The game also introduces the "Fangs for Hire," allowing you to recruit animals like bears and cougars as allies, adding an extra layer of strategy.

"Far Cry 5" is quite a visual marvel too. The attention to detail in Hope County's environments, from the lush forests to the foreboding cult compounds, is breathtaking. Dynamic weather, day-night cycles, and the use of the Dunia Engine create a world that feels alive and ever-changing.

Sound design is equally exceptional. The haunting hymns of the cultists and the roar of wildlife in the wilderness immerse players in the game's world. Voice acting is top-notch, with Joseph Seed's performance being particularly chilling.

In conclusion, "Far Cry 5" is a masterclass in open-world gaming, blending a gripping narrative with explosive game-play. It delves into disturbing themes while offering players an unparalleled level of freedom and immersion. Its compelling characters, unforgettable villains, and stunning world make it a must-play for any gaming enthusiast. In it's chaotic realm of Hope County, Montana, your choices matter, and the line between hero and villain blurs. "Far Cry 5" is not just your everyday Ubisoft game; it's an unforgettable journey into madness that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

It is a Ubisoft sandbox game. Most folks are going to know if they like that style of game or not by now, but here is what you expect.

Linear Narrative - very little ability to truly influence the outcome
Open Play Space and Style  - You choose where to go, who to fight, and when
Progression is King - Ubisoft is all about the collectibles, unlocks, and the steady drip of powerups

Bottom line I find Far Cry 5 to be a great casual shooter I could drop in for a few hours clear a few missions after work, and slowly chip away at the Seed Family. Weapons Felt good, characters were fun, narrative was a bit overworked but interesting, and When you just want to blow stuff up hop in an attack chopper and go to town.

I'm not quite sure how I feel about this game. I wish there was a medium review, but there's not. So I'll just say that it was all right, it was intriguing enough that I wanted to finish it, and that I don't think I'll be playing it again.

Why is there air to air combat in this game?  I don't want to dogfight with your POS flying system, and I definitely don't want to have to shoot down an enemy fighter plane that requires roughly 200 bullets to bring down.  This would suck less if my plane's machine guns didn't overheat after 3 seconds of continuous fire.  This is not a good "boss battle" and the designers should have realized it miles ahead of actually putting it in the game.

Also don't love the amount of ground-to-air combat I'm expected to fulfill while just trying to navigate the map, especially given the lack of proper AA in this game. Maybe the designers felt a need to replace the intense frustration of eagle attacks from FC4 with this fresh new hell from above?

Another thing: either let me craft med kits or make them a lot more prevalent.  Why is this game so stingy with health?  It would be less frustrating if we still had the "freebie" healing like in previous games, e.g. pulling shrapnel out of our forearms or resetting broken hands.  Instead these fights feel a lot like COD with me needing to just cower and hide while I hope my dog doesn't get blown away (he often does).

"Just buy more health kits" they're fairly expensive and I run out of money restocking them, kind of a lot.  "Just hunt to collect skins to sell" NO.  There's a cult enacting a secession that for some reason isn't being responded to by every element of the US army within 1000 miles, I want to shoot religious lunatics in the face not stalk animals with a bow that requires multiple hits to get the job done.

I just love Fry Cry games. I always imagine myself as a insane lone wolf colonizer. I enter a territory and I must explore these lands to conquer. The game has it's story, but every Far Cry game is waging another campaign to increase my power.......... as a "good" guy.

The real fun of this game is the insanity the game throws at you. A lot of times I don't get angry that I died; the usual response is amazement in the escalation of things. It's fun to get attacked by a wild animal in the road, then have a car with crazy goons stop to shoot at you, escalate to multiple cars into a bigger fire fight, and then finally get taken out while running for dear life from an airplane. Few games touch the level of insane random fun as the Fry Cry games.

Far Cry 5 is the fifth installment in the franchise, and one of the first far cry games to overhaul the progression system. instead of just doing a story mission to progress, FC5 uses multiple story missions, multiple characters, and takes advantages of its open world by being able to liberate outposts, small or big and can also go towards your main story progression. Its sort of like just cause 3, just less explosions and more outposts.
Far Cry 5 is a title many should play, because of its interesting villains and their unique identities make the game a whole lot more interesting and more compelling to play. you play as a rookie saving regions from each of the seed children and confronting joseph seed in the end. Its such a great idea and makes it more interesting by adding 3 more villains you can meet, kill and learn.
I like this game, but theres definitely some improvements that can be made to FC5, one of it are the "get meat/skin undamaged" missions that could be a huge issue and halt your progress by a TON. the companions are really useless, i played through most of this game without one because while companions can fight, for some reason they wont revive me unless on special occassions, it drove me to insanity.
this is the best Far Cry game out there you can play, possibly better than Far Cry 3.
