This game was a mess. The short version is I don't regret buying/playing it, but there's a lot to dislike about it.

Pros:
The map looks great
Coop is better than the previous games as you can stay together the entire time after the tutorial
The setting was believable, an religious extremes militia as an enemy seems plausible to me
Having 2 recruit slots lets you play coop and still have a gun/fang for hire which we found pretty enjoyable
Gunplay and stealth are fun
The stashes were an interesting way to get upgrades

Neutral:
Balance is completely scuffed in this game. Some guns are locked behind progress with map completion, but there are prestige and dlc weapons that have the same stats as locked guns that are available from the start, and some have bloated stats like the mars pistol with max power and accuracy with infinite ammo.
Adding the ability to order vehicles was a nice touch, but the vehicles without weapons are pointless, and the ones with weapons are also unbalanced. The enemy seems to have no counter for helicopters with guns/missiles and you could easily clear most open world content with those.
There are vestigial things from previous games, in FC3+4 hunting was used to upgrade your storage space, in this game storage space upgrades are a perk, hunting is still there but only for selling the skins for money, and in typical far cry fashion once you get a set of weapons you like there's very little to spend money on aside from refilling ammo.
Crafting as a whole is just tacked on in this game, you can craft some explosives and the boosting drugs (oddly the pipe bomb isn't craftable despite being a notoriously home brewed weapon) but this just adds steps, just let us loot the consumables directly and not bother with the extra clicking.
They changed the health system for the worse in this game too, in previous games you had multiple health bar segments and if they got too low you could use a weak heal that came with a rather impractical field wound treatment. In this game you have one bar and it regenerates if you go long enough without being hit, this really makes things slow down and isn't the best. There are medkits to heal instantly but I was constantly flipping between having 0 of them when needed, and being full so I couldn't pick up what I found.
Another far cry reoccurring issue is once you've captured enough outposts the map feels too safe, in the start you have to fight your way everywhere but towards the end you'll hardly see enemies anywhere and it'll just be a lot of traversing empty space to get to the next fight.

Cons:
Microtransactions in a single player/coop game is such a slap to the face, what could that possibly add to the game?
Animals are super spongy for some reason, it shouldn't take half an LMG clip to take down a single bear especially when it's only for money. This is really bad for the judges since they'll mess up your stealth attempts because you can't kill them in one shot and they'll alert everyone.
The story is flat out garbage, rather than organically give you the story you end up getting kidnapped 3 times by each of the 3 leaders. These involve fights but are ultimately unavoidable and they happen no matter what you're doing so saving a hostage on your way to an outpost may put you over the edge starting the kidnap and then ending with you on the other side of the map from where you wanted to be. The kidnappings makes suspension of disbelief impossible since it's so ridiculous that you'd have survived all of that. Additionally the cult feels disjointed, one leader just wants to torture people, another is converting people by force with drugs, and the 3rd is conditioning people and killing those he deems weak. These are all so counter to each other that it's hard to tell what they're goal even is. The ending shows that they were preparing for the end of days but that doesn't make sense that they'd be culling people who'd have died anyways. They seem to try for a "maybe Joseph was right all along" ending but it literally doesn't matter, you can't let the moral of the story be to let a militant cult that is forcing people under their rule do as they please. The cutscenes are all in direct address as well, with your character willingly getting way to close to these people and letting them monologue endlessly even as they're dying. 
The boss fights are super unsatisfying, 3 of them take place in an altered state so it doesn't even feel like you're really fighting them. The one that doesn't ends up taking place in a dogfight with an airplane. They're all so anticlimactic it feels like you just drifted off for a bit and come back to them being suddenly bleeding out.
The story also has some seriously predictable parts, like when you're conditioned by Jacob to kill Eli. Just like FC4 this is so frustrating, seeing the rake from miles away but still being forced to step on it. It's even a mission to save someone who's being programmed by Jacob so they KNOW the programming exists but just decide not to deprogram you despite being captured 3 times and apparently missing for days.
Lastly the bugs, several times missions refused to progress, some wouldn't spawn the necessary items/people, others wouldn't register our progress to go to the next step. We had one cutscene drop down to 2-3 fps for some reason and the audio desynced. The wingsuit refused to open almost half the time, a few times using the parachute made me fall faster. Despite being the stealth fang for hire we had peaches just walk into the open and stand there until enemies spotted her. Sometimes bullet hits wouldn't register (more a problem for the coop partner) and I'm not sure if it's a bug but a few enemies seem to be able to survive headshots even though they don't have any armor/helmet.
good

Far Cry 5 is a game that aim at many targets but hits none. Above all it's a mess of good ideas mixed together to create below mediocre experience. Map itself is beautiful but also very "artifiicial" in a sense - it has no reason to it, no flow whatsoever - just a bunch of fields and forests with "content" sprinkle around it. It would be decent for a farming sim, or a game with much more hardcore aim - but in arcade'y farcry it's just "small" and pointless. Combat is horrible both when it comes to weapon handling that simply isn't fun, and when it comes to brain dead enemies that behave like a hive of morons rushing you all the time. 
Identity crisis that this game suffers from is even more obvious when you look at the survival aspects (crafting, healing items and so on) that are contradicted by fast and chaotic combat. I've tried for many hours, even modding the game with resistance mod that allows to iron out few issues but the core gameplay is just never really that fun to begin with.
I much MUCH prefer recent Ghost Recon games when it comes to open world action - they are both highly customisable, both have much better maps and outposts leagues above far cry 5 offering, both are better as action games and as hardcore titles - all depending on your settings (and with FPP mod for Wildlands you even get decent first person experience, which allows to enjoy map craftmanship that the team behind it clearly possesed).
If you are looking for decent (or more decent) far cry experience FC3 is much more streamlined and does not suffer from before mentioned identity crisis nearly as much, same goes for FC4. And if you don't care about open world but you like fpp stealth, and exploration i would highly encourage to try Sniper Ghost Warrior Contracts 1 and 2 (SGW 3 has open world in classic sense, and is really good on highest difficulty, but the world, although beautifully crafted, is even more lifeless than the one presented here).
WTF climax?

I've got it on sale cause I had never played any Far Cry game before, and I'm amazed. I love the fact that you're not forced to do all of the MAIN missions and that the order of completing them is primarily up to you. I think that's just the Far Cry formula, but it works here very well.

It's also nice that most activities that involve combat can be done in either a super stealthy way - including bows, throwing knives, suppressors, long scopes, and remote explosives - or in a RAMBO way (preferred by me) which includes choppers, planes, armored trucks, RPGs, choppers, guided missiles, grenades, molotovs, flamethrowers, and choppers. Oh, and you can also have up to 2 companions among whom there is a dude piloting a plane, and a lady piloting A MOTHER**CKING CHOPPER. I can tell you that such an air fleet (including you in the chopper obviously) can be a meaningful addition to the resistance.

All in all, there is a lot of action-driven fun packed in Far Cry 5 and it's hard to keep track of the passing hours. Of course, it gets repetitive after some time (like most Ubisoft games) but after ~24 hours of playtime, I haven't found it annoying yet. I recommend grabbing it on sale with all the DLCs included - that way you can also get a VIETNAM CHOPPER in the main campaign as soon as you get to your first chopper shop (and it's free).
Bad game, terrible story, very buggy, not satisfied with it, only fun part was messing with the broken mechanics. Would not recommend.

Came back for my third playthough after the huge disappointment  of Far Cry 6. This game isn't flawless by any means, but I think they nailed one of the most important things to me. I actually care about what's happening in Hope County and the fate of the people who live there. Your character isn't voice acted, but it doesn't matter that much (it certainly didn't do much in FC6). The people you meet during your adventures makes up for it. The story is a little over the top at times, but it's engaging. The music is also amazing, which adds another layer to the overall ambiance and feel of the game.

There are plenty of ways to play, whether you like the stealthy approach, or just run in guns blazing. Some enemies are bullet sponges and the AI is questionable at times, but it doesn't impact the overall experience too much.
The resistance points you need to farm to progress each zone and advance the story might feel a bit grindy to some, but you get most of it by simply playing the game normally. 


The same can be said for skill points, but again most of it is obtained by just playing the game and exploring the map. I never felt like I had to farm the same stuff over and over, which was the case with Outpost re-capping in Far Cry New Dawn.

One of the things I am not a big fan of is the scripted progression in each zone once you reach certain resistance levels. Even if you're not on an active story mission, hitting a certain level of the resistance will trigger an event where you get removed from whatever it is you were doing. It's a minor annoyance, but I would have preferred to decide myself when to advance the story.

Overally though I think Far Cry 5 strikes a great balance where there is a lot of stuff to do, but you don't really have to if you just care about the main story. I wouldn't buy a 5 year old game for 60$, but it's fairly often on sale at 50% discount or more.

Great game. Played through most story missions and some side missions which took about 40 hours. The graphics are great, the story is entertaining and impactful. 

The ambience of the game is very engaging, it's clear a lot of care was put into building the environments and the sound design added to this a lot. 

Gunplay was pretty fun, the odd bug here or there but nothing inexcusable. A great variety of weapons. Stealth can be difficult at times early on, but not too hard. In the late game with the right perks you can run and slide about enemy outposts clearing them without getting detected which is also fun. 

This is an arcade-y game and it's not afraid to lean into that at times with some crazy sequences, at the same time it can get real with some quite hard hitting story moments.

The last act provides an interesting choice on what you do with the main antagonist which adds some weight to the ending depending on which choice you make. 

All in all, great game. HOWEVER, I do have to deduct a point because the dog can't ride in the car with you.

9/10 highly recommend

Worst Far Cry I ever played.
Pros:
- Mechanically the best so far
- Good ideas
- Whole world open from start, no enemy scaling
Cons:
- Story
- Writing
- Silent Protagonist, especially in scenes where it doesn't make sense for him to don't speak
- Butchered tutorials ( I had to look up on internet how to do Sidearm Takedowns)
- Stupid Ai both enemy and allies
- Your sidekicks comment constantly and it's annoying. They yell even if you are currently sneaking
- To kill any of 3 lieutenants you have to be kidnapped by them 3 times (9 in total!!!). Each time you somehow escape or are released becasue Main Bad Guy "Got a Plan for You", even at the last kidnapping, only for him to throw a tantrum and say maybe he was wrong about MC after you kill his last lieutenant.
- Villain is a self rightoues hipocrite "that is right in the end"
- If you do too much side content in one area, then game locks you out of some missions without warning.
- Ending out of left field with no foreshadowing (or bad and minimal foreshadowing, that is contradicted many times) that only serves as an excuse for New Dawn and is made non-canon because of Far Cry 6
Overall if you don't care about story and characters at all and can tune out whenever cutscene plays and only want to play for shooting and fun it's for you. Otherwise don't bother.

WARNING: SPOILERS AHEAD

Far Cry 5 takes place in my home state, and though they got the environments right, it's stereotyped to hell... but what Far Cry game hasn't been?
Far Cry 5 takes place in Hope County (which doesn't exist. It's fictional) which has been taken over by a fanatical cult that totally isn't a bargain-bin Branch Davidian Cult. In this installment you must take the steps to dismantle this cult, which is known as The Project at Eden's Gate, to free Hope County from their tyrannical preachy clutches... because there was absolutely no military response... for reasons that make no sense.

So why am I recommending this? Because it's fun to play. DON'T PLAY IT FOR THE STORY, YOU WILL BE DISAPPOINTED!!!

Pros:
- Fun Gameplay
- Beautiful Environment
- There are helicopters and planes now
- Fun with Friends (If Ubisoft's software will actually work)
- Arcade is pretty fun

Cons:
- Map is small compared to 3, 4, and 6.
- The story is subpar and it's endings invalidate everything that happened in the entire game. And there was so much wasted potential with it.
- Enemy Variety hasn't changed except for adding the Angels which are the easiest things to fight.
- Though the gameplay is fun, it's not really different from 3 and 4.
- Multiplayer might break, because Ubisoft Connect is always going critical somehow.


 ~5/10 - The ending ins't real. It's just a hallucination caused by the Bliss.

Another good addition to the Far Cry series .

Far Cry 5 is a whirlwind of explosive action, captivating storytelling, and a vast open world that beckons to be explored. From the moment I stepped into the fictional Hope County, Montana, I was immersed in a world teeming with unpredictable danger and unexpected charm.

Immersive Open World:

The game's meticulously crafted open world is a playground of diverse landscapes, from lush forests to serene lakeshores and towering mountains. Every corner hides a new adventure, whether it's encountering a dangerous cult, rescuing a civilian, or stumbling upon hidden treasures that add a layer of depth to the experience.

Dynamic Gameplay:

Far Cry 5's gameplay is an adrenaline-fueled rollercoaster ride. From liberating outposts with explosive finesse to taking on ferocious wildlife, every encounter offers a unique challenge. The freedom to approach situations with an array of weapons, vehicles, and tactics keeps the gameplay fresh and exciting.

Compelling Characters and Story:

The game's charismatic characters and gripping storyline kept me invested in the battle against the menacing cult led by Joseph Seed. The blend of dark themes and unexpected humor created a narrative that was both engaging and memorable.

Co-op Chaos:

The addition of co-op play introduced a whole new dimension of chaos and camaraderie. Joining forces with a friend to take down cultists, wreak havoc, or explore the vast world added an extra layer of enjoyment that made the experience even more immersive.

Stunning Visuals:

Far Cry 5's attention to detail is evident in its stunning visuals. From the realistic lighting and weather effects to the meticulously designed environments, the game's aesthetics contribute to the sense of immersion, making every moment feel like a cinematic adventure.

Conclusion: A Wild Ride in Big Sky Country

Far Cry 5 is a wild ride that encapsulates the essence of both action-packed gameplay and captivating storytelling. The dynamic world, intriguing characters, and explosive encounters all contribute to an experience that's both thrilling and unforgettable. As I battled against the cult and forged my own path in the untamed Montana wilderness, I couldn't help but be swept away by the exhilarating journey that Far Cry 5 offered.

This game is similar to Just Cause 3 but with a more detailed and nuanced world for the player to inhabit and explore. It has a wonderful array of activities and content that will keep anyone looking for a more "tactical" approach to a "turn your mind off" FPS. THIS IS THE AC4: BLACK FLAG FOR THE FAR CRY SERIES.... not the most plot heavy title and it can get lost in its own sauce... but you get to be a Montana Cowboy Vigilante Angel of Vengeance and Wrath! its fucking fun, and the world is absolutely gorgeous...... but then then comes the rub. 

1. UBISOFT EXISTS..... and thus a game can not simply be fun. The one credit i will give them is that everything i have wanted to have, i have been able to obtain with the currency of the game and not my own... and that it. These Trash Baskets continue to force you to abandon steam and use their RAM hogging, under developed, and bloated excuse of an extension.... it is needless and has only proven to be a waste of my time and a shockingly significant hurdle between me AND A GAME I ALREADY FUCKING PAYED FOR!!!! Shit will full ass make you sign in every time regardless of any options you choose, and will add a good 3 minutes to the games acceptable boot-up time. also they might just delete your account for not playing the game every fucking day...

2. The god forsaken shoe-horned story that feels like one writers failed and utterly pedantic attempt at trying to over force a basic and tired philosophy on the player, and then act like its the first new philosophical thought since Plato. Now lets be clear, the basic story beats and the atmosphere its creates are great... the intro and starting island are near flawless bangers that get you rock solid for a story that will never actually manifest.... instead you will be forced into encounters against you will, having all player agency taken away from you as though you are some petulant child for daring to explore the world. The vibe and tone will remain very good and it does a good job of making you care for the "good guys' and the over world as a whole.... but all of the forced interactions with the Cult are an experiment in great concept.. that never materializes... which will all lead to one of the worst endings i have seen in gaming... its like getting high with a sophomore psych student who thinks that 9 credit hours have formed them into this paragon of metaphysical knowledge and wisdom...and instead of engaging with you as a player and purchaser of this game, they force you to listen to another philosophy 101 lecture from a strung out junkie and then take all the stake and reason behind the game up until this point and metaphorically wipe their dysentery riddle ass with it. 

So the brass tax is this

It is a solid 8.5/10 open world fps that has polished what it knows and even tries some new shit... nothing revolutionary, but very satisfying nonetheless. It has a gripping and fascinating world that is simply not given the due it deserves from the actual scripted story, but the companions and inhabitants make up for it with some absolutely fire dialogue and banter. This game will be a fun thrill ride of near 50hrs of content that will come at the price of a roughly 3 hours philosophy 101 lecture dispersed throughout, a truly unsatisfying ending..... and at the end of the day.... it is another fun game that comes at the cost of being made by fucking Ubisoft. 

All in all, i would put it on par with AC4 and Watch Dogs 2... fun and engaging, but is another ubisoft game that forces its story on you regardless of your feelings on the matter. 

DISCLAIMER: i have never played Arcade. i have literally zero - 1 interest in the concept, so none of the above apllies to it in any way shape or form..... pretty fun co-op though, if you can get past the Ubisoft client.

It's the same old un-inventive combat you're used to from Far Cry with a story that is deeply unsatisfying to play through. The cult is unabashedly evil, you can scourge them from the earth, but you'll still lose in cutscenes where bosses spout trite, nonsensical monologues only for you to escape captivity for the eighth time once again. Having agency in gameplay, but absolutely zero agency when it comes to the story just makes for a bad experience. It left me feeling like none of what I did as the player ever really mattered. Seriously, what did I play through the game for? Was it the combat? Not really, that's so run of the mill that it puts me to sleep. The story? It sucks. I'd skip this in favor of Far Cry 3 or 4. It may have some of the same issues this game had, but they were at least done better than this. I'm not even mentioning the numerous game breaking glitches and bugs I encountered throughout my playthrough, like losing the ability to reverse vehicles, or getting locked into one of the frustratingly slow drugged out sequences, or how spastic and uncanny valley the animations in this game are.

This review follows my first play through. Having been a fan of the far cry series since the good old playstation 3 era I can safely say I was not disappointed. Despite being late to play this game I still found it enjoyable knowing the "Twist" at the end that the car radios not so subtly hint at, Far Cry 5 is a delightful adventure with whats surprisingly a respectable display of cultism using Christian myth and misinterpretations.

Do not expect side stories (apart from the Rye Family one) to be engaging and memorable, expect however fun gunplay and interesting story telling when you spend the time chatting with who you have saved. 
The game does rush you through the areas as most ubisoft games do, climb a tower shoot a red thing blah blah blah but game is under 30 hours so getting it on sale promises to give you your money's worth.

Three and a half years and it still has game-breaking bugs where it crashes every five minutes and you get something called the granite-2000 error which corrupts your save files and its a bitch of a workaround to resolve. Beautiful, fun (when you can play), but Christ if it isn't riddled with more bugs than a bad-guy's truck after drum/mag-dumping an M60.

I've just finished this game and the feelings are... quite mixed, I would say. However, it's more of a "No", then "Yes"

Pros : 
- The story is pretty interesting, as well as the endings that could leave you flabbergasted for a long time
- The guns have their own behaviour and impact and they don't feel like clones
- The variety of random situations you can stumble upon

Cons : 
- VERY outdated and primitive game design. The devs fantasy is sufficient for 2 things only : spawning the hordes of enemies after every little action made and triggering the story events. It can seem to be fun in the beginning, but only makes one annoyed and angry when repeated for a hundred times
- Dependancy on microtransactions. Like buying an in-game currency for a single player game, really?
- The freedom of choice in this game is nothing, but a simple illusion. You're not keen on hunting? You won't be able to make money then. Some of the tasks imply endless scouting for resources (which is boring), some make you fish/hunt/do stunts/get involved in the activities you don't really want to do, but some of them can be easily avoided. The key word here is SOME and it does make the game annoying
- Very stupid companion AI. Blocking the path, running straight into the danger and whatnot
- Boss fights. This is not what you expect from a AAA-game (no spoilers allowed, so I won't say much here. Just don't expect too much from them).

This was a great story and definitely not a waste of time, however, this is the most annoying game I've completed for a couple of years so far. And even the variety of activities doesn't make it better.

4/10.

I actually had quite an enjoyable with Far Cry 5, its gameplay was fairly simple but entertaining. This goes the same for the story, while there wasn't much depth to its narrative and characters, it was still entertaining enough to get by, that is until.... The ending

So you just spent around 20 hours apposing some lunatic cult that's prophesying the end of the world, you spend all game think Joseph is a lying fuck who just uses the whole religious angle as an excuse for his misdeeds, but the ending reveals that he was right and the world fucking ends. This completely makes everything done before this moment obsolete, all the areas you cleared, every side quest you did, every main quest, means fucking nothing. 

So in conclusion, if you buy this game, don't complete it.

[b]FAR CRY 5 BASE GAME[/b]

Honestly, just a really fun game that you can really just get into without much worry, with a lot of "video game logic" and arcade-like features to make it feel like your a one man army and a lot of extra stuff to make the game world feel alive and unique. That is about how I would sum Far Cry 5 up in one sentence.

But to be a bit more in-depth, here is my reasons on what makes Far Cry such a great game.

The wit and character of everything in the game. Nearly each individual mission, prepper stash and side quest is packed full of wit and character, from the environmental storytelling in the prepper stash missions to the crazy and downright insane NPC side characters. The main story is also pretty decent as well, striking a nice balance between an information overload and no story at all, unlike the COD games where it is 99% gun pew pew and 1% story. The 3 endings are all pretty cool and also pretty fucked up at the same time, but they all leave you with a sense of satisfaction. I won't spoil any as I'm sure you can just look them up if your interested enough.

Mmmmmm the mechanics in this game are simply JUICY. From the driving and movement to the shooting and the UI, everything feels smooth and good to handle. The driving is just so nice and makes you NOT want to use fast travel as you can have a fun time off-roading. The drive assist when your aiming and shooting also makes it feel so good and not at all clunky and difficult to do. The movement with parachuting and flying with your wing suit feels smooth and the swinging from grappling hooks and jumping across ledges feels snappy and parkour like. Everything about the shooting feels wonderful as well. The animations for it are well done and the handling feels natural and intuitive, leaving it all up to your skill to perform well. 

Oh, and one last thing, but there is a bonus "arcade" game mode, where you can verse people in death matches, explore user created maps, play through custom missions in said user created maps and earn small bonuses to the base game. Personally, I don't find these types of extra game modes very fun, but this one is pretty polished and worth a shot, as well as adding a fair amount of replayability to Far Cry 5. 

I could go on and on about what I like about Far Cry 5 and why you should get it, but I think you get the idea. That and I can't be bothered adding more. Of course wait till a 50%+ sale to get it, and it should give you about 50 hours of game play with all the DLC included, but of course if you really enjoy it, it will give you many, many more hours of game play. 


[b]LOST ON MARS DLC[/b]

Out of all the three DLC's, this one is the one with the most work put into it. It feels as if its taken the best aspects of both the other DLC's and the base game. This continues to have the wit and comedy of Far Cry whilst presenting something new, as there is a new (smaller then the base game) Mars map, several new space weapons, new unique missions and new alien bug type enemies. 

The missions all feel juuuust unique enough that they don't end up copying each other and over staying their welcome, as they range from parkour type puzzles, enhanced by the low gravity of Mars, to finding Hurk's Body parts (don't worry, he's mostly fine without them but would prefer them back).

The space guns are a welcome change from traditional fire arms and there is a surprising amount of variety in them, ranging from your traditional laser beam, to a guided plasma orb gun. 

The developers have done well to make the endless red desert of Mars into an interesting map with a decent amount of different locations. These include: space stations, satellite towers that you can climb up, alien dens, small rocky canyons, desert (of course) and even an area of the base game map in a dreamlike state. 

The alien enemies are pretty standard really, being giant bug like beasts, similar to other sci-fi films. There is about 3 or 4 different types of these bugs each with a different strength and weakness, but other then this, there isn't much else to say here.

Verdict: Probably the most worthwhile DLC out of all three, and is a nice change from the base game of Far Cry 5. Get this one while one sale.


[b]DEAD LIVING ZOMBIES DLC[/b]

Probably my favourite DLC of all three, this DLC involves 7 "movie pitches" which are essentially 7 scenarios you run through killing zombies, with much of it being scripted events, while "Guy Marvel" an overenthusiastic movie director wanna-be, pitches the idea of this to famous directors. 

These movie pitches take only about 15-30 minutes, but each feel different from each other. The scripting works in sync with your game play and feels really smooth. Not only this, but if you stray from the intended path and do a bit of exploration, you will often be rewarded with a better weapon and special dialogue, making it feel like you have found a cool little secret.

Also, after you complete each movie pitch, you will unlock the score attack mode, where you have to try and get as high of a score has possible, if that interests you. You can also unlock bonus weapons for the base game as well.

Verdict: if you enjoy bite sized missions that is full of the wit and comedy of Far Cry 5, definitely get this one.


[b]HOURS OF DARKNESS DLC[/b]

This is my least favourite DLC of all three, as it does use much of the same mechanics as the base game, but without a lot of the wit, character and atmosphere of the base game. The point of this DLC is that it is set in the Vietnam war and you're playing as an American helicopter gunner. The helicopter that you were in gets shot down and you have to try and make it to an evacuation point across the map from you. Whilst you do this, you can do extra (optional) tasks like collect lighters from shot down fighter pilots, rescue P.O.W's, destroy propaganda speakers, destroy AA guns and save your 3 other crew members. 

Here lies the the problem with this. These all feel the same. Each P.O.W rescue mission feels like a repeat of one outpost mission, each lighter and propaganda speaker feels like the same Prepper stash mission and to top it all off, there really is no point to doing this extra stuff as you don't unlock anything new, nor do you get a achievement for doing 100%. 

Verdict: It's fine if your looking for more far cry to play, otherwise, don't bother as it doesn't add much new stuff. Get it on sale if you still want to get it.

[h1]Negatives:[/h1]

- Gets a bit repetitive in some places. 

- In-app-purchases, but they are buyable with in-game money that you earn from playing so I don't mind them all that much. Still, it's a singleplayer game. No place for IAPs.

[h1]Positives:[/h1]

+ Scenery is gorgeous. Well designed world.

+ Game runs really well. On ultra settings I get 100+ FPS on 3440x1440 with my 1080 Ti.

+ Perk system is much better than the crafting system of previous titles.

+ Fishing is fun and relaxing (when you aren't being assaulted by planes or bears).

+ Characters are well developed.

+ Despite being a little hectic and imbalanced, the PVP multiplayer is really fun.

+ The map editor is great as usual and support in-game for sharing and playing other people's maps is incredible.

+ Air combat is decently fun.

[h1]Neutral:[/h1]

= There are a lot of bugs, but none game-breaking so far. Bears swim along the ground, enemies can slide 100 ft to cover, and vehicles often are flung dozens of feet into the air when they collide.

= Montana is nowhere near as, er... "diverse" as they are portraying. I know this is a work of fiction but it seems almost wishful thinking.

[h1]Summary:[/h1]

40.9 hours played in 5 days... I think that says enough. It's definitely worth buying. I feel like I got my money's worth already.

This games makes me want to live in its world and stock as many arms (guns) as possible because it's violently crazy, and I also don't want to die unarmed having been flanked by wildly uncut potheads.

A lot of people complained about setting this one in Montana, to which I say why the hell not?  The map is beautiful, well executed amalgamation of western MT, north of Missoula. For someone from Ohio or the UK, it's every bit as exotic as any other location.  As someone who has lived there, and still spends a lot of time there, it's a fantastic homage.

As for gameplay,  if you're familiar with the franchise, then you already know what you're getting,  Ubi hasn't diverged much from the long running formula.  It's very detailed without being particularly deep. Compared to previous titles, the region clearing feels very nerfed.  There's only three regions, with bosses at the end of each.  When you clear a region there are no longer any hostiles, so it just becomes a driving game in those places.  You can't really avoid pushing the game forward either, so it feels rushed. Also there is the obligatory point Ubi seems to put in all their games, where you're unavoidably captured, and wake up without all the weapons you've been collecting and you have to fight your way out...I HATE that, and really wish Ubi would just stop it already.

The voice acting is terrific, and there's a lot of great characters, which really helped make this the most immersive entry in the series so far.  Unfortunately, like all the other FCs, it suffers from some really absurd half-assed moral equivalency by trying to make the case the obviously demented evil psycho killers aren't any worse than you. The whole script comes off life a weekend effort by a twenty year old college kid who read way too much Ayn Rand.  That ridiculous,  chickens*** both-sides jive has always been a problem with Ubisoft, but it was particularly bad here.

Despite the issues, the game looks fantastic, and was a lot of fun to play.  I might have been disappointed if I'd bought it when it came out at full price, but I got it when it was on sale for $15 and I couldn't be happier with that.  At this moment, they are back to charging $60,so Ubi must have moved from Montreal to Qubecrazy...wait for a sale, they drop the price every few months.

[b]New Players[/b]
Far Cry 5 is a first-person shooter, open-world experience where you play as a American deputy set in an area in Montana where a cult has taken over the region and are promoting their ideology through force. You are set with driving the cult out, take back the region and deal with the mysterious figure known as The Father and his siblings.

[b]Review[/b]
I've been a fan of the Far Cry series since 3 and have greatly enjoyed the experience each had to offer with the open-world scene and the plenty of exploration based objectives to find. I have to admit though, the game hasn't changed all that much since FC3 other than the theme and environment. I suppose the greatest deviation is FC5 since a lot of the progression based objectives have been removed, but overall, the game play experience is very much the same. The game got gripe for being political and I won't lie, there were a couple of obvious ones like Hurk's dad, but for the most part, it wasn't as political as I expected it to be and it gave a good laugh for some of the more extreme examples.

[b]**Game Play**[/b]
What is there to say about all Far Cry games... they involve lots of exploring, lots of dealing with bad guys and at times some fun on the side stuff to do like fishing. There isn't really much to say about FC5 game play if you've played the previous ones. You start off with mediocre weapons that actually carry on well until the end, but the more you complete missions and liberate outposts, the more loot you'll unlock. FC5, however did remove the formula of completing challenges to unlock special weapons, and instead replaced it with unlocking skill points to improve your character. Not sure what they were aiming for, and perhaps it was meant to get the player straight into the action, but some of my best memories of FC is exploring the map and obtaining all the hidden loot, and completing hunting challenges to get the upgrades. You can get really beefed up quickly by just completing the easy challenges and only unlocking your most important skills. Most skills are meh in my opinion, but that's just my opinion.

Some negatives though are that the game very quickly becomes redundant and easy. As mentioned, you get beefed up really quickly and even on the hardest difficulty, things become easy and stale. One of the worst parts though was I felt very little need to use most weapons. I got what I wanted early and kinda just stuck with that. I barely used any of the herb-boosts and unfortunately, I later on felt no need to aim for 100% because there wasn't any reward for doing that. This is a great game, don't get me wrong, but it felt empty in comparison to its predecessors.

[b]**Graphics**[/b]
All FC games have this in common too... they are absolutely gorgeous ([i]for their time[/i]). FC5 is no exception. In fact, the landscapes are some of the most beautiful I've experienced in a game. Seeing the woods, the mountains, the detailed terrain, it's pretty damn impressive I have to say. So just from a graphical experience, I can recommend giving this a shot.

[b]**Story**[/b]
This is usually where FC shines as they have some of the most controversial, but outright awesome takes on character perspectives that I feel few games attempt to try. Since Far Cry 2, there's always some hidden figure just out of reach that is told is the real bad guy. As you progress however, the perspective also becomes clear that although the bad guy is in fact pretty bad, the ones fighting him are usually just as bad or at times even worse. It creates this interesting narrative of what are you truly fighting for? Are you really fighting the bad guy and does all of this make sense? FC5 is no exception to this and in fact I feel it takes it even further with a major twist at the end.

Without spoiling anything, all you need to know is that there's a cult causing mayhem and your main target is The Father, Joseph Seed. After the prologue, you have different regions controlled by his sibling, so each part has it's own dark, disturbing facets that need to be dealt with. It is however, an awesome and worthwhile experience.

[b]**Conclusion**[/b]
Is this a great game... HELL YEAH! It's fun and you'll most probably get engaged very quickly, but like its predecessors, it's a one time experience for me. I don't see myself playing this again, but I have no regrets for playing it.

It is a good game with a good setting, enfuriating antagonists whose every word and blind idiotic believe they are right makes you wanna brickfuck their faces into oblivion. 
Not too much filler-missions, a good balance of fun and serious moods - amazing graphics, of course, can´t do without those. I would have liked more opportunities to hear the game´s soundtrack and a speaking protagonist. 
But - no spoilers here - the ending is pure shit. This feels like a game-version of Stephen King´s "The Stand". Interesting characters in an interesting situation and the end leaves you with the shitty feeling of nothing having been accomplished. No justice dished out, no craving for vengeance satisfied, only lazy-ass writing and forced cutscenes (which happens a lot during the game, major minus here). 
I hate it when a game forces me into doing things I simply would not do for whatever reasons just to further its own story - or doesn´t even force me into doing it, but simply makes me watch it doing those things for me. Its railroading at its finest and I don´t like it.
So, in conclusion: 3/4 of the game are really good and fun. The other 1/4 is a fuckup in my humble opinion.

Ubisoft can go to Hell for their stupid DRM garbage. So much content and even air vehicles like helicopters and planes! This is one of the most beautiful games I've ever seen. My God the graphics are amazing and almost borderline on realistic and real life looking! Everybody took this game for granted! The characters are dull and boring! The villains are decent and better than the side characters. The story is also an interesting concept but done poorly. So much more to do in this game's world! You can fish and encounter so many random events on the roads and in the wild. You can rescue hostages and civilians who are being kidnapped or about to be executed. You can recruit allies and resistance remembers to fight alongside you. There is a friendly dog whose name is Boomer and a friendly Cougar by the name of Peaches and they can fight alongside you. You can get a friendly Grizzly bear whose name is CHEESEBURGER and he helps you fight and kill cultists! Also cool that for the first time in a Far Cry game you can pick which gender you want your playable character to be and even customize the looks and clothes you wear, but it's too bad you play as a silent protagonist again which I despise! Still suffers from optimization and performance issues. The endings are holy unsatisfying. Also this game is the most boring to me just doing the same thing over and over. I don't recommend this game unless you're playing multiplayer which is more fun.

I have mixed feelings. Mostly I feel slightly betrayed. The gameplay is pretty typical FarCry: fast paced shooter, lots of fun, mayhem, and explosions. The characters are engaging and the main villain is well designed. Where it falls over (and it falls hard) is the writing. The story writing, while at first quite engaging, becomes very repetitive and predictable. There's one story point that is repeated 2-3 TIMES IN EACH ZONE. It only makes marginal sense in one of the areas, but still... 8 times? 8??? The one time it DOESN'T stay repetitive is the end... and not in a good way. The end COULD have saved this game. It could have left the player with a sense of satisfaction. Instead the player is left feeling empty, because no actions made during the game made a difference. Nothing. If you weren't there there would be no difference. I looked up the ending I didn't get and the feeling is the same. 

TL:DR
Solid gameplay loop, terrible storytelling that makes the game not worth playing. Actually made me angry.

I do highly recommend this game, but with a caveat.

The gameplay is amazing. The arsenal you eventually have at your disposal is varied and fun. The main companions you can acquire are mostly cool and the vehicles are fun to use. Clearing out enemy bases is a blast and taking the time to fish is even fun.

However, almost all of the forced story portions are awful. My biggest complaint though, is the ending. There are three endings, as I have found out, and the one in which you "beat the game" is, in my opinion, one of the worst endings in video game history.

Everything else is great. I just think that with the amazing setting and enemy group could have led to better story points and definitely a better ending.

Theres a couple things it gets right. The combat and stealth is actually pretty satisfying when you get a bunch of skill points but thats mostly because of the braindead computer which makes the game laughably easy. The world looks amazing and the textures and character models are some of the best I've seen in any game ever. There's no bullshit RPG mechanics like assassins creed so you can play the game at your own pace and just do whatever you want to do. 

However, the story fucking sucks. The 4 main villains are pretty interesting but the game is too scared to do anything with them. The ending is fucking awful and the least satisfying conclusion possible to a 30 hour game. Also, none of the other characters are memorable except the dog and the bear. It's your standard Ubisoft format game with a big checklist of chores to do in the world that gets boring really really quick.

SPOILERS

Worst story of all far cry franchise. The father makes no sense, saying he wants to save everyone while their cultists kill people left and right. Then it feels like the story gives a forced twist just to give one. It clearly wants you to reflect on the effects of fighting violence with violence, but put you in one of the few situations in which violence is THE only option. On every other installment I felt the villain leaves you with food for thought, whatever your choice is, like Pagan Ming and the deplorable state of affairs you leave Kyrat in after choosing any of the rebel fighters side, making his path the sour-sweet "better" one. He is also a ruthless killer and dicatator, but he never claims to be anything but. The father instead is all about "I am giving you a chance", "I love you all", "I only drug you and strip you of your mind to save you"... like hell, he's killing left and right, hanging their carcases head-down from trees, then sticking twigs in their carcases to resemble deer, the whole place looks like a scene from Dante's inferno with so many of the townsfolk corpses laying around, and you are to forgive him to show you're the better man??? If you let him loose he's going to kill everyone!! How the fuck the medieval torture his "Family" members put the population through has anything to do with salvation (yeah, ripping pieces of your skin with a knive is totally because he wants you to join him in his bunker of salvation)! and then he lets you walk away from HIS grip because he's a mass murderer? And somehow if you forgive him the nuke doesn't fall? That's idiotic, the radios all throughout the land say that cities are being bombed left and right, so this bombing is not connected unless magic! Arrrggh, I am frustrated.
Far Cry 5 is one of the best games I have ever play it has, a Good story, A good villain, And looks good. I would recommend buying it.

This is, hands down, the worst game I've ever played.  This is not because the quality of the game is low, but because it is so effective at being bad.

Note to game developers:  It isn't rocket science.  Players should be the hero of their own narrative.  If you want to tightly control the narrative, make a movie.  Otherwise, let players make their own choices.  And, if you MUST script events to move a story in a certain direction, make sure those scripted events ADD to the fun and don't either suck the fun out or just make the player feel crappy.

FC5 makes you grind through repetitive world-wandering where you indiscriminately destroy bad guys and their stuff.  That, in itself, is not terrible.  You get to be the good guy and the game presents a villain that sort of begs to be destroyed ... so you can feel good about the fact that you are a mass murderer.  OK, that's sort of the game style.

But, where this game goes horribly off-track is that it makes you grind along at this repetition until you earn enough points to trigger scripted events that actually move the story forward.  In other words, you need to do a LOT of busy work before the game decides you have earned the right to advance the story.  This isn't based on whether or not you make good decisions - just whether or not you have sufficiently paid your dues in mindless repetition.

Then, it gets really ugly.  The scripted events just pluck you out of time and space once you have met the trigger conditions.  It really takes your head out of the game in a way that feels powerless.  No matter what decisions you have made and how intelligent you are, your character is forced into situations that you definitely would not have gotten into, had you been allowed to be in control.

In pretty much every scripted event, you are made to feel increasingly powerless and manipulated.  This is supposed to motivate you against the villain.  But, it really just reminds you that game isn't supposed to be fun - it is supposed to teach you a lesson.  And, that lesson is:  Puny player - you must do what we tell you to do.  You don't get to decide anything of consequence.

Again, that would be weak game design, but no weaker than most other games of the genre.  Where this crossest the line to become the worst game I have ever played is that the game takes what should be a heroic/savior character and forces the player to willingly participate in brainwashing to effectively become a more mindless mass murderer.

I am not really one to blame violence on video games, but this game is particularly effective at creating an environment that is almost unapologetically grooming mass shooters.  Some have pointed out that, in fact, some of this is more of a satire on violence in FPS games ... blah, blah, blah.  While that may have been the intent, that finer commentary is, I'm sure, lost on many impressionable players.

Regardless of the impact, it just isn't fun.  It just seems designed to make you experience futility to which the only remedy is mass violence.  I think that the game designers probably think this is clever - to invoke an emotional response in a video game.  But, it is not hard to make a player feel powerless or to motivate them to shoot characters.

It is way more clever to give players some choices that matter and to let them walk away from their time playing the game with a sense that it was fun and that they accomplished something.  At BEST, FC5 will just leave you feeling hollow.  More likely, it will leave you feeling worse than before you played it.  If it brings you joy, you are probably already a cult member.

...

On the positive side, the technical execution of the game is OK to excellent.  Some of the graphics/artwork is well above average, though not particularly unique.  The technical experience is solid with no real unpleasant surprises.

...

And ... now for some nitpicky stuff, but stuff that bugs me anyway.  If you look around, you will find plenty of commentary on much of the stuff that is annoying or makes no sense.  I won't focus on the common issues.  These comments are really directed at the game developers.

1)  Montanans do NOT have Texas accents.  The creative team seems get the West, Northwest, South, and Appalachia all mixed up.  This would be OK, as a fictitious world, but they made a point of setting this in Montana - specifically a few hours southwest of Missoula.  Almost none of the characters fit that region.

2) There really are extremist groups lurking about in that area, making it in really poor taste as a setting for this fictitious fantasy wasteland.  There is actually a town called Hope, ID which was probably the inspiration for the name of Hope County.  There are white supremacist and other idiot organizations in that region - more so than southwest of Missoula.

3)  I and my family and friends are from all over the region and no one I know has EVER seen a wolverine in the wild.  Yet, they commonly jump out and attack your crotch in FC5.  Similarly, we have mountain lions for sure, but you can live your whole life and never actually see one.  Yet, these are appearing and attacking randomly no matter where you are (alongside a major highway while a gunfight is going on, for example).  And ... bears almost never attack people, but moose do.  You got that backward.

4)  I couldn't prove it, but it appears that planes were able to take off and land from a forested hillside.  I did stumble across an enemy pilot idling a fighter plane on such a patch, completely surrounded by trees.  I didn't see how he got there, and I didn't see him take off, but another irritation is that the cult was able to deploy Spitfire-like fighter planes in just a few seconds whenever any cult member spotted the main character.  So, I assume they are just lurking in the trees?

5)  To limit my exposure, a few times I tried destroying a bunch of vehicles to effectively block the road from one direction.  This worked great except that I found that if I moved just out of sight for a few seconds, then back, the vehicles were already magically removed.  This generally follows a pattern in the game where spawning and de-spawning just make the world feel randomly-generated in a circa 1980s game sort of way.

Has that good old FarCry feeling. I would say it's even better than FarCry 6. I like 6 too but I forgot how in depth some of these mechanics in this game were. The graphics are beautiful but what I really love is the simplicity but comprehensiveness of the guns for hire system in this release. I can tell my follower to get in a gunship and when I tell them to follow me they don't jump out like an idiot they actually follow me. They'll use the gunship to attack hostile targets or targets I order them to attack. I can grapple the helicopter, mark a location for them to go to. hop out and parachute and get air support all fluidly. If i order them to specific spot they'll land and I can tell them to follow again and they'll hop out. I will say especially when it comes to flying the AI can get confused at times but its not that bad. It's nice to just be able to ride and look at the scenery on the way to a location. Good variety in side missions. Story is pretty good. Not much else to say. It good.

Far Cry 5 delivers an adrenaline-fueled, open-world experience that places players in the heart of an unforgettable rural American setting. As the latest installment in the acclaimed Far Cry franchise, this game maintains the series' signature elements while introducing fresh gameplay mechanics and an intriguing narrative.

The first thing that stands out in Far Cry 5 is its stunning visuals and attention to detail in the fictional Hope County, Montana. The vast, picturesque landscapes, dense forests, and varied terrain contribute to an immersive environment that beckons players to explore every nook and cranny. The world feels alive, teeming with wildlife and numerous interactive elements, making the journey genuinely engaging.

The storyline revolves around the sinister doings of a cult called "The Project at Eden's Gate," led by the enigmatic Joseph Seed. Players assume the role of a rookie deputy tasked with dismantling the cult and bringing Joseph to justice. While the narrative tackles some intriguing themes, the storytelling doesn't always reach its full potential, leaving some loose ends and unexplored character arcs.

Gameplay is the series' bread and butter, and Far Cry 5 continues the tradition of offering freedom and creativity in approaching missions. From stealthy takedowns to all-out mayhem, players have an arsenal of weapons and tools at their disposal. Furthermore, the "Guns for Hire" system allows players to recruit unique allies, each with their own abilities and quirks, adding depth to the gameplay experience.

One aspect that distinguishes Far Cry 5 from its predecessors is its focus on cooperative play. The entire campaign can be enjoyed in two-player co-op mode, fostering a sense of camaraderie and making the game even more enjoyable with a friend.

While the game offers an impressive array of activities and side missions, some players may find certain missions repetitive or formulaic over time. Additionally, the AI behavior of both enemies and allies occasionally exhibits quirks and limitations, which can slightly detract from the immersion.

In conclusion, Far Cry 5 delivers an exciting and visually stunning adventure set in a captivating open world. The gripping gameplay and cooperative features are definite highlights, even if the narrative falls short of fully realizing its potential. Fans of the series and newcomers alike will undoubtedly find much to enjoy in this action-packed journey through rural Montana.

The description of the game didn't provide an ample context for the setting. A "doomsday cult" poses itself as a legitimate Christian church that misrepresents what Christianity actually stands for is, in my opinion, damaging to Christianity and Jesus Christ Himself. in the first 30 minutes of the gameplay the characters slandered the name of Jesus about 5 times. As a Christian myself, I do acknowledge that there were many instances in history when self-professing Christians committed violent atrocities, and I would not have problem playing such games as far as historical accuracy was concerned. However, to gamers unfamiliar with the the message of Christianity, this game only causes the divide with faith to widen. Even though, knowing my faith I can discern where the false teachers and false prophets are, I cannot in good conscience support this game because of countless souls led astray by such extreme and inaccurate depiction. If you decide to play this game, please, do not perceive the antagonist and this "doomsday cult" as an actual depiction of Christianity because it is simply not so, and give Jesus Christ a chance to speak for Himself. Read the gospels according to Matthew, Mark, Luke and John and draw a conclusion for yourself if Jesus really taught those things, and whether or not He rose from the dead.

Hello everyone! I want to share my opinion on the game Far Cry 5.

So, I'll start by saying that I love this game! Far Cry 5 is an incredibly exciting game that takes you to the state of Montana, where you encounter the cult called "The Project at Eden's Gate." This game is amazingly well done, perfectly balanced, and has lots of interesting quests and missions. Moreover, I'm just in awe of the game world! It's so vast and diverse that you can spend hours wandering through the wilderness, driving cars, or boating. And it all looks amazing! The visual part of the game is surprising with its beauty and detail.

Now, of course, there are some things that I didn't like in the game. For example, it's not always convenient to navigate the map, and sometimes there are quite boring missions. But honestly, these are minor flaws compared to how huge and exciting world the developers have created. 

So, what's my final verdict? Far Cry 5 is simply an amazing game that you definitely need to try. If you love open-world, action, adventure, and humor, then this game should be on your "must-play" list. I would give it a 9 out of 10, and only because no game is perfect.

Far Cry 5 as a game itself is good and I'd say it's worth playing. However, DO NOT PURCHASE THE DLC!  
   The graphics are really nice, decent sound, gunplay/combat is satisfying, story is okay at best. Regardless, worth a play through.
   Despite that BASE GAME being worth it, I wouldn't waste any of your money on DLC. Even if it's on sale, don't.  The DLC is garbage in my opinion. The Zombies one are score/time based mini missions. Not bad but not great.  The Vietnam one is short and rather lackluster, basically you just try to get from one side of the map to the other with a few objectives in-between. Pretty sure it doesn't even take an hour to do.
   Now the Mars DLC is what really bugged me. It's bland and just boring. You're on Mars doing essentially the longest fetch quest possible fighting the same 2 enemies in an orange wasteland.

Awesome game. Took about 80 hours to complete everything the main campaign has to offer. Joseph Seed is an interesting character and a great addition to the series. Absolutely gorgeous graphics even for a game released in 2018 and the game runs really well too. One of the very few optimized games from Ubisoft. The shovel and shovel launcher are both hilarious amazing weapons to use. Possibly my favorite Far Cry game along with Far Cry 3.

My only issue with this game is the absolutely bonkers ending(s). Far Cry 5 is a great game with multiple (4 to be exact; 1 being a meme ending) completely unsatisfying and head scratching endings. The other day when I completed the campaign, I couldn't help but ask myself "What the fuck!?!?!?" sort of ending was that, and not in a good way. None of them are exactly a cliff hanger, but rather they aren't what the player truly wants and makes you also ask yourself why you played this game if it was going to end like that. One of the best-worst endings I've seen to a game. A true head scratching ending.

The only ending that I liked was the "secret" ending. That was hilarious and pure gold. The only issue is the game just ends right there and there's no game to play after that. You'll see what I mean if you figure out how to get that ending.

I highly recommend this game in Co-Op with friends and solo play. The story is interesting but the ending is typical Ubisoft being Ubisoft. One of my favorite games but I have to criticize Far Cry 5 for the stupid ending.

At first I was pleasantly surprised by this game. Once you break free of the first few missions, you can join a friend for what seems like one of the most chaotic, open co-op games I've ever played. There is the slight exception that you can't really travel too far from your companion without being teleported back to eachother. The other caveat being that you are quite literally kidnapped to be fed story and cutscenes over a dozen times. Its the only real way that the game progresses, The worst part, however, has to be the fact that Ubisoft basically forces you to 100% this game to even complete the basic story. You require a certain amount of resistance points to be "kidnapped" for the next story beat. This means that we had multiple hours where me were scouring the map looking for certain enemies that would only spawn every 45 minutes. Way to kill what could have been the best popcorn co-op game ever.

Like many of the Far Cry series, the game play is top notch. However, this entry falls short with the way it handles its story. NOT the story itself (though it ain't amazing), but rather in the way it handles itself.

The forte here is the co-op up to six players. The game doesn't feel as arcady as FC3 or 4, but feels more like a COD with a PvE feel to it; easy to die, easy to kill. It is fast and it encourages being aggressive. The whole crafting system from FC 3, 4 and Primal seems to have been thrown out the window.

I did appreciate the amount of ''partners'' you can have to accompany you, giving them orders and the fact that they can revive you was a major plus considering how easy it is to die. 

It is important to note that only the host will progress in his or her story (the map), none of the joined players will have any progress save (apart from their perks, guns and money). 

There are also some bugs, like invisible cars in multiplayer (which is hilarious, made me think of wonder woman in her plane), disappearing NPCs (enemies popping in and out of existence while driving), quests objectives that stick on screen... Nothing major, most of these are easy to shrug off. 

The acting and voice overs are great, but sadly there are too few story missions and too much freedom (I know, what? Too much freedom?!) It tends to make it lack continuity. I ended up doing many things in an order that made the game lack a lot of sense. But that's fine. I'm not even going to get into the endings. 

I should also mention the game has a big emphasis on religion, 'merica and might rub some people the wrong way. Personally, I thought it was funny. Especially Hurk. Gotta love Hurk.

All in all, it's a good game. It just didn't feel like a Far Cry at all. It's the RE 6 to the Resident Evils. But it's a blast nonetheless.

Fun Game, Ubisoft-steam integration awful:
For the people who have many bugs with ubi-connect etc. This is mostly because of the steam-ubi connection thing. Really stupid but when you buy a game from ubi over steam, they are most times very buggy and not working. To fix this issue you have to install the game via steam, so it registers in your ubi-acc with dlc's etc. Then you delete it from steam and install it again over ubi-connect. Then you will never have to use the stupid steam-ubi integration again and from that point on I could play the game as it was intented, and its really fun (besides the kidnapping cutscenes, but there are like only 6 of them so not too many) and my favorite FarCry game by far. The cult is very , shall we call it interesting?, and the game overall couldnt feel more american. Guns Guns Guns and some very stereotype shit. The map feels authentic as a ubisoft open world can be and the side missions are 95% all fun and not repetetive. i mean you have to harvest testicles from a bull with a fcking tractor with a shredder, do i have to say more? thats all i have for you know, but i really recommend getting all the dlc with it, Besides everyone hating the dlc, I personally  really enjoyed them. the vietnam one felt authentic, but a bit short and lost on mars is, well, weird but you can make pew pew on aliens so very cool aswell. Just dont expect any good story from the dlc, both are miserable in that part.  Get the agme and enjoy, I mean 13 bucks for the gold edition is worth it, just dont ragequit after the first 10 mins because you are stuck in a cutscene. Youll get used to it, that happens plenty. Sry for the review being a bit messy but i hope I could help some of you with your decision. :)

A really mediocre entry into the franchise. It's beautiful and the gun-play can be a lot of fun, but the game is obsessed with making sure you play it the way they want you to. For an open world game that invites you to take the game at your own pace and in your own ways this is particularly unforgivable. 
Periodically throughout the game it will declare your playtime finished, abducting the player, and then forcing them through some version of the same escape mission they have already done several times before. The game presents it as if you have a chance to avoid this fate but that is a smoke screen. 
In short, if you enjoy having choice in your open world games look somewhere else.

Took me a while to learn how the UI works because it is different than Far Cry 3 and 4, but once that was done I started to enjoy the game. The terrain is so beautifully crafted that sometimes I just had to slow down and enjoy exploring the mountain ranges and walking through the redwood forests, or swimming across a lake (the water looks so real). Far Cry 5 is now my favorite game in the series, displacing Far Cry 3. The plot line is not as linear as previous games in the Far Cry series. This game is about building resistance against the cult factions. This can be done in different ways. I gained a lot of resistance points by patrolling the main roadways and freeing citizen prisoners and destroying cult supply vehicles. If you like the Far Cry series then I think you will like version 5 as well. I'm only 55 hours in, but the Montana accent has rubbed off in the way I talk to my spouse or to myself. Hopefully, in time the effect will wear off or maybe the twang in my voice is here to stay. I like the NPC characters--most are good people that just like their independence. In that aspect the game developers where right on target.

I wasn't sure about this game at first; however, after 5-6 hours it started to grow on me. All the same Far Cry fun as the previous instalments, but bigger and better looking. Story is really interesting and the antagonists are really fun to go up against. Lots of other interesting characters also.

Gun play is good with a nice selection of firearms and explosives. Air combat is fun, nothing better than strafing an enemy convoy. 

I like the fact you can have allies, both human and animal. One downside is they can get in the way at times. Also if you park up your helicopter and they are around they will jump in and fly around meaning you can't. 

Only other annoyance is you can be roaming the open world in the middle of something and just suddenly be pulled in to a mission (captured) out of nowhere. 

Overall a really decent game, with all the usual gun play madness and thankfully not too many towers to climb :)

Imagine you're having sex.
Like, really good sex.
Not the best, but really good.

Then this convo starts...

(partner) "omg, it's coming!"
(you) "you're coming?"
(partner) "no, it's coming!"
(you) "what's coming?"
(partner) "my monologue about Alexis de Toqueville's Democracy in America!"
(you) "what?"
(partner) "omg, I feel it rising up!"
(you) "no, wait.. we're having sex! What if I fondle you some more..."
(partner) "it's almost here! It's inevitable no matter how hard you try to stop it!"
(you) "But, I want to keep having sex! I'm enjoying the sex!"

Then your partner freezes up, as if in a trance.
And, worse, suddenly you find yourself bound to the bed.
So, all you can do is lie there while they start up a powerpoint presentation on how the governments and society and blah blah blah

And like.. you really f*****g hate it.

But, you know if you just sit through it, eventually they'll shut up and you can get back to sex.

Now repeat that many times during your evening.

Now, fast-forward to the end.
You're nearing climax.
Aside from the crazy monologues on dystopia of the world, the sex has been pretty darn good.
So, this climax will probably be good, too.
And you're almost there. It's right there. You're just about to...

Your partner stops, gets up, and walks off saying "this isn't about you, it's about me. And I'm done here."

And you're left frustrated.
Everything you did is pointless, b/c it didn't end with a satisfying bang.

~~~~~~~~~~~

And that's Far Cry 5 in a nutshell.

If you've played Far Cry N, N+1, N+2, ..., then you've played Far Cry 5, and know the mechanics.

Pros:

+ They took the great graphics from Primal, and added guns

+ But, you're not focused on finding craftables like Primal, so you can actuall enjoy the graphics instead of "hunter vision" all the time

+ Some find the plot weird, insulting, etc (eg: they feel it's an allegory for christo-facists, so why did they allow black people into their fold?) I feel the plot is just about cults.. Manson, Koresh, etc style cults where a "cult of personality" leader  finds discarded people, gives them a purpose, and suddenly they have an army and are trying to take over everything. It's an interesting view into how cults work.

+ The exploration, random gun fights, base take overs, etc are fun. Open world sandbox with great graphics and "do what you want" is always fun. This is the "sex" I was talking about.

Cons:

- ... until they decide you're not allowed to have fun. And, instead, they feel you must be railroaded into a long-winded plot continuation against your will. This is the  "monologue" I was talking about. As you clear areas, a meter racks up. When it hits a certain milestone, instead of something good happening, instead the head bad guy of the area comes and forcefully kidnaps you into a cut scene.

If you're lucky, you just sit through some monologe'ing and can then get on with life. If you're not lucky, you get stuck having to control your character mucking through some drug-fueled dream state, or trying to escape some prison.

It's incredibly stupid.

The most important thing about the game should be the player. Is the player having fun? Is the player feeling a sense of accomplishment? Is the player feeling a sense of progress? Is the player feeling like they have some sense of control of outcomes?

Instead, the devs decided that their plot is more important than the player. So, they forcefully take away all player agency and shove you down the plot rabbit hole they dug for you against your will.

And it is forced.

You get a notice "You've been marked / blessed / etc"
Then you get another notice "a party is out to get you"
From that point on, enemies home in on you like you're lit-up with a neon sign.
And, even if you do everything you can to evade them, kill them, etc, they'll still magically capture you.

The Faith girl is worse, b/c she just says "you've been blessed", and if you ignore talking to her ghost enough she'll just insta-jump you a final time without any warning.

I was almost to the top of a mountain I was climbing looking for a stash. Suddenly I'm interrupted by a kidnapping from the girl out of nowhere.

I was done with a base, and ready to go to my next target. Nope, the head guy in the area called in his lackeys to kidnap me. So, I spent 5 pointless minutes running just for everyone in a truck to find me out in BFE nowhere as if by magic, and get caught.

The other problem is it breaks realism. If these folks instantly know how to find you when you've been "marked", why can't they just instantly find you all the time? It makes no sense.

I got kidnapped.
I escaped the prison.
Why doesn't the bad guy just "mark" me again, and have them zero in on me instantly?

Why?

Because.

There's no explanation other than the devs want to screw with you.

Whoever play-tested this game should have kicked-up a much bigger fuss about this garbage mechanic, b/c it almost makes this a down-vote from me.

The ending of the game basically taking away all impact you had on the game is also icing on the cake. This is the "your partner gets up and walks off right before you can climax."

It just leaves you frustrated.

So, those are my biggest complaints. There's other stuff I could nitpick.

But, I still give it a thumbs-up.

Why?

Because, at the end of the day, 90% of the game is fun.
It's a Far Cry game. It's fun.
But, it's also a Far Cry game, which means for some stupid reason the devs once again decided to have a stupid plot that has insert its stupid self into my stupid life just so I can get back to the fun. But, this time around, *I* don't get to control when the plot interrupts my fun; they decide when that happens. And that is an awful design decision.

A lot of bugs

The enemy NPCs act almost like the police on GTA V. They also attack you every second of the game. They recognize you everywhere. There is ALWAYS chaos.

This game is more like Call of duty zombies but in open world and instead of running away and shooting zombies you run away from enemies while shooting them etc....

Ally NPCs do whatever they want in the game.

This game is only CHAOS and MORE CHAOS with ultime unrealistic NPC behavior.

"I really didn’t enjoy this one. I feel like the developer did not respect their customers, and this is why:

The story: For me, there is no story, just a nice idea.

The characters: They don’t have any real interesting story, so you can’t get attached to them. They’re just 
there, which is the only part that I like - the animal companion, air support, etc. 
The hunting and crafting: The hunting is so lame like 10 shot for a turky. and crafting is really basic with only a few weapons.

The economy: You can sell very little things like animal fur for like 100-300 dollars, but weapon trinkets and other looting for trade do not exist.

The player character: The worst part for me is that the player has no voice! Come on! Is that a joke? I played for like 50 hours and I don’t even know my full name in the game. They may have mentioned it, but you don’t have any connection to the character.

The morality: Also, what is the idea behind killing innocent people who are under the influence of bliss and calling yourself a hero (with no voice)? 
I am really disappointed and I definitely won’t buy 6.”

The most fun of any of the Far Cry series, including FC 6. Decent action. Probably the best aspect is the community supported "Arcade," where users build their own levels in their own style. That's where I've spent most of my time.

Pros:
- Great graphics and optimization.
- Variety of rideable vehicles.
- Things to do more than just killing.
- Variety of interesting companions and their back story.
- When a region is free of cultists (lieutenant & side missions are cleared out), place becomes a lot nicer: no one wants to kill you while you fish (other than wild animals)

Cons:
- Variety of general populace.
- The story progresses you without warning, not giving you a chance to make precautions.
- Unable to save in key story missions.
- With the above two: If you get yourself to face off with one of the lieutenants, you'll have to do it, or else the only save will be before the other action/mission you did before reaching that high on the wanted list, making your next playthrough longer.
- Supposedly (at highest levels) you are the most wanted in the region, yet the roads can be so empty, you bore to death. That's contradicted when you don't want attention (applies to early stages too) and enemies just keep pouring in like there's no tomorrow.
- On later times, when the resistance gets high enough, cleaning out an outpost completely stealthed will be difficult as many times NPCs just show up and start a fight with the cultists, or an airborne dogfight is getting started above your head.
- Some missions are too easy to do, if you have an attack hellicopter, that is... Like helping Grace. There's no restrictions that you can't "cheat" (like when you had to blow up convoys with Nick's plane, but you did it with an attack chopper instead).
- The last mission (take on Father), is pretty much un-doable for casual players, or those who got more used to the stealth of the game.
