Meme's aside, Far Cry 5 is a pretty solid game, and worth playing with a friend, I thoroughly enjoyed my time, but the writing is very hit or miss in some places. 
Don't go into it expecting a typical Far Cry game, no exotic islands or pirates here, just American Values, and Religion.

Of all the characters, John and Joseph Seed are the two most memorable ones, Jacob is mediocre with horribly boring story sections until the second-last and last section. Faith is just an obstacle, and her fight is reminiscent of an old boss arena from a DOOM game or something.

John Seed's story was probably the more interesting one, even ending in one of my favourite fights (Especially Co-op).

The Gunplay is really fun, the Hunting is.. well very arcadey, but a nice distraction between missions, and the Fishing is relaxing, but not overly rewarding.

The Guns for Hire are awesome too (My last FC game was 3, so FC5 was a real interesting change), Peaches is by far my Favourite, while a Whitetail Sniper and Grace came second for Solo Play.
The Weapon Selection is neat, but feels lacking.

The driving in this game feels -really- good, compared to previous Ubisoft titles, it actually felt like I was driving a car, they had weight to them, grunt, and handled like a damn car, however, All cars in a category are the same short of weaponised ones. A Sportscar is the same speed as a family sedan.

The Monetisation is honestly not as bad as previous Ubisoft titles, it's.. completely unnecessary and completely avoidable.

The Story itself takes inspiration from Wildlands, as in it's a Semi-linear progression. You're not forced to follow a set path, instead, you can progress however you want, I enjoy it.

The character customization is decent, but, I personally would like more National Guard clothes, but, what we have is okay.

Sadly, the ending left me with more questions than answers, and it's only explained through Radio Broadcasts, it honestly felt like a kick in the face, there's no good endings here, all three end in ways to piss you off.

Let me clearly state that I AM ENJOYING THIS GAME. But, for the fact that this game has been out for over 2 years now, and it's still in its current state, tells a lot about Ubisoft's development cycle for this game.

I am a gamer who likes to typically give an exception to bugs either because 1. it's funny as hell, and 2. it isn't game breaking.

I have already taken a screen capture of an infamous "floating tree" in the valley of Hope/Sinner County...and as much as it pulled me out of the "immersion" of the game's story, I still could care less. Why? Because I could laugh about it amidst the game's slightly disturbing overtone for the story.

The game's story is its stronger point, which is both good and bad. When there are in-game cutscenes (AND THERE ARE A LOT OF THEM), these are the moments the story flow the best and feel the most fluent and immersive. The characters feel so hollow and empty-threat when they are sending goons out to kill you...but when you encounter them face to face, it feels and plays by experiences similar to that to Far Cry 3, when you fought Vaas, or Hoyt, or Citra's Giant, etc. It all panders to a really compelling set of characters that are portrayed in such a manner that the game is enriched just by their presence (prodominently Faith and The Father). However, this then all falls out the flippin' window onto a bed of spikes laced with laughing poison when you have to engage in 'combat' during a story mission, when the AI is just a bunch of morons.

The AI from Far Cry has never been something that monumental or ground-shattering, but the variety in enemy types is what divided super easy enemies from the not-so-easy. I look at Far Cry 4, and think about how many enemy types there are in that game, and how Heli gunships would fly in, along with just the sheer vastness of the fortresses. There was a lot of verticality brought into the mix when Far Cry 4 introduced the varying placement of outposts and fortresses, and allowed the player to abuse the grappling hook item. Here, I throw a proximity bomb where enemies are sure to run towards after I shoot a guy. I shoot a guy, they know where it's coming from (without detecting me), run up there and I just move to the other vantage point across the way, and kill the rest while the bumbling idiot AI just waltzes straight into my proximity bomb! Stupid EZ. What happened to the fear that Far Cry brought out? Far Cry 3 always stands as the pinnacle to the series, as the characters were likable and hateable, the gameplay loop was satisfying yet grindy, and the weapons/enemy variety was enough to not drive you insane...then Far Cry 4 took those concepts AGAIN, put it in a BIGGER map, and basically turned it into a base-capturing simulator, but with a story around it.

Here, I feel none of those things, but a pandering backseat story to the extremes of zealous religious cults taking it to the max in America.

But to keep this review short and to the point, I'll say this: Am I enjoying the game? Yes, I most definitely am! 
Do I recommend this game? Only on sale, and ONLY if you are willing to look past certain bugs (like I did). If you can't look past these things, you are gonna HATE this game.
Finally, is it worth the full price? HELL NO! Get this monster on sale, and consider the DLCs for another time. (got it for $9 bucks during the recent sales).

If you've played FC 3 and/or 4 you will probably be initially disappointed by this game. There aren't any towers to capture (which I personally enjoyed), the health system is different in that you can't heal without medkits, and healing with them takes longer than in FC4 or 3 BUT the entire health bar can heal naturally given time. I personally think that the map (which is set in Montana if I'm not mistaken) isn't as pretty as Kyrat, but it is still gorgeous, they definitely made improvements to the DUNIA engine in that regard. Making money near the start of the game is annoying, it isn't as plentiful as it was before in FC4, not helped by the fact that enemies don't drop things specifically to sell, and that enemy bodies disappear upon liberating an outpost. That means if you try to be sneaky and pick everyone off with a sniper rifle, you won't get the added benefit of being able to loot everyone when you're done (However there are bonuses given for no alarms and being undetected). Initially I found the antagonist to just kinda be annoying, but as I keep going, the story gets more and more interesting. So if you're like me and just finished Far Cry 4, give this a shot, play for about 10 hours or so, I think you'll find that it grows on you.

I was a huge fan of Far Cry 3, and somehow had skipped over 4. I went with Far Cry 5 as my next entry into the series as the setting intrigued me. There is a lot of fun to be had in Far Cry 5, however it is also a deeply flawed game.

I'll start with the good. First, the gameplay and controls are very intuitive and fun. Far Cry has always had a great feel to the guns and stealth mechanics. Radio Towers are no longer a thing, which is nice. You're immediately dropped into an open map and can pretty much go wherever you want right from the very beginning. The amount of vehicles, guns and companions can suit various play styles. The grappling hook is also a great addition to traversal.

Now, the bad. Unfortunately, the story was a huge letdown for me. I found all of the antagonists to be incredibly boring, cliche and lack any clear motivations. The whole story and dialogue felt like it was written by a teenager trying to be edgy, yet it never crossed any truly controversial lines. Eden's Gate is clearly inspired by some real-world far right religious cults, but Far Cry 5 has absolutely nothing original or interesting to say about any of it. The bad guys are basically just crazy for crazy-sake. This criticism extends to all of the other side characters as well. I found that none of the companions said or did anything remotely of interest, and half of them devolved into slapstick, sophomoric humor (nothing wrong with that in and of itself, however it doesn't really fit the narrative the game is clearly trying to tell).

Far Cry has always had some drug-fueled story lines, but Far Cry 5 really went overboard to the point that your character is drugged and/or hallucinating in just about every other cutscene. In fact, the Bliss drug is basically a narrative crutch anytime the game needs you to be at a disadvantage.

Character customization might as well be non-existent because the player models all look like Madden create-a-players, and you can't even alter their looks that much (seriously, only 5-6 hairstyles and no facial hair options?). I think the story also suffers from silent protagonist syndrome. Besides shooting people, your character never gets to directly intervene or interact with any of the other characters in a meaningful way. Now, I get why a lot of games go this route, but in order to pull it off, you need a much stronger story or some sort of dialogue options ala Fallout 3/New Vegas. 

I know I listed a lot more cons, but the game is very fun to actually play. Just don't expect any kind of groundbreaking storytelling.

There's not a whole lot I can add to it that others haven't already said in their negative reviews, but I'll give it the ol' college try anyway:

The Good:
Gameplay is Ubisoft doing what Ubisoft does. If you like Far Cry gameplay, you'll like this. It polishes the formula to a near mirror finish, and sets the stage for what would be built on in Far Cry 6 (if you've the choice of the two but can only get one, get 6. Seriously. 5 sucks, 6 is FUGGIN GREAT). The guns gun, the bows bow, and the cars go vroom. It has better car mechanics than Cyberpunk 2077 (not hard to do). The flight mechanics suck--don't fly a plane, get a helicopter.

It has all the features you know and love, hunting, gathering, crafting. The ability to take a base YOUR WAY, from stealth, to gunplay, to using nature, to mortars. Ya know, good ol' Far Cry Gameplay. Bullet Types add a fun dynamic, and the "hit Q and use the mouse scroll wheel to fly around" menu is very intuitive. I very much like the UI. Felt natural, and as it should be.

The friendly NPCs are fun, funny, and damn memorable. Hurk is a hoot, Nick is a nut, and Jess is a joy. Most of the time I had Jess and Peaches with me, though, since I prefer a stealthy approach.

The Bad:
Literally everything else. The story is garbage. It started off interesting enough, [strike]Jim Jones[/strike] [strike]David Koresh[/strike] [strike]Randal Claude Weaver[/strike] Joseph Seed is under arrest for kidnapping and assault at the very least, probably murder as well. Not to mention the drugs. Lots of drugs are involved. He's got an entire cult around him that decide "Hey, they showed up in a heliochopter, let's make sure the whirlybird what's got our Beloved Leader on it [i]CRASHES![/i]" cause ya know that makes sense.

After that it just goes down hill. You escape, of course, and meet up with the Resistance. Every "Resistance Level" you gain, though, you're interrupted by one of Seed's lieutenants (also a family member-YAY NEPOTISM!) in an absolutely unavoidable railroaded "hunt party" kidnapping. Or ya know, a cloud of psychedelic drug gas. Whatever. Point is, you get railroaded off to these absolute... well, I was going to say demagogues, but they don't play as much to prejudice as they do to fear and emotion. Anyway, you get to listen to them monologue at you--with no way of escaping or walking away--even in the one section where that appears to be an option. And they don't just put a bullet to you. Knowing full well you're harming their cause. Nor can you just put a bullet to them. Because... Reasons?

And then there's "the Bliss." Or I should say there's "the Bliss" the drug, and "the Bliss" the state of... being? I guess? It's all really rather very silly. Anyway, the drug is basically, as others have said, Ubisoft's catchall for whatever they need for plot. It makes people a mindless zombie. It's a mind control agent. It makes them instantly swap over to Seed's side. It's whatever it needs to be for the narrative to move forward. It is the ultimate lazy writing drug. And when combined with other plants in the area, the player can use it to boost their speed, strength, and other attributes! Woo hoo! Cause that makes sense somehow?

Then there's the narrative itself. I'm not going to go into too much detail, other than to say it's all over the place in tone, and it takes away player agency A LOT. I mean a whole friggin' HEAP. More than just railroading you. It's the Bullet Train to No More Agency.

The Ugly:
Put it this way: Rock Paper Shotgun called the ending "The Worst Ending In Video Game History." I don't know as I'd go that far, but I will say it's the worst piece of writing in the Far Cry series. Possibly the worst piece of writing in Ubisoft's history. It's just really, really badly done. It's out of left field, it's not only unexpected, it literally negates everything you as the player have done for the past uh... I have 28.3 hours as of writing this, cause turns out guess what? Once you get to the end? That's the end. You don't get to go and wrap up all those other sidequests you had left. So make sure you're ready. Cause to quote Jar Jar Binks, "you say BOOM degasser, den crash in de Boss' hedlibber, den BANISHED."

The Irritating:
Ubisoft requires Uplay to make this work. I've had mixed results with Steam+Uplay, sometimes the game links, sometimes it don't sometimes it asks for a key, and when that happens, it's time for a refund. Obviously, I was able to get this one to work. But YMMV, Buyer Beware, all those other caveats.

TL;DR-Gameplay is Far Cry Gameplay: Liberate outposts, stop the convoys, find collectibles, stare at people till little icons appear over their heads like fairies on Christmas Trees. Everything else is hot garbage. And that garbage is on fire. And the fire is on your trousers. And there's a badger loose in them. And he's very upset at being in your flaming trousers. What I'm driving at is it's a very bad situation and no one should ever want to subject themselves to it if they can avoid it.

Far Cry 5 is a very underappreciated game. While I firmly believe Far Cry 4 is the peak "power fantasy" title and Far Cry 2 is the best overall, Far Cry 5 offers an experience that takes some of the best out of every prior entry.

The plot is by no means special, but it's well written (for the most part) with funny satire, commentary that is still welcome and relevant in 2023, and actually interesting side-characters. The villains are fun, with Faith and Joseph himself taking the cake as the best due to them being deeper and more complex than John and Jacob (mind you, the latter two are still a joy to see, specially Jacob).

The gameplay trims down on the boring aspects of Far Cry 3 and 4. You aren't handicapped by boring crafting that forces you to go to the middle of nowhere and pray what you're looking for spawns. All items have their own slots, with the stuff you can sell never getting in the way of your crafting components. The Deputy is very mobile and versatile from the start, with nearly all takedowns unlocked right from the get go. Whatever's left, alongside other traits and extra equipment slots, they are all locked behind the perks, which this time are unlocked by spending points you earn through challenges and exploration instead of an arbitrary XP system. It's also rather hard to get rich in this game, which is welcome.  The game is also rather hard, even on Normal, as the Deputy feels like a glass cannon.
This game released right before Ubisoft turned the series into a low quality looter shooter, too, so the gunplay is at its peak: weapons all handle differently, bullet travel and gravity are a real thing to worry about, and it overall feels satisfying.

It isn't a perfect experience, but it is nonetheless fun and it got more hate than it deserved. The game also has full campaign co-op and the Arcade mode, complete with an extremely advanced map editor that allows for infinite replayability. At a discount, this game is a must for any first person shooter fans, open world fans or co-op fans.

A game I just can't stop coming back to. Story isn't that great (captures suck and interrupt whatever you're doing), a lot of the missions are weak (progressing the story through world activities is so much better), and the resistance characters don't have the same impact as in previous games with you rotating regions and not getting enough time with them. Even The Father suffers from this, not intimidation or charisma but a 3 sniveling broadcasts and a few cut-scenes. As a Far Cry game it is beaten out by 2, 3, 4, and even primal in my potentially controversial opinion.

But,
BUT,

Hope County Montana is one of my favorite settings in gaming. When you are walking through the woods, hunting or exploring or whatever, and you turn and look past the trees to see beautiful big sky Montana with acres of trees and flowing creeks and fish jumping from lakes GOD DAMN. I can't tell you how many times I've just stopped and stared, soaking in the world and ambiance, having the soundtrack start playing and having a moment of peace before the murder kicks up again. Noticeable variation to the 3 regions keeps things fresh with enough areas of interest and much to explore (I really liked the treasure hunts, some bland but others were piecing together stories of survivors or had an interesting gimmick). Speaking of the soundtrack, its fantastic. If they made religious music like whats in the game I'd be a choir boy by now. Both energetic christian country and choir music that gives strange feelings of belonging and hope in a way (besides the murder). Not to mention the beautiful instrumental violin, piano, and BANJO tracks, I never thought I'd enjoy a banjo but here we are. Each region has its own songs and 'genre', keeps the music feeling new and really well represents the sibling of the region you are in.

The weapons are fun to play with, especially giving each gun a test run at an outpost (with a few game-y mechanics and weak sound effects aside). My favorite thing to do is to get a hunting rifle, get the cost of a gun and it's upgrades that I want to mess around with, and hunt and adventure until the the cost is met. The game def goes full 'Murica with the number of well modeled firearms and not even mentioning all the spawn-able weaponized trucks and cars. Far Cry 5 goes the farthest into the sandbox genre, adding a whole bunch of land, sea, and air vehicles to mess around with. Some vehicles do outright break the games difficulty but who can deny the fun of rocking up to a fight with a semi truck armed to the teeth or flying a helicopter and raining death from above. Is having to handicap yourself in a game to even have a challenge good game design? Not really, but it is just so much fun here I don't mind being death incarnate (I think in the cult you they believe you to literally be 'hell' so why not live up to that). 

There is enough to this game I think it's worth your time. I only glossed over the main things I liked, not even mentioning co-op, arcade mode, or the characters and missions that are actually pretty good. If you are a Far Cry fan or just an fps enjoyer pick it up at a discount unless you are needing Montana time desperately and flights are too expensive.

This game is an experience that conveys some very strong messages about the modern world, whilst incorporating key features and mechanics that make FPS games engaging. It's been thoroughly well done and the developers should be proud of their accomplishment.

This game took me out of my comfort zone and shone a light onto some subjects that made me feel uncomfortable, and made me think about the subjects they were portraying. All of these are positive things and an achievement for games to do such things for their audience.

The reason I don't recommend it?

1. Limited 2 player co-op only, with a maximum distance threshold of about 800m makes the trailer of 2 players flying planes obsolete and misleading. Ghost Recon Wildlands was released 1 year before (2017) with 4 player co-op with zero tether mechanics (meaning you could travel the entire massive map without penalty). Likewise FC5 and shares some familiar systems with Wildlands, but fails to meet cooperative expectations. Yes, they were developed by different branches of Ubisoft, but that's not an excuse for AAA. Additionally Breakpoint (2019) was later updated to support quality of life features - Ubisoft can certainly do the same here. It's my opinion they choose not to and I think poorly of them for doing so. Were they to leave it and just have it singleplayer only? I could completely respect that - however to advertise only 2-player co-op AND with tether mechanics seems to highlight a wider, systemic problem with Ubisoft as a developer and publisher and the disconnect from their fanbase.

2. 90% of the time I spend senselessly killing people, animals etc. I would have hoped for more dynamic gameplay and narrative options that reflected this. I appreciate that this is part of a wider, meta narrative to emphasise a pessimistic view of America (and world), but in my opinion it was very heavily imbalanced (emphasising the senseless killing too much) and made gameplay dull rather quickly and lost it's meaning. To me that is the antithesis of a game trying to make a point / present an agenda. Dialling it back on the constant shooting / killing would contribute to the overall message of the game in my opinion by making it so when you do take a life, it would have more meaning. Yes they're cultists, but it very quickly just become "they're mobs in the way of me progressing the story". I became quite quickly emotionally detached from this aspect of the game. I would have been very interested to tackle additional themes like redemption which the game seemed to shy away from, despite the overarching religious themes (i.e can you turn cult members? Can you play against the resistance? Could you convert resistance members?).

3. Some of the overarching narrative felt a little stale. I found myself disagreeing with a lot of choices that characters made, or seeing cheap plot devices to extend the plot. Far Cry is an IP that isn't shy to hidden or alternate endings (Ubisoft in general with games like Wildlands which also had alternate endings). I would have preferred the option to explore alternate routes in the *narrative* rather than be forced down a linear path (as mentioned above in my earlier point). Even if this was basic gameplay like faction management etc. There are 3 endings to this game, but in the end players' actions don't mean squat until the very end of the game. 

4. Being hunted is completely unavoidable. I've been hit with various sleep bullets/bliss/etc whilst inside resistance HQs (Wolves Den for example) - extremely immersion breaking. I would have preferred an escalation mechanic similar to other Ubisoft games (like escalated notoriety mechanics) to make it overwhelming for the player and truly give the player a sense of challenge, accomplishment and like they're being properly hunted. Again, poor plot device. Wildlands did it, so should Far Cry. Additionally what happens to companions when the player is taken, narratively speaking? It was jarring and disappointing for an otherwise immersive experience.

5. Pacing was off throughout the game. It seemed to jump between intense, fast paced action - to mandatory slow pace. There was a reason people got upset with Bioware when they forced players to walk in Anthem: we don't like being forced into a single play style. There were moments when it felt like the game dictated the pace so much that I may as well have just decided to watch a movie.

6. I found it hard to connect with characters emotionally or care about them in some instances. This is a personal point, but due to the game design and the scope of what was immediately available: i.e being able to go anywhere or do anything, I had a weird sense of just needing to tick off all the people in a region so I could fight the main bad guy, and then move on & repeat until finally confronting the Big Bad™. This goes back into pacing, but too many options and too much freedom in the beginning gave me the sense that my actions weren't really going to matter and that the ultimate goal was getting to Joseph, not helping free people. Especially when it came to freeing people - I would have preferred people with names, not randomly spawned NPCs. It would have made hostages being executed much more impactful. So again with pacing - just easing into the game with a direction that slowly opens up the overall goal would have been beneficial for gripping my attention, rather than just a tick list of names to help and meaningless actions. I think this was most emphasised satirically by the FBI agent & the rather meta fetch quest you do for him.

7. Despite Dutch telling me I wasn't going to have to climb up towers for the rest of the game, I did, in fact, climb up and down towers for the rest of the game. (I joke... Kinda).

8. Finally the Ubisoft Formula™: It's not a bad thing to build on what you've already got and used established mechanics and tools. However Ubisoft games are starting to feel pretty much the same at the moment, with just different themes. Hostile area, slowly liberate it. It worked well for Ghost Recon games because it's that "operator/blackops-vibe", but I found it wasn't enough to rely upon when making games like Far Cry where there are big, sweeping themes. In my opinion, the narrative and plot development also needs to take a front row seat to ensure that the player connects with that theme in some way (regardless if positive or negative).

9 (Cheeky). Mute protagonists drive me crazy. Fallout 4 was a great example of telling the story of Nate / Nora. Cyberpunk about telling the story of V. I would enjoy playing a Far Cry where I control a tangible protagonist rather than someone who is mute. This may have been a factor into the duality of immersion and total emotional disconnection - because I was just being talked at for the *entirety of the game* with little agency. There was no emotional connection between the deputy and the players. When you conclude the Whitetail story line, it didn't have an impact on me because there wasn't that emotional connection that I was expecting to have between the protagonist and the other characters. To top this off - there weren't any dialogue options, which really sealed the deal. I could not express my views, I was just simply watching a movie with extra steps.

Overall it was a good game, but Ubisoft could have, and has done better. Especially for open world games, Ubisoft needs to take a leaf out of Bioware, Bethesda and CD Projekt Red's narrative books on how successful open world & narrative driven games are designed. Players need agency to express their wants and control the protagonist their way, not be told or forced into a specific direction. If Ubisoft is going to do that, then they need to commit to the direction of linear story and not wrap it up as something pretending to be an open world game with any illusion of control on overall narrative beyond a few main plot points which lead to similar conclusions.

Before buying this game my only other experience of the Farcry series was Farcry2. I know it wasn't the best but I enjoyed it. When I noticed this game had gone on sale I debated purchasing it and I have to say, it was probably the best decision I've made. Some things aren't perfect, but I've yet to have the game break on me. The open world feels much like Farcry2 in the aspect of you literally get to do whatever you want. The world is also super interactive; companions converse with each-other and other npc's, there's a couple puzzles, and action is never too far away. I think what has grown on me the most though, is the sound track and the loading screens. I don't think this game gets enough credit for the amount of work that was put into it. Honestly worth full price.

Going to give this game a recommend because the positives outweigh the negatives, but to be fair there are negatives. 

Positives:
Great game play and mechanics.
Great map and characters. 
Nice weapons and features although you will end up finding a default that works too soon.
Great vehicle options that have good drive features. 

Negatives:
CUT SCENE HELL. The cuts have broken 2 rules for me and they don't do it well. They lock you into a linear story that you can't escape and always has a negative result. In the majority of them you have to traverse a linear space but are forced to do so as though you were frozen and then dipped in tar. Though they have good cinematic value clearly someone was too impressed with their work to let you consume it at your pace. This is almost unforgivable.

At first, I didn't know whether to buy this game. Mostly because the game felt very AMERICAN, and I wasn't really attracted to it. I ended up buying this game and Far Cry 5: New Dawn at a huge discount, and I really think it was worth it. I gave it a try and I don't regret playing it at all.

The story or stories are really good. I really liked Joseph Seed as the antagonist. The best part of the whole story, in my opinion, was Faith. I understood her character very well and I really liked what role she played in the story. Her story is sad, and I could somehow relate to her. In the end, I ended up feeling sorry for her, which I liked, because I don't really feel that sorry for some of characters in games as much as I was for her.

The side missions were quite good, at least some of them, some are very irritating, but others quite enjoyable.

The gameplay is different, very good for the most part. The only things that didn't really satisfy me were the takedowns. They were ok, but it would've been better if they didn't change them. The flying system/gameplay is very good, I really I enjoyed it.

One of the best things about this game is the map. I love it, the atmosphere is great, the animals add a lot to the map, a wild vibe, I really liked it.

The graphics are beautiful, the game looks better than the previous one, so that's good.

There are some minor bugs here and there, some of them quite annoying, but nothing to really complain about.

In conclusion, I recommend buying this game only at a discount, I don't think it's worth the full price. It's a good game, not excellent, but a really good one, and i enjoyed it.   8.5/10

I'm disappointed, but not surprised. I really enjoyed Far Cry 3 and Far Cry 4 and was hoping Far Cry 5 would offer more of the same, but unfortunately for all the objective improvements it just feels...soulless. Normally I make a long bulleted list of all the positives and negatives, but since I won't be finishing the game I won't do that here.

I do have the admit that the graphics are excellent and the environment design is pretty amazing: the forests are surprisingly realistic. Unfortunately, beyond this pretty facade lies...more of that, more facade. The game's story tries way too hard to be cinematic. Sure, the prequels were to a degree, but they still had some willingness to be excessive and borderline silly. They still felt *game-y*. Far Cry 5 takes itself way too seriously, and presents itself as this epic dramatic film-game. In fact, this is fueled by the "improvements" made that ostensibly removed the repetitiveness, but actually just hid it behind the guise of more storytelling and writing. Instead of racing missions you have sidequests that [i]just so happen[/i] to be races; instead of hunting missions you have sidequests that [i]just so happen[/i] to require hunting. Every aspect of the game is about you being the local hero, but I really appreciated how, for example, Far Cry 4's hunting missions were just you slaughtering rare animals on the whims of some deranged fashion designer. That was funny! Hunting bears to "save the ranch"? I don't really care.

I see so much promise, too -- I think the religious elements and the character development of the villains goes in a very interesting direction, but falls short of actually being compelling. I could go on, but it just doesn't feel worth my time.

Go play FC3 or FC4.

Saw this for the summer sale but unfortunately the game wasn't all it was hashed up to be. First off if using a gamepad, reverse controls dont work or descending in aerial vehicles. There are multiple claimed fixes posted but I couldn't get one to work. As someone who has applied their own control to a gamepad for even games such as Tarkov or Ground Branch and had more success setting those up, reverse still doesnt seem to work unless using keyboard. The most recommended fix at the least requires you have to reset or disable certain controls (either in game or steam, not sure as i tried all methods to no avail) and you have to do this every time you start the game. Sorry i really dont want to do that.
Gameplay wise the story sounds great and pulled me in to buy it. However, gameplay gets very repetitive fast. Even if you unlock a third weapon slot it seems pointless to use any other gun aside from the enemy rifles etc. as even trying to sneak or play stealthy getting detected can just lead to a constant firefight of enemies showing up. Traveling on the roads is almost impossible to not get detected, however traveling off path you can still get detected and have a truck follow shooting you, which forces you to stop or have to attack from vehicle which draws more enemies to your position and leads to another tedious time consuming firefight with not enough ammo so you have to pick up enemy weapons or take their ammo. After enough times dying and spending either too much time trying to avoid enemies to reach a destination or obj, or getting caught and starting another firefight which even potentially lead to you winning and then all of a sudden you get killed by a bear, wolf or an eagle that you will often see attacking people near roads or off path. 
Overall, its a great looking game, but i just feel like i'm playing a better looking Ghost Recon Breakpoint.
Now it doesn't mean alot of people wouldn't enjoy this game, but its just constantly, CONSTANTLY being surrounded by enemies of all types, nothing too dynamic with shooting options as select fire would be nice. The ability to go prone would be nice as well, and AI detection is a little weird but manageable and various types of playstyles don't seem to be encouraged or easily done compared a more meta option.
